  • Typing Style Guide

docs.title: blank-line-with-whitespace (W293)
docs.text:
Derived from the pycodestyle linter.

Fix is always available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for superfluous whitespace in blank lines.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: According to PEP 8, "avoid trailing whitespace anywhere. Because it’s usually invisible, it can be confusing"

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
class Foo(object):
    
    bang = 12

Use instead:

class Foo(object):

    bang = 12

docs.title: Fix safety
docs.text: This fix is marked unsafe if the whitespace is inside a multiline string, as removing it changes the string's content.

docs.title: blank-lines-after-function-or-class (E305)
docs.text:
Derived from the pycodestyle linter.

Fix is always available.

This rule is unstable and in preview. The --preview flag is required for use.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for missing blank lines after the end of function or class.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
PEP 8 recommends using blank lines as follows:

  • Two blank lines are expected between functions and classes
  • One blank line is expected between methods of a class.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
class User(object):
    pass
user = User()

Use instead:

class User(object):
    pass


user = User()

docs.title: Typing stub files (.pyi)
docs.text: The typing style guide recommends to not use blank lines between statements except to group them. That's why this rule is not enabled in typing stub files.

docs.title: References
docs.text:
• PEP 8: Blank Lines
  • Flake 8 rule
  • Typing Style Guide

docs.title: blank-lines-before-nested-definition (E306)
docs.text:
Derived from the pycodestyle linter.

Fix is always available.

This rule is unstable and in preview. The --preview flag is required for use.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for 1 blank line between nested function or class definitions.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
PEP 8 recommends using blank lines as follows:

  • Two blank lines are expected between functions and classes
  • One blank line is expected between methods of a class.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
def outer():
    def inner():
        pass
    def inner2():
        pass

Use instead:

def outer():
    def inner():
        pass

    def inner2():
        pass

docs.title: Typing stub files (.pyi)
docs.text: The typing style guide recommends to not use blank lines between classes and functions except to group them. That's why this rule is not enabled in typing stub files.

docs.title: References
docs.text:
• PEP 8: Blank Lines
  • Flake 8 rule
  • Typing Style Guide

docs.title: blank-lines-between-header-and-content (D412)
docs.text:
Derived from the pydocstyle linter.

Fix is always available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for docstring sections that contain blank lines between a section header and a section body.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
This rule enforces a consistent style for multiline docstrings.

Multiline docstrings are typically composed of a summary line, followed by a blank line, followed by a series of sections, each with a section header and a section body. There should be no blank lines between a section header and a section body.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
def calculate_speed(distance: float, time: float) -> float:
    """Calculate speed as distance divided by time.

    Args:

        distance: Distance traveled.
        time: Time spent traveling.

    Returns:
        Speed as distance divided by time.

    Raises:
        FasterThanLightError: If speed is greater than the speed of light.
    """
    try:
        return distance / time
    except ZeroDivisionError as exc:
        raise FasterThanLightError from exc

Use instead:

def calculate_speed(distance: float, time: float) -> float:
    """Calculate speed as distance divided by time.

    Args:
        distance: Distance traveled.
        time: Time spent traveling.

    Returns:
        Speed as distance divided by time.

    Raises:
        FasterThanLightError: If speed is greater than the speed of light.
    """
    try:
        return distance / time
    except ZeroDivisionError as exc:
        raise FasterThanLightError from exc

docs.title: References
docs.text:
• PEP 257 – Docstring Conventions
  • PEP 287 – reStructuredText Docstring Format
  • NumPy Style Guide
  • Google Python Style Guide - Docstrings

docs.title: blank-lines-top-level (E302)
docs.text:
Derived from the pycodestyle linter.

Fix is always available.

This rule is unstable and in preview. The --preview flag is required for use.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for missing blank lines between top level functions and classes.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
PEP 8 recommends exactly two blank lines between top level functions and classes.

The rule respects the lint.isort.lines-after-imports setting when determining the required number of blank lines between top-level import statements and function or class definitions for compatibility with isort.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
def func1():
    pass
def func2():
    pass

Use instead:

def func1():
    pass


def func2():
    pass

docs.title: Typing stub files (.pyi)
docs.text: The typing style guide recommends to not use blank lines between classes and functions except to group them. That's why this rule is not enabled in typing stub files.

docs.title: References

  • Typing Style Guide

docs.title: blanket-noqa (PGH004)
docs.text:
Derived from the pygrep-hooks linter.

Fix is sometimes available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Check for noqa annotations that suppress all diagnostics, as opposed to targeting specific diagnostics.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
Suppressing all diagnostics can hide issues in the code.

Blanket noqa annotations are also more difficult to interpret and maintain, as the annotation does not clarify which diagnostics are intended to be suppressed.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
from .base import *  # noqa

Use instead:

from .base import *  # noqa: F403

docs.title: Fix safety
docs.text:
This rule will attempt to fix blanket noqa annotations that appear to be unintentional. For example, given # noqa F401, the rule will suggest inserting a colon, as in # noqa: F401.

While modifying noqa comments is generally safe, doing so may introduce additional diagnostics.

docs.title: References
docs.text: • Ruff documentation

docs.title: blanket-type-ignore (PGH003)
docs.text: Derived from the pygrep-hooks linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Check for type: ignore annotations that suppress all type warnings, as opposed to targeting specific type warnings.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
Suppressing all warnings can hide issues in the code.

Blanket type: ignore annotations are also more difficult to interpret and maintain, as the annotation does not clarify which warnings are intended to be suppressed.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
from foo import secrets  # type: ignore

Use instead:

from foo import secrets  # type: ignore[attr-defined]

docs.title: References
docs.text:
Mypy supports a built-in setting to enforce that all type: ignore annotations include an error code, akin to enabling this rule:

[tool.mypy]
enable_error_code = ["ignore-without-code"]

docs.title: blind-except (BLE001)
docs.text: Derived from the flake8-blind-except linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for except clauses that catch all exceptions. This includes except BaseException and except Exception.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
Overly broad except clauses can lead to unexpected behavior, such as catching KeyboardInterrupt or SystemExit exceptions that prevent the user from exiting the program.

Instead of catching all exceptions, catch only those that are expected to be raised in the try block.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
try:
    foo()
except BaseException:
    ...

Use instead:

try:
    foo()
except FileNotFoundError:
    ...

Exceptions that are re-raised will not be flagged, as they're expected to be caught elsewhere:

try:
    foo()
except BaseException:
    raise

Exceptions that are logged via logging.exception() or are logged via logging.error() or logging.critical() with exc_info enabled will not be flagged, as this is a common pattern for propagating exception traces:

try:
    foo()
except BaseException:
    logging.exception("Something went wrong")

docs.title: References
docs.text:
• Python documentation: The try statement
  • Python documentation: Exception hierarchy
  • PEP 8: Programming Recommendations on bare except

docs.title: blocking-http-call-httpx-in-async-function (ASYNC212)
docs.text:
Derived from the flake8-async linter.

This rule is unstable and in preview. The --preview flag is required for use.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks that async functions do not use blocking httpx clients.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
Blocking an async function via a blocking HTTP call will block the entire event loop, preventing it from executing other tasks while waiting for the HTTP response, negating the benefits of asynchronous programming.

Instead of using the blocking httpx client, use the asynchronous client.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
import httpx


async def fetch():
    client = httpx.Client()
    response = client.get(...)

Use instead:

import httpx


async def fetch():
    async with httpx.AsyncClient() as client:
        response = await client.get(...)

docs.title: blocking-http-call-in-async-function (ASYNC210)
docs.text: Derived from the flake8-async linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks that async functions do not contain blocking HTTP calls.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
Blocking an async function via a blocking HTTP call will block the entire event loop, preventing it from executing other tasks while waiting for the HTTP response, negating the benefits of asynchronous programming.

Instead of making a blocking HTTP call, use an asynchronous HTTP client library such as aiohttp or httpx.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
import urllib


async def fetch():
    urllib.request.urlopen("https://example.com/foo/bar").read()

Use instead:

import aiohttp


async def fetch():
    async with aiohttp.ClientSession() as session:
        async with session.get("https://example.com/foo/bar") as resp:
            ...

docs.title: blocking-open-call-in-async-function (ASYNC230)
docs.text: Derived from the flake8-async linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks that async functions do not open files with blocking methods like open.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
Blocking an async function via a blocking call will block the entire event loop, preventing it from executing other tasks while waiting for the call to complete, negating the benefits of asynchronous programming.

Instead of making a blocking call, use an equivalent asynchronous library or function.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
async def foo():
    with open("bar.txt") as f:
        contents = f.read()

Use instead:

import anyio


async def foo():
    async with await anyio.open_file("bar.txt") as f:
        contents = await f.read()

docs.title: blocking-sleep-in-async-function (ASYNC251)
docs.text: Derived from the flake8-async linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks that async functions do not call time.sleep.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
Blocking an async function via a time.sleep call will block the entire event loop, preventing it from executing other tasks while waiting for the time.sleep, negating the benefits of asynchronous programming.

Instead of time.sleep, use asyncio.sleep.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
import time


async def fetch():
    time.sleep(1)

Use instead:

import asyncio


async def fetch():
    await asyncio.sleep(1)

docs.title: boolean-chained-comparison (PLR1716)
docs.text:
Derived from the Pylint linter.

Fix is always available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Check for chained boolean operations that can be simplified.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: Refactoring the code will improve readability for these cases.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
a = int(input())
b = int(input())
c = int(input())
if a < b and b < c:
    pass

Use instead:

a = int(input())
b = int(input())
c = int(input())
if a < b < c:
    pass

docs.title: boolean-default-value-positional-argument (FBT002)
docs.text: Derived from the flake8-boolean-trap linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for the use of boolean positional arguments in function definitions, as determined by the presence of a boolean default value.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
Calling a function with boolean positional arguments is confusing as the meaning of the boolean value is not clear to the caller and to future readers of the code.

The use of a boolean will also limit the function to only two possible behaviors, which makes the function difficult to extend in the future.

Instead, consider refactoring into separate implementations for the True and False cases, using an Enum, or making the argument a keyword-only argument, to force callers to be explicit when providing the argument.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
from math import ceil, floor


def round_number(number, up=True):
    return ceil(number) if up else floor(number)


round_number(1.5, True)  # What does `True` mean?
round_number(1.5, False)  # What does `False` mean?

Instead, refactor into separate implementations:

from math import ceil, floor


def round_up(number):
    return ceil(number)


def round_down(number):
    return floor(number)


round_up(1.5)
round_down(1.5)

Or, refactor to use an Enum:

from enum import Enum


class RoundingMethod(Enum):
    UP = 1
    DOWN = 2


def round_number(value, method):
    return ceil(number) if method is RoundingMethod.UP else floor(number)


round_number(1.5, RoundingMethod.UP)
round_number(1.5, RoundingMethod.DOWN)

Or, make the argument a keyword-only argument:

from math import ceil, floor

docs.title: boolean-type-hint-positional-argument (FBT001)
docs.text: Derived from the flake8-boolean-trap linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for the use of boolean positional arguments in function definitions, as determined by the presence of a type hint containing bool as an evident subtype - e.g. bool, bool | int, typing.Optional[bool], etc.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
Calling a function with boolean positional arguments is confusing as the meaning of the boolean value is not clear to the caller and to future readers of the code.

The use of a boolean will also limit the function to only two possible behaviors, which makes the function difficult to extend in the future.

Instead, consider refactoring into separate implementations for the True and False cases, using an Enum, or making the argument a keyword-only argument, to force callers to be explicit when providing the argument.

Dunder methods that define operators are exempt from this rule, as are setters and @override definitions.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
from math import ceil, floor


def round_number(number: float, up: bool) -> int:
    return ceil(number) if up else floor(number)


round_number(1.5, True)  # What does `True` mean?
round_number(1.5, False)  # What does `False` mean?

Instead, refactor into separate implementations:

from math import ceil, floor


def round_up(number: float) -> int:
    return ceil(number)


def round_down(number: float) -> int:
    return floor(number)


round_up(1.5)
round_down(1.5)

Or, refactor to use an Enum:

from enum import Enum


class RoundingMethod(Enum):
    UP = 1
    DOWN = 2


def round_number(value: float, method: RoundingMethod) -> float: ...

Or, make the argument a keyword-only argument:

from math import ceil, floor


def round_number(number: float, *, up: bool) -> int:
    return ceil(number) if up else floor(number)


round_number(1.5, up=True)
round_number(1.5, up=False)

docs.title: builtin-argument-shadowing (A002)
docs.text: Derived from the flake8-builtins linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for function arguments that use the same names as builtins.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
Reusing a builtin name for the name of an argument increases the difficulty of reading and maintaining the code, and can cause non-obvious errors, as readers may mistake the argument for the builtin and vice versa.

Builtins can be marked as exceptions to this rule via the lint.flake8-builtins.ignorelist configuration option.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:

    result = set()
    for value in list:
        result.add(value)
    for value in list2:
        result.add(value)
    return list(result)  # TypeError: 'list' object is not callable

Use instead:

def remove_duplicates(list1, list2):
    result = set()
    for value in list1:
        result.add(value)
    for value in list2:
        result.add(value)
    return list(result)

docs.title: builtin-attribute-shadowing (A003)
docs.text: Derived from the flake8-builtins linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for class attributes and methods that use the same names as Python builtins.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
Reusing a builtin name for the name of an attribute increases the difficulty of reading and maintaining the code, and can cause non-obvious errors, as readers may mistake the attribute for the builtin and vice versa.

Since methods and class attributes typically cannot be referenced directly from outside the class scope, this rule only applies to those methods and attributes that both shadow a builtin and are referenced from within the class scope, as in the following example, where the list[int] return type annotation resolves to the list method, rather than the builtin:

class Class:
    @staticmethod
    def list() -> None:
        pass

    @staticmethod
    def repeat(value: int, times: int) -> list[int]:
        return [value] * times

Builtins can be marked as exceptions to this rule via the lint.flake8-builtins.ignorelist configuration option, or converted to the appropriate dunder method. Methods decorated with @typing.override or @typing_extensions.override are also ignored.

    @staticmethod
    def list() -> None:
        pass

    @staticmethod
    def repeat(value: int, times: int) -> list[int]:

docs.title: cached-instance-method (B019)
docs.text: Derived from the flake8-bugbear linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for uses of the functools.lru_cache and functools.cache decorators on methods.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
Using the functools.lru_cache and functools.cache decorators on methods can lead to memory leaks, as the global cache will retain a reference to the instance, preventing it from being garbage collected.

Instead, refactor the method to depend only on its arguments and not on the instance of the class, or use the @lru_cache decorator on a function outside of the class.

This rule ignores instance methods on enumeration classes, as enum members are singletons.

docs.title: Example

from functools import lru_cache


def square(x: int) -> int:
    return x * x

    value: int

    @lru_cache
    def squared(self):
        return square(self.value)

Use instead:

from functools import lru_cache


@lru_cache
def square(x: int) -> int:
    return x * x


class Number:
    value: int

    def squared(self):
        return square(self.value)

docs.title: call-date-fromtimestamp (DTZ012)
docs.text: Derived from the flake8-datetimez linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for usage of datetime.date.fromtimestamp().

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
Python datetime objects can be naive or timezone-aware. While an aware object represents a specific moment in time, a naive object does not contain enough information to unambiguously locate itself relative to other datetime objects. Since this can lead to errors, it is recommended to always use timezone-aware objects.

datetime.date.fromtimestamp(ts) returns a naive datetime object. Instead, use datetime.datetime.fromtimestamp(ts, tz=...) to create a timezone-aware object.

Use instead:

import datetime

datetime.datetime.fromtimestamp(946684800, tz=datetime.timezone.utc)

Or, for Python 3.11 and later:

import datetime

datetime.datetime.fromtimestamp(946684800, tz=datetime.UTC)

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for CamelCase imports that are aliased as acronyms.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
PEP 8 recommends naming conventions for classes, functions, constants, and more. The use of inconsistent naming styles between import and alias names may lead readers to expect an import to be of another type (e.g., confuse a Python class with a constant).

Import aliases should thus follow the same naming style as the member being imported.

Note that this rule is distinct from camelcase-imported-as-constant to accommodate selective enforcement.

Also note that import aliases following an import convention according to the lint.flake8-import-conventions.aliases option are allowed.

Use instead:

from example import MyClassName

docs.title: camelcase-imported-as-constant (N814)
docs.text: Derived from the pep8-naming linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for CamelCase imports that are aliased to constant-style names.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
PEP 8 recommends naming conventions for classes, functions, constants, and more. The use of inconsistent naming styles between import and alias names may lead readers to expect an import to be of another type (e.g., confuse a Python class with a constant).

Import aliases should thus follow the same naming style as the member being imported.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
from example import MyClassName as MY_CLASS_NAME

Use instead:

from example import MyClassName

docs.title: Note
docs.text:
Identifiers consisting of a single uppercase character are ambiguous under the rules of PEP 8, which specifies CamelCase for classes and ALL_CAPS_SNAKE_CASE for constants. Without a second character, it is not possible to reliably guess whether the identifier is intended to be part of a CamelCase string for a class or an ALL_CAPS_SNAKE_CASE string for a constant, since both conventions will produce the same output when given a single input character. Therefore, this lint rule does not apply to cases where the alias for the imported identifier consists of a single uppercase character.

A common example of a single uppercase character being used for a class name can be found in Django's django.db.models.Q class.

docs.text: Checks for uses of set.remove that can be replaced with set.discard.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: If an element should be removed from a set if it is present, it is more succinct and idiomatic to use discard.

docs.title: Known problems
docs.text: This rule is prone to false negatives due to type inference limitations, as it will only detect sets that are instantiated as literals or annotated with a type annotation.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
nums = {123, 456}

if 123 in nums:
    nums.remove(123)

Use instead:

nums = {123, 456}

nums.discard(123)

docs.title: References
docs.text: • Python documentation: set.discard()

docs.title: class-as-data-structure (B903)
docs.text:
Derived from the flake8-bugbear linter.

This rule is unstable and in preview. The --preview flag is required for use.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for classes that only have a public __init__ method, without base classes and decorators.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: Classes with just an __init__ are possibly better off being a dataclass or a namedtuple, which have less boilerplate.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
class Point:
    def __init__(self, x: float, y: float):
        self.x = x
        self.y = y

Use instead:

from dataclasses import dataclass


@dataclass
class Point:
    x: float
    y: float

docs.title: class-with-mixed-type-vars (RUF053)
docs.text: Fix is sometimes available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for classes that have PEP 695 while also inheriting from typing.Generic or typing_extensions.Generic.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
Such classes cause errors at runtime:

from typing import Generic, TypeVar

U = TypeVar("U")

# TypeError: Cannot inherit from Generic[...] multiple times.
class C[T](Generic[U]): ...

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
from typing import Generic, ParamSpec, TypeVar, TypeVarTuple

U = TypeVar("U")
P = ParamSpec("P")
Ts = TypeVarTuple("Ts")


class C[T](Generic[U, P, *Ts]): ...

Use instead:

class C[T, U, **P, *Ts]: ...

docs.title: Fix safety
docs.text: As the fix changes runtime behaviour, it is always marked as unsafe. Additionally, comments within the fix range will not be preserved.

docs.title: References
docs.text:
• Python documentation: User-defined generic types
  • Python documentation: type parameter lists
  • PEP 695 - Type Parameter Syntax

docs.title: collapsible-else-if (PLR5501)
docs.text:
Derived from the Pylint linter.

Fix is sometimes available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for else blocks that consist of a single if statement.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: If an else block contains a single if statement, it can be collapsed into an elif, thus reducing the indentation level.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
def check_sign(value: int) -> None:
    if value > 0:
        print("Number is positive.")
    else:
        if value < 0:
            print("Number is negative.")
        else:
            print("Number is zero.")

Use instead:

def check_sign(value: int) -> None:
    if value > 0:
        print("Number is positive.")
    elif value < 0:
        print("Number is negative.")
    else:
        print("Number is zero.")

docs.title: References
docs.text: • Python documentation: if Statements

docs.title: collapsible-if (SIM102)
docs.text:
Derived from the flake8-simplify linter.

Fix is sometimes available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for nested if statements that can be collapsed into a single if statement.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: Nesting if statements leads to deeper indentation and makes code harder to read. Instead, combine the conditions into a single if statement with an and operator.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
if foo:
    if bar:
        ...

Use instead:

if foo and bar:
    ...

docs.title: References
docs.text:
• Python documentation: The if statement
  • Python documentation: Boolean operations

docs.title: collection-literal-concatenation (RUF005)
docs.text: Fix is sometimes available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for uses of the + operator to concatenate collections.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
In Python, the + operator can be used to concatenate collections (e.g., x + y to concatenate the lists x and y).

However, collections can be concatenated more efficiently using the unpacking operator (e.g., [*x, *y] to concatenate x and y).

Prefer the unpacking operator to concatenate collections, as it is more readable and flexible. The * operator can unpack any iterable, whereas + operates only on particular sequences which, in many cases, must be of the same type.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
foo = [2, 3, 4]
bar = [1] + foo + [5, 6]

Use instead:

foo = [2, 3, 4]
bar = [1, *foo, 5, 6]

docs.title: Fix safety
docs.text: The fix is always marked as unsafe because the + operator uses the __add__ magic method and *-unpacking uses the __iter__ magic method. Both of these could have custom implementations, causing the fix to change program behaviour.

docs.title: References
docs.text:
• PEP 448 – Additional Unpacking Generalizations
  • Python documentation: Sequence Types — list, tuple, range

docs.title: collections-named-tuple (PYI024)
docs.text: Derived from the flake8-pyi linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for uses of collections.namedtuple in stub files.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
typing.NamedTuple is the "typed version" of collections.namedtuple.

Inheriting from typing.NamedTuple creates a custom tuple subclass in the same way as using the collections.namedtuple factory function. However, using typing.NamedTuple allows you to provide a type annotation for each field in the class. This means that type checkers will have more information to work with, and will be able to analyze your code more precisely.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
from collections import namedtuple

Person = namedtuple("Person", ["name", "age"])

Use instead:

from typing import NamedTuple

class Person(NamedTuple):
    name: str
    age: int

docs.title: commented-out-code (ERA001)
docs.text: Derived from the eradicate linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for commented-out Python code.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: Commented-out code is dead code, and is often included inadvertently. It should be removed.

docs.title: Known problems
docs.text: Prone to false positives when checking comments that resemble Python code, but are not actually Python code (#4845).

docs.title: Example
docs.text: # print("Hello, world!")

docs.title: Options
docs.text: • lint.task-tags

docs.title: compare-to-empty-string (PLC1901)
docs.text:
Derived from the Pylint linter.

This rule is unstable and in preview. The --preview flag is required for use.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for comparisons to empty strings.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: An empty string is falsy, so it is unnecessary to compare it to "". If the value can be something else Python considers falsy, such as None, 0, or another empty container, then the code is not equivalent.

docs.title: Known problems
docs.text: High false positive rate, as the check is context-insensitive and does not consider the type of the variable being compared (#4282).

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
x: str = ...

if x == "":
    print("x is empty")

Use instead:

x: str = ...

if not x:
    print("x is empty")

docs.title: References
docs.text: • Python documentation: Truth Value Testing

docs.title: compare-with-tuple (SIM109)
docs.text:
Derived from the flake8-simplify linter.

Fix is always available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for boolean expressions that contain multiple equality comparisons to the same value.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: To check if an object is equal to any one of multiple values, it's more concise to use the in operator with a tuple of values.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
if foo == x or foo == y:
    ...

Use instead:

if foo in (x, y):
    ...

docs.title: References
docs.text: • Python documentation: Membership test operations

docs.title: comparison-of-constant (PLR0133)
docs.text: Derived from the Pylint linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for comparisons between constants.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: Comparing two constants will always resolve to the same value, so the comparison is redundant. Instead, the expression should be replaced with the result of the comparison.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
foo = 1 == 1

Use instead:

foo = True

docs.title: References
docs.text: • Python documentation: Comparisons

docs.title: comparison-with-itself (PLR0124)
docs.text: Derived from the Pylint linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for operations that compare a name to itself.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: Comparing a name to itself always results in the same value, and is likely a mistake.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
foo == foo

In some cases, self-comparisons are used to determine whether a float is NaN. Instead, prefer math.isnan:

import math

math.isnan(foo)

docs.title: References
docs.text: • Python documentation: Comparisons

docs.title: complex-assignment-in-stub (PYI017)
docs.text: Derived from the flake8-pyi linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for assignments with multiple or non-name targets in stub files.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
In general, stub files should be thought of as "data files" for a type checker, and are not intended to be executed. As such, it's useful to enforce that only a subset of Python syntax is allowed in a stub file, to ensure that everything in the stub is unambiguous for the type checker.

The need to perform multi-assignment, or assignment to a non-name target, likely indicates a misunderstanding of how stub files are intended to be used.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
from typing import TypeAlias

a = b = int

class Klass: ...

Klass.X: TypeAlias = int

Use instead:

from typing import TypeAlias

a: TypeAlias = int
b: TypeAlias = int

class Klass:
    X: TypeAlias = int

docs.title: complex-if-statement-in-stub (PYI002)
docs.text: Derived from the flake8-pyi linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for if statements with complex conditionals in stubs.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: Type checkers understand simple conditionals to express variations between different Python versions and platforms. However, complex tests may not be understood by a type checker, leading to incorrect inferences when they analyze your code.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
import sys

if (3, 10) <= sys.version_info < (3, 12): ...

Use instead:

import sys

if sys.version_info >= (3, 10) and sys.version_info < (3, 12): ...

docs.title: References
docs.text: • Typing documentation: Version and platform checking

docs.title: complex-structure (C901)
docs.text: Derived from the mccabe linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for functions with a high McCabe complexity.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
The McCabe complexity of a function is a measure of the complexity of the control flow graph of the function. It is calculated by adding one to the number of decision points in the function. A decision point is a place in the code where the program has a choice of two or more paths to follow.

Functions with a high complexity are hard to understand and maintain.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
def foo(a, b, c):
    if a:
        if b:
            if c:
                return 1
            else:
                return 2
        else:
            return 3
    else:
        return 4

Use instead:

def foo(a, b, c):
    if not a:
        return 4
    if not b:
        return 3
    if not c:
        return 2
    return 1

docs.title: Options
docs.text: • lint.mccabe.max-complexity

docs.title: constant-imported-as-non-constant (N811)
docs.text: Derived from the pep8-naming linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for constant imports that are aliased to non-constant-style names.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
PEP 8 recommends naming conventions for classes, functions, constants, and more. The use of inconsistent naming styles between import and alias names may lead readers to expect an import to be of another type (e.g., confuse a Python class with a constant).

Import aliases should thus follow the same naming style as the member being imported.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
from example import CONSTANT_VALUE as ConstantValue

Use instead:

from example import CONSTANT_VALUE

docs.title: Note
docs.text:
Identifiers consisting of a single uppercase character are ambiguous under the rules of PEP 8, which specifies CamelCase for classes and ALL_CAPS_SNAKE_CASE for constants. Without a second character, it is not possible to reliably guess whether the identifier is intended to be part of a CamelCase string for a class or an ALL_CAPS_SNAKE_CASE string for a constant, since both conventions will produce the same output when given a single input character. Therefore, this lint rule does not apply to cases where the imported identifier consists of a single uppercase character.

A common example of a single uppercase character being used for a class name can be found in Django's django.db.models.Q class.

docs.title: Options
docs.text:
• lint.pep8-naming.ignore-names
  • lint.pep8-naming.extend-ignore-names

docs.title: continue-in-finally (PLE0116)
docs.text: Derived from the Pylint linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for continue statements inside finally

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: continue statements were not allowed within finally clauses prior to Python 3.8. Using a continue statement within a finally clause can cause a SyntaxError.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
while True:
    try:
        pass
    finally:
        continue

Use instead:

while True:
    try:
        pass
    except Exception:
        pass
    else:
        continue

docs.title: Options
docs.text: • target-version

docs.title: continue-outside-loop (F702)
docs.text: Derived from the Pyflakes linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for continue statements outside of loops.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: The use of a continue statement outside of a for or while loop will raise a SyntaxError.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
def foo():
    continue  # SyntaxError

docs.title: References
docs.text: • Python documentation: continue

docs.title: convert-named-tuple-functional-to-class (UP014)
docs.text:
Derived from the pyupgrade linter.

Fix is sometimes available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for NamedTuple declarations that use functional syntax.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
NamedTuple subclasses can be defined either through a functional syntax (Foo = NamedTuple(...)) or a class syntax (class Foo(NamedTuple): ...).

The class syntax is more readable and generally preferred over the functional syntax, which exists primarily for backwards compatibility with collections.namedtuple.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
from typing import NamedTuple

Foo = NamedTuple("Foo", [("a", int), ("b", str)])

Use instead:

from typing import NamedTuple


class Foo(NamedTuple):
    a: int
    b: str

docs.title: Fix safety
docs.text: This rule's fix is marked as unsafe if there are any comments within the range of the NamedTuple definition, as these will be dropped by the autofix.

docs.title: References
docs.text: • Python documentation: typing.NamedTuple

docs.title: convert-typed-dict-functional-to-class (UP013)
docs.text:
Derived from the pyupgrade linter.

Fix is sometimes available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for TypedDict declarations that use functional syntax.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
TypedDict types can be defined either through a functional syntax (Foo = TypedDict(...)) or a class syntax (class Foo(TypedDict): ...).

The class syntax is more readable and generally preferred over the functional syntax.

Nonetheless, there are some situations in which it is impossible to use the class-based syntax. This rule will not apply to those cases. Namely, it is impossible to use the class-based syntax if any TypedDict fields are:

  • Not valid python identifiers (for example, @x)
  • Python keywords such as in
  • Private names such as __id that would undergo name mangling at runtime if the class-based syntax was used
  • Dunder names such as __int__ that can confuse type checkers if they're used with the class-based syntax.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
from typing import TypedDict

Foo = TypedDict("Foo", {"a": int, "b": str})

Use instead:

from typing import TypedDict


class Foo(TypedDict):
    a: int
    b: str

docs.title: Fix safety
docs.text: This rule's fix is marked as unsafe if there are any comments within the range of the TypedDict definition, as these will be dropped by the autofix.

docs.title: References
docs.text: • Python documentation: typing.TypedDict

docs.title: create-subprocess-in-async-function (ASYNC220)
docs.text: Derived from the flake8-async linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks that async functions do not create subprocesses with blocking methods.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
Blocking an async function via a blocking call will block the entire event loop, preventing it from executing other tasks while waiting for the call to complete, negating the benefits of asynchronous programming.

Instead of making a blocking call, use an equivalent asynchronous library or function, like trio.run_process() or anyio.run_process().

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
import os


async def foo():
    os.popen(cmd)

Use instead:

import asyncio


async def foo():
    asyncio.create_subprocess_shell(cmd)

docs.title: custom-type-var-for-self (PYI019)
docs.text:
Derived from the flake8-pyi linter.

Fix is sometimes available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for methods that use custom TypeVars in their annotations when they could use Self instead.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
While the semantics are often identical, using Self is more intuitive and succinct (per PEP 673) than a custom TypeVar. For example, the use of Self will typically allow for the omission of type parameters on the self and cls arguments.

This check currently applies to instance methods that return self, class methods that return an instance of cls, class methods that return cls, and __new__ methods.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
from typing import TypeVar

_S = TypeVar("_S", bound="Foo")

class Foo:
    def __new__(cls: type[_S], *args: str, **kwargs: int) -> _S: ...
    def foo(self: _S, arg: bytes) -> _S: ...
    @classmethod
    def bar(cls: type[_S], arg: int) -> _S: ...

Use instead:

from typing import Self

class Foo:
    def __new__(cls, *args: str, **kwargs: int) -> Self: ...
    def foo(self, arg: bytes) -> Self: ...
    @classmethod
    def bar(cls, arg: int) -> Self: ...

docs.title: Fix behaviour
docs.text:
The fix replaces all references to the custom type variable in the method's header and body with references to Self. The fix also adds an import of Self if neither Self nor typing is already imported in the module. If your target-version setting is set to Python 3.11 or newer, the fix imports Self from the standard-library typing module; otherwise, the fix imports Self from the third-party typing_extensions backport package.

If the custom type variable is a PEP-695-style TypeVar, the fix also removes the TypeVar declaration from the method's type parameter list. However, if the type variable is an old-style TypeVar, the declaration of the type variable will not be removed by this rule's fix, as the type variable could still be used by other functions, methods or classes. See unused-private-type-var for a rule that will clean up unused private type variables.

docs.title: Fix safety
docs.text: The fix is only marked as unsafe if there is the possibility that it might delete a comment from your code.

docs.title: Availability
docs.text: Because this rule relies on the third-party typing_extensions module for Python versions before 3.11, its diagnostic will not be emitted, and no fix will be offered, if typing_extensions imports have been disabled by the lint.typing-extensions linter option.

docs.title: Options
docs.text: • lint.typing-extensions

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for enum classes which are also decorated with @dataclass.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
Decorating an enum with @dataclass() does not cause any errors at runtime, but may cause erroneous results:

@dataclass
class E(Enum):
    A = 1
    B = 2

print(E.A == E.B)  # True

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
from dataclasses import dataclass
from enum import Enum


@dataclass
class E(Enum): ...

Use instead:

from enum import Enum


class E(Enum): ...

docs.title: References
docs.text: • Python documentation: Enum HOWTO § Dataclass support

docs.title: datetime-min-max (DTZ901)
docs.text: Derived from the flake8-datetimez linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for uses of datetime.datetime.min and datetime.datetime.max.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
datetime.min and datetime.max are non-timezone-aware datetime objects.

As such, operations on datetime.min and datetime.max may behave unexpectedly, as in:

import datetime

# Timezone: UTC-14
datetime.datetime.min.timestamp()  # ValueError: year 0 is out of range
datetime.datetime.max.timestamp()  # ValueError: year 10000 is out of range

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
import datetime

datetime.datetime.max

Use instead:

import datetime

datetime.datetime.max.replace(tzinfo=datetime.UTC)

docs.title: datetime-timezone-utc (UP017)
docs.text:
Derived from the pyupgrade linter.

Fix is sometimes available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for uses of datetime.timezone.utc.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: As of Python 3.11, datetime.UTC is an alias for datetime.timezone.utc. The alias is more readable and generally preferred over the full path.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
import datetime

datetime.timezone.utc

Use instead:

import datetime

datetime.UTC

docs.title: Options
docs.text: • target-version

docs.title: References
docs.text: • Python documentation: datetime.UTC

docs.title: debugger (T100)
docs.text: Derived from the flake8-debugger linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for the presence of debugger calls and imports.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
Debugger calls and imports should be used for debugging purposes only. The presence of a debugger call or import in production code is likely a mistake and may cause unintended behavior, such as exposing sensitive information or causing the program to hang.

Instead, consider using a logging library to log information about the program's state, and writing tests to verify that the program behaves as expected.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
def foo():
    breakpoint()

docs.title: References
docs.text:
• Python documentation: pdb — The Python Debugger
  • Python documentation: logging — Logging facility for Python

docs.title: decimal-from-float-literal (RUF032)
docs.text: Fix is always available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for Decimal calls passing a float literal.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: Float literals have limited precision that can lead to unexpected results. The Decimal class is designed to handle numbers with fixed-point precision, so a string literal should be used instead.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
num = Decimal(1.2345)

Use instead:

num = Decimal("1.2345")

docs.title: Fix safety
docs.text: This rule's fix is marked as unsafe because it changes the underlying value of the Decimal instance that is constructed. This can lead to unexpected behavior if your program relies on the previous value (whether deliberately or not).

docs.title: default-except-not-last (F707)
docs.text: Derived from the Pyflakes linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for except blocks that handle all exceptions, but are not the last except block in a try statement.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: When an exception is raised within a try block, the except blocks are evaluated in order, and the first matching block is executed. If an except block handles all exceptions, but isn't the last block, Python will raise a SyntaxError, as the following blocks would never be executed.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
def reciprocal(n):
    try:
        reciprocal = 1 / n
    except:
        print("An exception occurred.")
    except ZeroDivisionError:
        print("Cannot divide by zero.")
    else:
        return reciprocal

Use instead:

def reciprocal(n):
    try:
        reciprocal = 1 / n
    except ZeroDivisionError:
        print("Cannot divide by zero.")
    except:
        print("An exception occurred.")
    else:
        return reciprocal

docs.title: References
docs.text: • Python documentation: except clause

docs.title: default-factory-kwarg (RUF026)
docs.text: Fix is sometimes available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for incorrect usages of default_factory as a keyword argument when initializing a defaultdict.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
The defaultdict constructor accepts a callable as its first argument. For example, it's common to initialize a defaultdict with int or list via defaultdict(int) or defaultdict(list), to create a dictionary that returns 0 or [] respectively when a key is missing.

The default factory must be provided as a positional argument, as all keyword arguments to defaultdict are interpreted as initial entries in the dictionary. For example, defaultdict(foo=1, bar=2) will create a dictionary with {"foo": 1, "bar": 2} as its initial entries.

As such, defaultdict(default_factory=list) will create a dictionary with {"default_factory": list} as its initial entry, instead of a dictionary that returns [] when a key is missing. Specifying a default_factory keyword argument is almost always a mistake, and one that type checkers can't reliably detect.

docs.title: Fix safety
docs.text: This rule's fix is marked as unsafe, as converting default_factory from a keyword to a positional argument will change the behavior of the code, even if the keyword argument was used erroneously.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
defaultdict(default_factory=int)
defaultdict(default_factory=list)

Use instead:

defaultdict(int)
defaultdict(list)

docs.title: delete-full-slice (FURB131)
docs.text:
Derived from the refurb linter.

Fix is sometimes available.

This rule is unstable and in preview. The --preview flag is required for use.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for del statements that delete the entire slice of a list or dictionary.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: It is faster and more succinct to remove all items via the clear() method.

docs.title: Known problems
docs.text: This rule is prone to false negatives due to type inference limitations, as it will only detect lists and dictionaries that are instantiated as literals or annotated with a type annotation.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
names = {"key": "value"}
nums = [1, 2, 3]

del names[:]
del nums[:]

Use instead:

names = {"key": "value"}
nums = [1, 2, 3]

names.clear()
nums.clear()

docs.title: References
docs.text:
• Python documentation: Mutable Sequence Types
  • Python documentation: dict.clear()

docs.title: deprecated-c-element-tree (UP023)
docs.text:
Derived from the pyupgrade linter.

Fix is always available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for uses of the xml.etree.cElementTree module.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: In Python 3.3, xml.etree.cElementTree was deprecated in favor of xml.etree.ElementTree.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
from xml.etree import cElementTree as ET

Use instead:

from xml.etree import ElementTree as ET

docs.title: deprecated-import (UP035)
docs.text:
Derived from the pyupgrade linter.

Fix is sometimes available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for uses of deprecated imports based on the minimum supported Python version.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
Deprecated imports may be removed in future versions of Python, and should be replaced with their new equivalents.

Note that, in some cases, it may be preferable to continue importing members from typing_extensions even after they're added to the Python standard library, as typing_extensions can backport bugfixes and optimizations from later Python versions. This rule thus avoids flagging imports from typing_extensions in such cases.

docs.title: Example

from collections import Sequence

Use instead:

from collections.abc import Sequence

docs.title: What it does

import logging


def foo():

import logging


def foo():

docs.title: dict-get-with-none-default (SIM910)
docs.text:
Derived from the flake8-simplify linter.

Fix is always available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for dict.get() calls that pass None as the default value.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: None is the default value for dict.get(), so it is redundant to pass it explicitly.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
ages = {"Tom": 23, "Maria": 23, "Dog": 11}
age = ages.get("Cat", None)

Use instead:

ages = {"Tom": 23, "Maria": 23, "Dog": 11}
age = ages.get("Cat")

docs.title: dict-index-missing-items (PLC0206)
docs.text: Derived from the Pylint linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for dictionary iterations that extract the dictionary value via explicit indexing, instead of using .items().

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: Iterating over a dictionary with .items() is semantically clearer and more efficient than extracting the value with the key.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
ORCHESTRA = {
    "violin": "strings",
    "oboe": "woodwind",
    "tuba": "brass",
    "gong": "percussion",
}

for instrument in ORCHESTRA:
    print(f"{instrument}: {ORCHESTRA[instrument]}")

Use instead:

ORCHESTRA = {
    "violin": "strings",
    "oboe": "woodwind",
    "tuba": "brass",
    "gong": "percussion",
}

for instrument, section in ORCHESTRA.items():
    print(f"{instrument}: {section}")

docs.title: dict-iter-missing-items (PLE1141)
docs.text:
Derived from the Pylint linter.

Fix is always available.

This rule is unstable and in preview. The --preview flag is required for use.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for dictionary unpacking in a for loop without calling .items().

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
When iterating over a dictionary in a for loop, if a dictionary is unpacked without calling .items(), it could lead to a runtime error if the keys are not a tuple of two elements.

It is likely that you're looking for an iteration over (key, value) pairs which can only be achieved when calling .items().

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
data = {"Paris": 2_165_423, "New York City": 8_804_190, "Tokyo": 13_988_129}

for city, population in data:
    print(f"{city} has population {population}.")

Use instead:

data = {"Paris": 2_165_423, "New York City": 8_804_190, "Tokyo": 13_988_129}

for city, population in data.items():
    print(f"{city} has population {population}.")

docs.title: Known problems
docs.text:
If the dictionary key is a tuple, e.g.:

d = {(1, 2): 3, (3, 4): 5}
for x, y in d:
    print(x, y)

The tuple key is unpacked into x and y instead of the key and values. This means that the suggested fix of using d.items() would result in different runtime behavior. Ruff cannot consistently infer the type of a dictionary's keys.

docs.title: Fix safety
docs.text: Due to the known problem with tuple keys, this fix is unsafe.

docs.title: direct-logger-instantiation (LOG001)
docs.text:
Derived from the flake8-logging linter.

Fix is sometimes available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for direct instantiation of logging.Logger, as opposed to using logging.getLogger().

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
The Logger Objects documentation states that:

Note that Loggers should NEVER be instantiated directly, but always through the module-level function logging.getLogger(name).

If a logger is directly instantiated, it won't be added to the logger tree, and will bypass all configuration. Messages logged to it will only be sent to the "handler of last resort", skipping any filtering or formatting.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
import logging

logger = logging.Logger(__name__)

Use instead:

import logging

logger = logging.getLogger(__name__)

docs.title: Fix safety
docs.text: This fix is always unsafe, as changing from Logger to getLogger changes program behavior by will adding the logger to the logging tree.

docs.title: django-all-with-model-form (DJ007)
docs.text: Derived from the flake8-django linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for the use of fields = "__all__" in Django ModelForm classes.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: If a ModelForm includes the fields = "__all__" attribute, any new field that is added to the model will automatically be exposed for modification.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
from django.forms import ModelForm


class PostForm(ModelForm):
    class Meta:
        model = Post
        fields = "__all__"

Use instead:

from django.forms import ModelForm


class PostForm(ModelForm):
    class Meta:
        model = Post
        fields = ["title", "content"]

docs.title: django-exclude-with-model-form (DJ006)
docs.text: Derived from the flake8-django linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for the use of exclude in Django ModelForm classes.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: If a ModelForm includes the exclude attribute, any new field that is added to the model will automatically be exposed for modification.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
from django.forms import ModelForm


class PostForm(ModelForm):
    class Meta:
        model = Post
        exclude = ["author"]

Use instead:

from django.forms import ModelForm


class PostForm(ModelForm):
    class Meta:
        model = Post
        fields = ["title", "content"]

docs.title: django-extra (S610)
docs.text: Derived from the flake8-bandit linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for uses of Django's extra function where one or more arguments passed are not literal expressions.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: Django's extra function can be used to execute arbitrary SQL queries, which can in turn lead to SQL injection vulnerabilities.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
from django.contrib.auth.models import User

# String interpolation creates a security loophole that could be used
# for SQL injection:
User.objects.all().extra(select={"test": "%secure" % "nos"})

Use instead:

from django.contrib.auth.models import User

# SQL injection is impossible if all arguments are literal expressions:
User.objects.all().extra(select={"test": "secure"})

docs.title: References
docs.text:
• Django documentation: SQL injection protection
  • Common Weakness Enumeration: CWE-89

docs.title: django-locals-in-render-function (DJ003)
docs.text: Derived from the flake8-django linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for the use of locals() in render functions.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: Using locals() can expose internal variables or other unintentional data to the rendered template.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
from django.shortcuts import render


def index(request):
    posts = Post.objects.all()
    return render(request, "app/index.html", locals())

Use instead:

from django.shortcuts import render


def index(request):
    posts = Post.objects.all()
    context = {"posts": posts}
    return render(request, "app/index.html", context)

docs.title: django-model-without-dunder-str (DJ008)
docs.text: Derived from the flake8-django linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks that a __str__ method is defined in Django models.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
Django models should define a __str__ method to return a string representation of the model instance, as Django calls this method to display the object in the Django Admin and elsewhere.

Models without a __str__ method will display a non-meaningful representation of the object in the Django Admin.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
from django.db import models


class MyModel(models.Model):
    field = models.CharField(max_length=255)

Use instead:

from django.db import models


class MyModel(models.Model):
    field = models.CharField(max_length=255)

    def __str__(self):
        return f"{self.field}"

docs.title: django-non-leading-receiver-decorator (DJ013)
docs.text: Derived from the flake8-django linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks that Django's @receiver decorator is listed first, prior to any other decorators.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: Django's @receiver decorator is special in that it does not return a wrapped function. Rather, @receiver connects the decorated function to a signal. If any other decorators are listed before @receiver, the decorated function will not be connected to the signal.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
from django.dispatch import receiver
from django.db.models.signals import post_save


@transaction.atomic
@receiver(post_save, sender=MyModel)
def my_handler(sender, instance, created, **kwargs):
    pass

Use instead:

from django.dispatch import receiver
from django.db.models.signals import post_save


@receiver(post_save, sender=MyModel)
@transaction.atomic
def my_handler(sender, instance, created, **kwargs):
    pass

docs.title: django-nullable-model-string-field (DJ001)
docs.text: Derived from the flake8-django linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks nullable string-based fields (like CharField and TextField) in Django models.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
If a string-based field is nullable, then your model will have two possible representations for "no data": None and the empty string. This can lead to confusion, as clients of the API have to check for both None and the empty string when trying to determine if the field has data.

The Django convention is to use the empty string in lieu of None for string-based fields.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
from django.db import models


class MyModel(models.Model):
    field = models.CharField(max_length=255, null=True)

Use instead:

from django.db import models


class MyModel(models.Model):
    field = models.CharField(max_length=255, default="")

docs.title: django-raw-sql (S611)
docs.text: Derived from the flake8-bandit linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for uses of Django's RawSQL function.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: Django's RawSQL function can be used to execute arbitrary SQL queries, which can in turn lead to SQL injection vulnerabilities.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
from django.db.models.expressions import RawSQL
from django.contrib.auth.models import User

User.objects.annotate(val=RawSQL("%s" % input_param, []))

docs.title: References
docs.text:
• Django documentation: SQL injection protection
  • Common Weakness Enumeration: CWE-89

docs.title: django-unordered-body-content-in-model (DJ012)
docs.text: Derived from the flake8-django linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for the order of Model's inner classes, methods, and fields as per the Django Style Guide.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
The Django Style Guide specifies that the order of Model inner classes, attributes and methods should be as follows:

  1. All database fields
  2. Custom manager attributes
  3. class Meta
  4. def __str__()
  5. def save()
  6. def get_absolute_url()
  7. Any custom methods

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
from django.db import models


class StrBeforeFieldModel(models.Model):
    class Meta:
        verbose_name = "test"
        verbose_name_plural = "tests"

    def __str__(self):
        return "foobar"

    first_name = models.CharField(max_length=32)
    last_name = models.CharField(max_length=40)

Use instead:

from django.db import models


class StrBeforeFieldModel(models.Model):
    first_name = models.CharField(max_length=32)
    last_name = models.CharField(max_length=40)

    class Meta:
        verbose_name = "test"
        verbose_name_plural = "tests"

    def __str__(self):
        return "foobar"

docs.title: doc-line-too-long (W505)
docs.text: Derived from the pycodestyle linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for doc lines that exceed the specified maximum character length.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
For flowing long blocks of text (docstrings or comments), overlong lines can hurt readability. PEP 8, for example, recommends that such lines be limited to 72 characters, while this rule enforces the limit specified by the lint.pycodestyle.max-doc-length setting. (If no value is provided, this rule will be ignored, even if it's added to your --select list.)

In the context of this rule, a "doc line" is defined as a line consisting of either a standalone comment or a standalone string, like a docstring.

In the interest of pragmatism, this rule makes a few exceptions when determining whether a line is overlong. Namely, it:

  1. Ignores lines that consist of a single "word" (i.e., without any whitespace between its characters).
  2. Ignores lines that end with a URL, as long as the URL starts before the line-length threshold.
  3. Ignores line that end with a pragma comment (e.g., # type: ignore or # noqa), as long as the pragma comment starts before the line-length threshold. That is, a line will not be flagged as overlong if a pragma comment causes it to exceed the line length. (This behavior aligns with that of the Ruff formatter.)

If lint.pycodestyle.ignore-overlong-task-comments is true, this rule will also ignore comments that start with any of the specified lint.task-tags (e.g., # TODO:).

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
def function(x):
    """Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit. Duis auctor purus ut ex fermentum, at maximus est hendrerit."""

Use instead:

def function(x):
    """
    Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit.
    Duis auctor purus ut ex fermentum, at maximus est hendrerit.
    """

docs.title: Error suppression
docs.text:
Hint: when suppressing W505 errors within multi-line strings (like docstrings), the noqa directive should come at the end of the string (after the closing triple quote), and will apply to the entire string, like so:

"""Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet.

Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit, sed do eiusmod tempor.
"""  # noqa: W505

docs.title: Options
docs.text:
• lint.task-tags
  • lint.pycodestyle.max-doc-length
  • lint.pycodestyle.ignore-overlong-task-comments

docs.title: docstring-extraneous-exception (DOC502)
docs.text:
Derived from the pydoclint linter.

This rule is unstable and in preview. The --preview flag is required for use.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for function docstrings that state that exceptions could be raised even though they are not directly raised in the function body.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
Some conventions prefer non-explicit exceptions be omitted from the docstring.

This rule is not enforced for abstract methods. It is also ignored for "stub functions": functions where the body only consists of pass, ..., raise NotImplementedError, or similar.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
def calculate_speed(distance: float, time: float) -> float:
    """Calculate speed as distance divided by time.

    Args:
        distance: Distance traveled.
        time: Time spent traveling.

    Returns:
        Speed as distance divided by time.

    Raises:
        ZeroDivisionError: Divided by zero.
    """
    return distance / time

Use instead:

def calculate_speed(distance: float, time: float) -> float:
    """Calculate speed as distance divided by time.

    Args:
        distance: Distance traveled.
        time: Time spent traveling.

    Returns:
        Speed as distance divided by time.
    """
    return distance / time

docs.title: Known issues
docs.text: It may often be desirable to document all exceptions that a function could possibly raise, even those which are not explicitly raised using raise statements in the function body.

docs.title: docstring-extraneous-returns (DOC202)
docs.text:
Derived from the pydoclint linter.

This rule is unstable and in preview. The --preview flag is required for use.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for function docstrings with unnecessary "Returns" sections.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
A function without an explicit return statement should not have a "Returns" section in its docstring.

This rule is not enforced for abstract methods. It is also ignored for "stub functions": functions where the body only consists of pass, ..., raise NotImplementedError, or similar.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
def say_hello(n: int) -> None:
    """Says hello to the user.

    Args:
        n: Number of times to say hello.

    Returns:
        Doesn't return anything.
    """
    for _ in range(n):
        print("Hello!")

Use instead:

def say_hello(n: int) -> None:
    """Says hello to the user.

    Args:
        n: Number of times to say hello.
    """
    for _ in range(n):
        print("Hello!")

docs.title: docstring-extraneous-yields (DOC403)
docs.text:
Derived from the pydoclint linter.

This rule is unstable and in preview. The --preview flag is required for use.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for function docstrings with unnecessary "Yields" sections.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
A function that doesn't yield anything should not have a "Yields" section in its docstring.

This rule is not enforced for abstract methods. It is also ignored for "stub functions": functions where the body only consists of pass, ..., raise NotImplementedError, or similar.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
def say_hello(n: int) -> None:
    """Says hello to the user.

    Args:
        n: Number of times to say hello.

    Yields:
        Doesn't yield anything.
    """
    for _ in range(n):
        print("Hello!")

Use instead:

def say_hello(n: int) -> None:
    """Says hello to the user.

    Args:
        n: Number of times to say hello.
    """
    for _ in range(n):
        print("Hello!")

docs.title: docstring-in-stub (PYI021)
docs.text:
Derived from the flake8-pyi linter.

Fix is always available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for the presence of docstrings in stub files.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: Stub files should omit docstrings, as they're intended to provide type hints, rather than documentation.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
def func(param: int) -> str:
    """This is a docstring."""
    ...

Use instead:

def func(param: int) -> str: ...

docs.title: docstring-missing-exception (DOC501)
docs.text:
Derived from the pydoclint linter.

This rule is unstable and in preview. The --preview flag is required for use.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for function docstrings that do not document all explicitly raised exceptions.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
A function should document all exceptions that are directly raised in some circumstances. Failing to document an exception that could be raised can be misleading to users and/or a sign of incomplete documentation.

This rule is not enforced for abstract methods. It is also ignored for "stub functions": functions where the body only consists of pass, ..., raise NotImplementedError, or similar.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
class FasterThanLightError(ArithmeticError): ...


def calculate_speed(distance: float, time: float) -> float:
    """Calculate speed as distance divided by time.

    Args:
        distance: Distance traveled.
        time: Time spent traveling.

    Returns:
        Speed as distance divided by time.
    """
    try:
        return distance / time
    except ZeroDivisionError as exc:
        raise FasterThanLightError from exc

Use instead:

class FasterThanLightError(ArithmeticError): ...


def calculate_speed(distance: float, time: float) -> float:
    """Calculate speed as distance divided by time.

    Args:
        distance: Distance traveled.
        time: Time spent traveling.

    Returns:
        Speed as distance divided by time.

    Raises:
        FasterThanLightError: If speed is greater than the speed of light.
    """
    try:
        return distance / time
    except ZeroDivisionError as exc:
        raise FasterThanLightError from exc

docs.title: docstring-missing-returns (DOC201)
docs.text:
Derived from the pydoclint linter.

This rule is unstable and in preview. The --preview flag is required for use.

docs.text: Checks for functions with return statements that do not have "Returns" sections in their docstrings.

A missing "Returns" section is a sign of incomplete documentation.

This rule is not enforced for abstract methods or functions that only return None. It is also ignored for "stub functions": functions where the body only consists of pass, ..., raise NotImplementedError, or similar.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
def calculate_speed(distance: float, time: float) -> float:
    """Calculate speed as distance divided by time.

    Args:
        distance: Distance traveled.
        time: Time spent traveling.
    """
    return distance / time

Use instead:

def calculate_speed(distance: float, time: float) -> float:
    """Calculate speed as distance divided by time.

    Args:
        distance: Distance traveled.
        time: Time spent traveling.

    Returns:
        Speed as distance divided by time.
    """
    return distance / time

docs.title: docstring-missing-yields (DOC402)
docs.text:
Derived from the pydoclint linter.

This rule is unstable and in preview. The --preview flag is required for use.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for functions with yield statements that do not have "Yields" sections in their docstrings.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
A missing "Yields" section is a sign of incomplete documentation.

This rule is not enforced for abstract methods or functions that only yield None. It is also ignored for "stub functions": functions where the body only consists of pass, ..., raise NotImplementedError, or similar.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
def count_to_n(n: int) -> int:
    """Generate integers up to *n*.

    Args:
        n: The number at which to stop counting.
    """
    for i in range(1, n + 1):
        yield i

Use instead:

def count_to_n(n: int) -> int:
    """Generate integers up to *n*.

    Args:
        n: The number at which to stop counting.

    Yields:
        int: The number we're at in the count.
    """
    for i in range(1, n + 1):
        yield i

docs.title: docstring-starts-with-this (D404)
docs.text: Derived from the pydocstyle linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for docstrings that start with This.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
PEP 257 recommends that the first line of a docstring be written in the imperative mood, for consistency.

Hint: to rewrite the docstring in the imperative, phrase the first line as if it were a command.

This rule may not apply to all projects; its applicability is a matter of convention. By default, this rule is enabled when using the numpy convention,, and disabled when using the google and pep257 conventions.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
def average(values: list[float]) -> float:
    """This function returns the mean of the given values."""

Use instead:

def average(values: list[float]) -> float:
    """Return the mean of the given values."""

docs.title: Options
docs.text: • lint.pydocstyle.convention

docs.title: References
docs.text: • PEP 257 – Docstring Conventions

docs.title: docstring-tab-indentation (D206)
docs.text: Derived from the pydocstyle linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for docstrings that are indented with tabs.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: PEP 8 recommends using spaces over tabs for indentation.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
def sort_list(l: list[int]) -> list[int]:
    """Return a sorted copy of the list.

    Sort the list in ascending order and return a copy of the result using the bubble
    sort algorithm.
    """

Use instead:

def sort_list(l: list[int]) -> list[int]:
    """Return a sorted copy of the list.

    Sort the list in ascending order and return a copy of the result using the bubble
    sort algorithm.
    """

docs.title: Formatter compatibility
docs.text:
We recommend against using this rule alongside the formatter. The formatter enforces consistent indentation, making the rule redundant.

The rule is also incompatible with the formatter when using format.indent-style="tab".

docs.text:
• PEP 257 – Docstring Conventions
  • NumPy Style Guide
  • Google Python Style Guide - Docstrings

docs.title: dot-format-in-exception (EM103)
docs.text:
Derived from the flake8-errmsg linter.

Fix is sometimes available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for the use of .format calls on string literals in exception constructors.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
Python includes the raise in the default traceback (and formatters like Rich and IPython do too).

By using a .format call, the error message will be duplicated in the traceback, which can make the traceback less readable.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
Given:

sub = "Some value"
raise RuntimeError("'{}' is incorrect".format(sub))

Python will produce a traceback like:

Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "tmp.py", line 2, in <module>
    raise RuntimeError("'{}' is incorrect".format(sub))
RuntimeError: 'Some value' is incorrect

Instead, assign the string to a variable:

sub = "Some value"
msg = "'{}' is incorrect".format(sub)
raise RuntimeError(msg)

Which will produce a traceback like:

Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "tmp.py", line 3, in <module>
    raise RuntimeError(msg)
RuntimeError: 'Some value' is incorrect

docs.title: double-negation (SIM208)
docs.text:
Derived from the flake8-simplify linter.

Fix is always available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for double negations (i.e., multiple not operators).

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: A double negation is redundant and less readable than omitting the not operators entirely.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
not (not a)

Use instead:

a

docs.text: • Python documentation: Comparisons

docs.title: dunder-function-name (N807)
docs.text: Derived from the pep8-naming linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for functions with "dunder" names (that is, names with two leading and trailing underscores) that are not documented.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
PEP 8 recommends that only documented "dunder" methods are used:

..."magic" objects or attributes that live in user-controlled namespaces. E.g. __init__, __import__ or __file__. Never invent such names; only use them as documented.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
def __my_function__():
    pass

Use instead:

def my_function():
    pass
