docs.title: duplicate-bases (PLE0241)
docs.text:
Derived from the Pylint linter.

Fix is sometimes available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for duplicate base classes in class definitions.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: Including duplicate base classes will raise a TypeError at runtime.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
class Foo:
    pass


class Bar(Foo, Foo):
    pass

Use instead:

class Foo:
    pass


class Bar(Foo):
    pass

docs.title: Fix safety
docs.text:
This rule's fix is marked as unsafe if there's comments in the base classes, as comments may be removed.

For example, the fix would be marked as unsafe in the following case:

class Foo:
    pass


class Bar(
    Foo,  # comment
    Foo,
):
    pass

docs.title: References
docs.text: • Python documentation: Class definitions

docs.title: duplicate-class-field-definition (PIE794)
docs.text:
Derived from the flake8-pie linter.

Fix is always available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for duplicate field definitions in classes.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: Defining a field multiple times in a class body is redundant and likely a mistake.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
class Person:
    name = Tom
    ...
    name = Ben

Use instead:

class Person:
    name = Tom
    ...

docs.title: Fix safety
docs.text: This fix is always marked as unsafe since we cannot know for certain which assignment was intended.

docs.title: duplicate-handler-exception (B014)
docs.text:
Derived from the flake8-bugbear linter.

Fix is always available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for exception handlers that catch duplicate exceptions.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: Including the same exception multiple times in the same handler is redundant, as the first exception will catch the exception, making the second exception unreachable. The same applies to exception hierarchies, as a handler for a parent exception (like Exception) will also catch child exceptions (like ValueError).

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
try:
    ...
except (Exception, ValueError):  # `Exception` includes `ValueError`.
    ...

Use instead:

try:
    ...
except Exception:
    ...

docs.title: References
docs.text:
• Python documentation: except clause
  • Python documentation: Exception hierarchy

docs.title: duplicate-isinstance-call (SIM101)
docs.text:
Derived from the flake8-simplify linter.

Fix is sometimes available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for multiple isinstance calls on the same target.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
To check if an object is an instance of any one of multiple types or classes, it is unnecessary to use multiple isinstance calls, as the second argument of the isinstance built-in function accepts a tuple of types and classes.

Using a single isinstance call implements the same behavior with more concise code and clearer intent.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
if isinstance(obj, int) or isinstance(obj, float):
    pass

Use instead:

if isinstance(obj, (int, float)):
    pass

docs.title: References
docs.text: • Python documentation: isinstance

docs.title: duplicate-literal-member (PYI062)
docs.text:
Derived from the flake8-pyi linter.

Fix is always available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for duplicate members in a typing.Literal[] slice.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: Duplicate literal members are redundant and should be removed.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
from typing import Literal

foo: Literal["a", "b", "a"]

Use instead:

from typing import Literal

foo: Literal["a", "b"]

docs.title: Fix safety
docs.text:
This rule's fix is marked as safe, unless the type annotation contains comments.

Note that while the fix may flatten nested literals into a single top-level literal, the semantics of the annotation will remain unchanged.

docs.title: duplicate-try-block-exception (B025)
docs.text: Derived from the flake8-bugbear linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for try-except blocks with duplicate exception handlers.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: Duplicate exception handlers are redundant, as the first handler will catch the exception, making the second handler unreachable.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
try:
    ...
except ValueError:
    ...
except ValueError:
    ...

Use instead:

try:
    ...
except ValueError:
    ...

docs.title: duplicate-union-member (PYI016)
docs.text:
Derived from the flake8-pyi linter.

Fix is sometimes available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for duplicate union members.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: Duplicate union members are redundant and should be removed.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
foo: str | str

Use instead:

foo: str

docs.title: Fix safety
docs.text:
This rule's fix is marked as safe unless the union contains comments.

For nested union, the fix will flatten type expressions into a single top-level union.

docs.title: duplicate-value (B033)
docs.text:
Derived from the flake8-bugbear linter.

Fix is sometimes available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for set literals that contain duplicate items.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: In Python, sets are unordered collections of unique elements. Including a duplicate item in a set literal is redundant, as the duplicate item will be replaced with a single item at runtime.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
{1, 2, 3, 1}

Use instead:

{1, 2, 3}

docs.title: ellipsis-in-non-empty-class-body (PYI013)
docs.text:
Derived from the flake8-pyi linter.

Fix is sometimes available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Removes ellipses (...) in otherwise non-empty class bodies.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: An ellipsis in a class body is only necessary if the class body is otherwise empty. If the class body is non-empty, then the ellipsis is redundant.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
class Foo:
    ...
    value: int

Use instead:

class Foo:
    value: int

docs.title: empty-comment (PLR2044)
docs.text:
Derived from the Pylint linter.

Fix is always available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for a # symbol appearing on a line not followed by an actual comment.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: Empty comments don't provide any clarity to the code, and just add clutter. Either add a comment or delete the empty comment.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
class Foo:  #
    pass

Use instead:

class Foo:
    pass

docs.title: References
docs.text: • Pylint documentation

docs.title: empty-docstring-section (D414)
docs.text: Derived from the pydocstyle linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for docstrings with empty sections.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
An empty section in a multiline docstring likely indicates an unfinished or incomplete docstring.

Multiline docstrings are typically composed of a summary line, followed by a blank line, followed by a series of sections, each with a section header and a section body. Each section body should be non-empty; empty sections should either have content added to them, or be removed entirely.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
def calculate_speed(distance: float, time: float) -> float:
    """Calculate speed as distance divided by time.

    Parameters
    ----------
    distance : float
        Distance traveled.
    time : float
        Time spent traveling.

    Returns
    -------
    float
        Speed as distance divided by time.

    Raises
    ------
    """
    try:
        return distance / time
    except ZeroDivisionError as exc:
        raise FasterThanLightError from exc

Use instead:

def calculate_speed(distance: float, time: float) -> float:
    """Calculate speed as distance divided by time.

    Parameters
    ----------
    distance : float
        Distance traveled.
    time : float
        Time spent traveling.

    Returns
    -------
    float
        Speed as distance divided by time.

    Raises
    ------
    FasterThanLightError
        If speed is greater than the speed of light.
    """
    try:
        return distance / time
    except ZeroDivisionError as exc:
        raise FasterThanLightError from exc

docs.text: Derived from the pydocstyle linter.

docs.text: An empty docstring is indicative of incomplete documentation. It should either be removed or replaced with a meaningful docstring.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
def average(values: list[float]) -> float:
    """"""

Use instead:

def average(values: list[float]) -> float:
    """Return the mean of the given values."""

docs.title: empty-method-without-abstract-decorator (B027)
docs.text: Derived from the flake8-bugbear linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for empty methods in abstract base classes without an abstract decorator.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: Empty methods in abstract base classes without an abstract decorator may be be indicative of a mistake. If the method is meant to be abstract, add an @abstractmethod decorator to the method.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
from abc import ABC


class Foo(ABC):
    def method(self): ...

Use instead:

from abc import ABC, abstractmethod


class Foo(ABC):
    @abstractmethod
    def method(self): ...

docs.title: empty-type-checking-block (TC005)
docs.text:
Derived from the flake8-type-checking linter.

Fix is always available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for an empty type-checking block.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: The type-checking block does not do anything and should be removed to avoid confusion.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
from typing import TYPE_CHECKING

if TYPE_CHECKING:
    pass

print("Hello, world!")

Use instead:

print("Hello, world!")

docs.title: References
docs.text: • PEP 563: Runtime annotation resolution and TYPE_CHECKING

docs.title: enumerate-for-loop (SIM113)
docs.text: Derived from the flake8-simplify linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for for loops with explicit loop-index variables that can be replaced with enumerate().

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: When iterating over a sequence, it's often desirable to keep track of the index of each element alongside the element itself. Prefer the enumerate builtin over manually incrementing a counter variable within the loop, as enumerate is more concise and idiomatic.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
fruits = ["apple", "banana", "cherry"]
i = 0
for fruit in fruits:
    print(f"{i + 1}. {fruit}")
    i += 1

Use instead:

fruits = ["apple", "banana", "cherry"]
for i, fruit in enumerate(fruits):
    print(f"{i + 1}. {fruit}")

docs.title: References
docs.text: • Python documentation: enumerate

docs.title: eq-without-hash (PLW1641)
docs.text: Derived from the Pylint linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for classes that implement __eq__ but not __hash__.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: A class that implements __eq__ but not __hash__ will have its hash method implicitly set to None, regardless of if a superclass defines __hash__. This will cause the class to be unhashable, which will in turn cause issues when using instances of the class as keys in a dictionary or members of a set.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
class Person:
    def __init__(self):
        self.name = "monty"

    def __eq__(self, other):
        return isinstance(other, Person) and other.name == self.name

Use instead:

class Person:
    def __init__(self):
        self.name = "monty"

    def __eq__(self, other):
        return isinstance(other, Person) and other.name == self.name

    def __hash__(self):
        return hash(self.name)

In general, it is unsound to inherit a __hash__ implementation from a parent class while overriding the __eq__ implementation because the two must be kept in sync. However, an easy way to resolve this error in cases where it is sound is to explicitly set __hash__ to the parent class's implementation:

class Developer(Person):
    def __init__(self): ...

    def __eq__(self, other): ...

    __hash__ = Person.__hash__

docs.text:
• Python documentation: object.__hash__
  • Python glossary: hashable

docs.title: error-instead-of-exception (TRY400)
docs.text:
Derived from the tryceratops linter.

Fix is sometimes available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for uses of logging.error instead of logging.exception when logging an exception.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: logging.exception logs the exception and the traceback, while logging.error only logs the exception. The former is more appropriate when logging an exception, as the traceback is often useful for debugging.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
import logging


def func():
    try:
        raise NotImplementedError
    except NotImplementedError:
        logging.error("Exception occurred")

Use instead:

import logging


def func():
    try:
        raise NotImplementedError
    except NotImplementedError:
        logging.exception("Exception occurred")

docs.title: Fix safety
docs.text: This rule's fix is marked as safe when run against logging.error calls, but unsafe when marked against other logger-like calls (e.g., logger.error), since the rule is prone to false positives when detecting logger-like calls outside of the logging module.

docs.title: References
docs.text: • Python documentation: logging.exception

docs.title: error-suffix-on-exception-name (N818)
docs.text: Derived from the pep8-naming linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for custom exception definitions that omit the Error suffix.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
The Error suffix is recommended by PEP 8:

Because exceptions should be classes, the class naming convention applies here. However, you should use the suffix "Error" on your exception names (if the exception actually is an error).

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
class Validation(Exception): ...

Use instead:

class ValidationError(Exception): ...

docs.title: Options
docs.text:
• lint.pep8-naming.ignore-names
  • lint.pep8-naming.extend-ignore-names

docs.title: escape-sequence-in-docstring (D301)
docs.text:
Derived from the pydocstyle linter.

Fix is sometimes available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for docstrings that include backslashes, but are not defined as raw string literals.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
In Python, backslashes are typically used to escape characters in strings. In raw strings (those prefixed with an r), however, backslashes are treated as literal characters.

PEP 257 recommends the use of raw strings (i.e., r"""raw triple double quotes""") for docstrings that include backslashes. The use of a raw string ensures that any backslashes are treated as literal characters, and not as escape sequences, which avoids confusion.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
def foobar():
    """Docstring for foo\bar."""


foobar.__doc__  # "Docstring for foar."

Use instead:

def foobar():
    r"""Docstring for foo\bar."""


foobar.__doc__  # "Docstring for foo\bar."

docs.title: References
docs.text:
• PEP 257 – Docstring Conventions
  • Python documentation: String and Bytes literals

docs.title: eval (PGH001)
docs.text:
Derived from the pygrep-hooks linter.

Warning: This rule has been removed and its documentation is only available for historical reasons.

docs.title: Removed
docs.text: This rule is identical to S307 which should be used instead.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for uses of the builtin eval() function.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: The eval() function is insecure as it enables arbitrary code execution.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
def foo():
    x = eval(input("Enter a number: "))
    ...

Use instead:

def foo():
    x = input("Enter a number: ")
    ...

• Python documentation: eval

docs.title: exc-info-outside-except-handler (LOG014)
docs.text:
Derived from the flake8-logging linter.

Fix is sometimes available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for logging calls with exc_info= outside exception handlers.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
Using exc_info=True outside of an exception handler attaches None as the exception information, leading to confusing messages:

>>> logging.warning("Uh oh", exc_info=True)
WARNING:root:Uh oh
NoneType: None

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
import logging


logging.warning("Foobar", exc_info=True)

Use instead:

import logging


logging.warning("Foobar")

docs.title: Fix safety
docs.text: The fix is always marked as unsafe, as it changes runtime behavior.

docs.title: except-with-empty-tuple (B029)
docs.text: Derived from the flake8-bugbear linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for exception handlers that catch an empty tuple.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: An exception handler that catches an empty tuple will not catch anything, and is indicative of a mistake. Instead, add exceptions to the except clause.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
try:
    1 / 0
except ():
    ...

Use instead:

try:
    1 / 0
except ZeroDivisionError:
    ...

docs.title: References
docs.text: • Python documentation: except clause

docs.text: Derived from the flake8-bugbear linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for exception handlers that catch non-exception classes.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: Catching classes that do not inherit from BaseException will raise a TypeError.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
try:
    1 / 0
except 1:
    ...

Use instead:

try:
    1 / 0
except ZeroDivisionError:
    ...

docs.title: References
docs.text:
• Python documentation: except clause
  • Python documentation: Built-in Exceptions

docs.title: exception-without-exc-info (LOG007)
docs.text: Derived from the flake8-logging linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for uses of logging.exception() with exc_info set to False.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
The logging.exception() method captures the exception automatically, but accepts an optional exc_info argument to override this behavior. Setting exc_info to False disables the automatic capture of the exception and stack trace.

Instead of setting exc_info to False, prefer logging.error(), which has equivalent behavior to logging.exception() with exc_info set to False, but is clearer in intent.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
logging.exception("...", exc_info=False)

Use instead:

logging.error("...")

docs.title: exec-builtin (S102)
docs.text: Derived from the flake8-bandit linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for uses of the builtin exec function.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: The exec() function is insecure as it allows for arbitrary code execution.

docs.title: Example
docs.text: exec("print('Hello World')")

docs.text:
• Python documentation: exec
  • Common Weakness Enumeration: CWE-78

docs.title: explicit-f-string-type-conversion (RUF010)
docs.text: Fix is sometimes available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for uses of str(), repr(), and ascii() as explicit type conversions within f-strings.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
f-strings support dedicated conversion flags for these types, which are more succinct and idiomatic.

Note that, in many cases, calling str() within an f-string is unnecessary and can be removed entirely, as the value will be converted to a string automatically, the notable exception being for classes that implement a custom __format__ method.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
a = "some string"
f"{repr(a)}"

Use instead:

a = "some string"
f"{a!r}"

docs.title: explicit-string-concatenation (ISC003)
docs.text:
Derived from the flake8-implicit-str-concat linter.

Fix is always available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for string literals that are explicitly concatenated (using the + operator).

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: For string literals that wrap across multiple lines, implicit string concatenation within parentheses is preferred over explicit concatenation using the + operator, as the former is more readable.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
z = (
    "The quick brown fox jumps over the lazy "
    + "dog"
)

Use instead:

z = (
    "The quick brown fox jumps over the lazy "
    "dog"
)

docs.title: expr-and-false (SIM223)
docs.text:
Derived from the flake8-simplify linter.

Fix is always available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for and expressions that contain falsey values.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
If the expression is used as a condition, it can be replaced in-full with False.

In other cases, the expression can be short-circuited to the first falsey value.

By using False (or the first falsey value), the code is more concise and easier to understand, since it no longer contains redundant conditions.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
if x and [] and y:
    pass

a = x and [] and y

Use instead:

if False:
    pass

a = x and []

docs.title: expr-and-not-expr (SIM220)
docs.text:
Derived from the flake8-simplify linter.

Fix is always available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for and expressions that include both an expression and its negation.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: An and expression that includes both an expression and its negation will always evaluate to False.

docs.title: Example
docs.text: x and not x

docs.text: • Python documentation: Boolean operations

docs.title: expr-or-not-expr (SIM221)
docs.text:
Derived from the flake8-simplify linter.

Fix is always available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for or expressions that include both an expression and its negation.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: An or expression that includes both an expression and its negation will always evaluate to True.

docs.title: Example
docs.text: x or not x

docs.title: References
docs.text: • Python documentation: Boolean operations

docs.title: expr-or-true (SIM222)
docs.text:
Derived from the flake8-simplify linter.

Fix is always available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for or expressions that contain truthy values.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
If the expression is used as a condition, it can be replaced in-full with True.

In other cases, the expression can be short-circuited to the first truthy value.

By using True (or the first truthy value), the code is more concise and easier to understand, since it no longer contains redundant conditions.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
if x or [1] or y:
    pass

a = x or [1] or y

Use instead:

if True:
    pass

a = x or [1]

docs.title: expressions-in-star-assignment (F621)
docs.text: Derived from the Pyflakes linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for the use of too many expressions in starred assignment statements.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
In assignment statements, starred expressions can be used to unpack iterables.

In Python 3, no more than 1 << 8 assignments are allowed before a starred expression, and no more than 1 << 24 expressions are allowed after a starred expression.

docs.text: • PEP 3132 – Extended Iterable Unpacking

docs.title: extraneous-parentheses (UP034)
docs.text:
Derived from the pyupgrade linter.

Fix is always available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for extraneous parentheses.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: Extraneous parentheses are redundant, and can be removed to improve readability while retaining identical semantics.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
print(("Hello, world"))

Use instead:

print("Hello, world")

docs.title: f-string-docstring (B021)
docs.text: Derived from the flake8-bugbear linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for docstrings that are written via f-strings.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: Python will interpret the f-string as a joined string, rather than as a docstring. As such, the "docstring" will not be accessible via the __doc__ attribute, nor will it be picked up by any automated documentation tooling.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
def foo():
    f"""Not a docstring."""

Use instead:

def foo():
    """A docstring."""

docs.title: References
docs.text:
• PEP 257 – Docstring Conventions
  • Python documentation: Formatted string literals

docs.title: f-string-in-exception (EM102)
docs.text:
Derived from the flake8-errmsg linter.

Fix is sometimes available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for the use of f-strings in exception constructors.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
Python includes the raise in the default traceback (and formatters like Rich and IPython do too).

By using an f-string, the error message will be duplicated in the traceback, which can make the traceback less readable.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
Given:

sub = "Some value"
raise RuntimeError(f"{sub!r} is incorrect")

Python will produce a traceback like:

Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "tmp.py", line 2, in <module>
    raise RuntimeError(f"{sub!r} is incorrect")
RuntimeError: 'Some value' is incorrect

Instead, assign the string to a variable:

sub = "Some value"
msg = f"{sub!r} is incorrect"
raise RuntimeError(msg)

Which will produce a traceback like:

Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "tmp.py", line 3, in <module>
    raise RuntimeError(msg)
RuntimeError: 'Some value' is incorrect

docs.title: f-string-in-get-text-func-call (INT001)
docs.text: Derived from the flake8-gettext linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for f-strings in gettext function calls.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
In the gettext API, the gettext function (often aliased to _) returns a translation of its input argument by looking it up in a translation catalog.

Calling gettext with an f-string as its argument can cause unexpected behavior. Since the f-string is resolved before the function call, the translation catalog will look up the formatted string, rather than the f-string template.

Instead, format the value returned by the function call, rather than its argument.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
from gettext import gettext as _

name = "Maria"
_(f"Hello, {name}!")  # Looks for "Hello, Maria!".

Use instead:

from gettext import gettext as _

name = "Maria"
_("Hello, %s!") % name  # Looks for "Hello, %s!".

docs.title: References
docs.text: • Python documentation: gettext — Multilingual internationalization services

docs.title: f-string-missing-placeholders (F541)
docs.text:
Derived from the Pyflakes linter.

Fix is always available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for f-strings that do not contain any placeholder expressions.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
f-strings are a convenient way to format strings, but they are not necessary if there are no placeholder expressions to format. In this case, a regular string should be used instead, as an f-string without placeholders can be confusing for readers, who may expect such a placeholder to be present.

An f-string without any placeholders could also indicate that the author forgot to add a placeholder expression.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
f"Hello, world!"

Use instead:

"Hello, world!"

Note: to maintain compatibility with PyFlakes, this rule only flags f-strings that are part of an implicit concatenation if none of the f-string segments contain placeholder expressions.

For example:

# Will not be flagged.
(
    f"Hello,"
    f" {name}!"
)

# Will be flagged.
(
    f"Hello,"
    f" World!"
)

See #10885 for more.

docs.title: References
docs.text: • PEP 498 – Literal String Interpolation

docs.title: f-string-number-format (FURB116)
docs.text:
Derived from the refurb linter.

Fix is sometimes available.

This rule is unstable and in preview. The --preview flag is required for use.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for uses of bin(...)[2:] (or hex, or oct) to convert an integer into a string.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: When converting an integer to a baseless binary, hexadecimal, or octal string, using f-strings is more concise and readable than using the bin, hex, or oct functions followed by a slice.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
print(bin(1337)[2:])

Use instead:

print(f"{1337:b}")

docs.title: Fix safety
docs.text: The fix is only marked as safe for integer literals, all other cases are display-only, as they may change the runtime behaviour of the program or introduce syntax errors.

docs.title: f-string (UP032)
docs.text:
Derived from the pyupgrade linter.

Fix is sometimes available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for str.format calls that can be replaced with f-strings.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: f-strings are more readable and generally preferred over str.format calls.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
"{}".format(foo)

Use instead:

f"{foo}"

docs.title: References
docs.text: • Python documentation: f-strings

docs.title: falsy-dict-get-fallback (RUF056)
docs.text:
Fix is sometimes available.

This rule is unstable and in preview. The --preview flag is required for use.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for dict.get(key, falsy_value) calls in boolean test positions.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: The default fallback None is already falsy.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
if dict.get(key, False):
    ...

Use instead:

if dict.get(key):
    ...

docs.title: Fix safety
docs.text: This rule's fix is marked as safe, unless the dict.get() call contains comments between arguments that will be deleted.

docs.title: Fix availability
docs.text: This rule's fix is unavailable in cases where invalid arguments are provided to dict.get. As shown in the documentation, dict.get takes two positional-only arguments, so invalid cases are identified by the presence of more than two arguments or any keyword arguments.

docs.title: fast-api-non-annotated-dependency (FAST002)
docs.text:
Derived from the FastAPI linter.

Fix is sometimes available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Identifies FastAPI routes with deprecated uses of Depends or similar.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
The FastAPI documentation recommends the use of typing.Annotated for defining route dependencies and parameters, rather than using Depends, Query or similar as a default value for a parameter. Using this approach everywhere helps ensure consistency and clarity in defining dependencies and parameters.

Annotated was added to the typing module in Python 3.9; however, the third-party typing_extensions package provides a backport that can be used on older versions of Python.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
from fastapi import Depends, FastAPI

app = FastAPI()


async def common_parameters(q: str | None = None, skip: int = 0, limit: int = 100):
    return {"q": q, "skip": skip, "limit": limit}


@app.get("/items/")
async def read_items(commons: dict = Depends(common_parameters)):
    return commons

Use instead:

from typing import Annotated

from fastapi import Depends, FastAPI

app = FastAPI()


async def common_parameters(q: str | None = None, skip: int = 0, limit: int = 100):
    return {"q": q, "skip": skip, "limit": limit}


@app.get("/items/")
async def read_items(commons: Annotated[dict, Depends(common_parameters)]):
    return commons

docs.title: Fix safety
docs.text: This fix is always unsafe, as adding/removing/changing a function parameter's default value can change runtime behavior. Additionally, comments inside the deprecated uses might be removed.

docs.title: Availability
docs.text: Because this rule relies on the third-party typing_extensions module for Python versions before 3.9, if the target version is < 3.9 and typing_extensions imports have been disabled by the lint.typing-extensions linter option the diagnostic will not be emitted and no fix will be offered.

docs.title: Options
docs.text: • lint.typing-extensions

docs.title: fast-api-redundant-response-model (FAST001)
docs.text:
Derived from the FastAPI linter.

Fix is always available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for FastAPI routes that use the optional response_model parameter with the same type as the return type.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
FastAPI routes automatically infer the response model type from the return type, so specifying it explicitly is redundant.

The response_model parameter is used to override the default response model type. For example, response_model can be used to specify that a non-serializable response type should instead be serialized via an alternative type.

For more information, see the FastAPI documentation.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
from fastapi import FastAPI
from pydantic import BaseModel

app = FastAPI()


class Item(BaseModel):
    name: str


@app.post("/items/", response_model=Item)
async def create_item(item: Item) -> Item:
    return item

Use instead:

from fastapi import FastAPI
from pydantic import BaseModel

app = FastAPI()


class Item(BaseModel):
    name: str


@app.post("/items/")
async def create_item(item: Item) -> Item:
    return item

docs.title: fast-api-unused-path-parameter (FAST003)
docs.text:
Derived from the FastAPI linter.

Fix is sometimes available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Identifies FastAPI routes that declare path parameters in the route path that are not included in the function signature.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
Path parameters are used to extract values from the URL path.

If a path parameter is declared in the route path but not in the function signature, it will not be accessible in the function body, which is likely a mistake.

If a path parameter is declared in the route path, but as a positional-only argument in the function signature, it will also not be accessible in the function body, as FastAPI will not inject the parameter.

docs.title: Known problems
docs.text: If the path parameter is not a valid Python identifier (e.g., user-id, as opposed to user_id), FastAPI will normalize it. However, this rule simply ignores such path parameters, as FastAPI's normalization behavior is undocumented.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
from fastapi import FastAPI

app = FastAPI()


@app.get("/things/{thing_id}")
async def read_thing(query: str): ...

Use instead:

from fastapi import FastAPI

app = FastAPI()


@app.get("/things/{thing_id}")
async def read_thing(thing_id: int, query: str): ...

docs.title: Fix safety
docs.text: This rule's fix is marked as unsafe, as modifying a function signature can change the behavior of the code.

docs.title: first-word-uncapitalized (D403)
docs.text:
Derived from the pydocstyle linter.

Fix is always available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for docstrings that do not start with a capital letter.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: The first non-whitespace character in a docstring should be capitalized for grammatical correctness and consistency.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
def average(values: list[float]) -> float:
    """return the mean of the given values."""

Use instead:

def average(values: list[float]) -> float:
    """Return the mean of the given values."""

docs.title: References
docs.text:
• PEP 257 – Docstring Conventions
  • NumPy Style Guide
  • Google Python Style Guide - Docstrings

docs.title: flask-debug-true (S201)
docs.text: Derived from the flake8-bandit linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for uses of debug=True in Flask.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: Enabling debug mode shows an interactive debugger in the browser if an error occurs, and allows running arbitrary Python code from the browser. This could leak sensitive information, or allow an attacker to run arbitrary code.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
from flask import Flask

app = Flask()

app.run(debug=True)

Use instead:

import os

from flask import Flask

app = Flask()

app.run(debug=os.environ["ENV"] == "dev")

docs.title: References
docs.text: • Flask documentation: Debug Mode

docs.title: for-loop-set-mutations (FURB142)
docs.text:
Derived from the refurb linter.

Fix is always available.

This rule is unstable and in preview. The --preview flag is required for use.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for code that updates a set with the contents of an iterable by using a for loop to call .add() or .discard() on each element separately.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: When adding or removing a batch of elements to or from a set, it's more idiomatic to use a single method call rather than adding or removing elements one by one.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
s = set()

for x in (1, 2, 3):
    s.add(x)

for x in (1, 2, 3):
    s.discard(x)

Use instead:

s = set()

s.update((1, 2, 3))
s.difference_update((1, 2, 3))

docs.title: Fix safety
docs.text: The fix will be marked as unsafe if applying the fix would delete any comments. Otherwise, it is marked as safe.

docs.title: References
docs.text: • Python documentation: set

docs.title: for-loop-writes (FURB122)
docs.text:
Derived from the refurb linter.

Fix is always available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for the use of IOBase.write in a for loop.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: When writing a batch of elements, it's more idiomatic to use a single method call to IOBase.writelines, rather than write elements one by one.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
from pathlib import Path

with Path("file").open("w") as f:
    for line in lines:
        f.write(line)

with Path("file").open("wb") as f_b:
    for line_b in lines_b:
        f_b.write(line_b.encode())

Use instead:

from pathlib import Path

with Path("file").open("w") as f:
    f.writelines(lines)

with Path("file").open("wb") as f_b:
    f_b.writelines(line_b.encode() for line_b in lines_b)

docs.title: Fix safety
docs.text: This fix is marked as unsafe if it would cause comments to be deleted.

docs.title: References
docs.text: • Python documentation: io.IOBase.writelines

docs.title: format-in-get-text-func-call (INT002)
docs.text: Derived from the flake8-gettext linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for str.format calls in gettext function calls.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
In the gettext API, the gettext function (often aliased to _) returns a translation of its input argument by looking it up in a translation catalog.

Calling gettext with a formatted string as its argument can cause unexpected behavior. Since the formatted string is resolved before the function call, the translation catalog will look up the formatted string, rather than the str.format-style template.

Instead, format the value returned by the function call, rather than its argument.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
from gettext import gettext as _

name = "Maria"
_("Hello, {}!".format(name))  # Looks for "Hello, Maria!".

Use instead:

from gettext import gettext as _

name = "Maria"
_("Hello, %s!") % name  # Looks for "Hello, %s!".

docs.title: References
docs.text: • Python documentation: gettext — Multilingual internationalization services

docs.title: format-literals (UP030)
docs.text:
Derived from the pyupgrade linter.

Fix is sometimes available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for unnecessary positional indices in format strings.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
In Python 3.1 and later, format strings can use implicit positional references. For example, "{0}, {1}".format("Hello", "World") can be rewritten as "{}, {}".format("Hello", "World").

If the positional indices appear exactly in-order, they can be omitted in favor of automatic indices to improve readability.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
"{0}, {1}".format("Hello", "World")  # "Hello, World"

Use instead:

"{}, {}".format("Hello", "World")  # "Hello, World"

This fix is marked as unsafe because:

  • Comments attached to arguments are not moved, which can cause comments to mismatch the actual arguments.
  • If arguments have side effects (e.g., print), reordering may change program behavior.

docs.title: References
docs.text:
• Python documentation: Format String Syntax
  • Python documentation: str.format

docs.title: forward-annotation-syntax-error (F722)
docs.text: Derived from the Pyflakes linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for forward annotations that include invalid syntax.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
In Python, type annotations can be quoted as strings literals to enable references to types that have not yet been defined, known as "forward references".

However, these quoted annotations must be valid Python expressions. The use of invalid syntax in a quoted annotation won't raise a SyntaxError, but will instead raise an error when type checking is performed.

docs.title: Example
docs.text: def foo() -> "/": ...

docs.title: References
docs.text: • PEP 563 – Postponed Evaluation of Annotations

docs.title: fromisoformat-replace-z (FURB162)
docs.text:
Derived from the refurb linter.

Fix is always available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for datetime.fromisoformat() calls where the only argument is an inline replacement of Z with a zero offset timezone.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
On Python 3.11 and later, datetime.fromisoformat() can handle most ISO 8601 formats including ones affixed with Z, so such an operation is unnecessary.

More information on unsupported formats can be found in the official documentation.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
from datetime import datetime


date = "2025-01-01T00:00:00Z"

datetime.fromisoformat(date.replace("Z", "+00:00"))
datetime.fromisoformat(date[:-1] + "-00")
datetime.fromisoformat(date.strip("Z", "-0000"))
datetime.fromisoformat(date.rstrip("Z", "-00:00"))

Use instead:

from datetime import datetime


date = "2025-01-01T00:00:00Z"

datetime.fromisoformat(date)

docs.title: Fix safety
docs.text:
The fix is always marked as unsafe, as it might change the program's behaviour.

For example, working code might become non-working:

d = "Z2025-01-01T00:00:00Z"  # Note the leading `Z`

datetime.fromisoformat(d.strip("Z") + "+00:00")  # Fine
datetime.fromisoformat(d)  # Runtime error

docs.title: References
docs.text:
• What’s New In Python 3.11 § datetime
  • fromisoformat

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for function calls in dataclass attribute defaults.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
Function calls are only performed once, at definition time. The returned value is then reused by all instances of the dataclass. This can lead to unexpected behavior when the function call returns a mutable object, as changes to the object will be shared across all instances.

If a field needs to be initialized with a mutable object, use the field(default_factory=...) pattern.

Attributes whose default arguments are NewType calls where the original type is immutable are ignored.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
from dataclasses import dataclass


def simple_list() -> list[int]:
    return [1, 2, 3, 4]


@dataclass
class A:
    mutable_default: list[int] = simple_list()

Use instead:

from dataclasses import dataclass, field


def creating_list() -> list[int]:
    return [1, 2, 3, 4]


@dataclass
class A:
    mutable_default: list[int] = field(default_factory=creating_list)

docs.title: Options
docs.text: • lint.flake8-bugbear.extend-immutable-calls

docs.title: function-call-in-default-argument (B008)
docs.text: Derived from the flake8-bugbear linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for function calls in default function arguments.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
Any function call that's used in a default argument will only be performed once, at definition time. The returned value will then be reused by all calls to the function, which can lead to unexpected behaviour.

Parameters with immutable type annotations will be ignored by this rule. Those whose default arguments are NewType calls where the original type is immutable are also ignored.

Calls and types outside of the standard library can be marked as an exception to this rule with the lint.flake8-bugbear.extend-immutable-calls configuration option.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
def create_list() -> list[int]:
    return [1, 2, 3]


def mutable_default(arg: list[int] = create_list()) -> list[int]:
    arg.append(4)
    return arg

Use instead:

def better(arg: list[int] | None = None) -> list[int]:
    if arg is None:
        arg = create_list()

    arg.append(4)
    return arg

If the use of a singleton is intentional, assign the result call to a module-level variable, and use that variable in the default argument:

ERROR = ValueError("Hosts weren't successfully added")


def add_host(error: Exception = ERROR) -> None: ...

docs.title: Options
docs.text: • lint.flake8-bugbear.extend-immutable-calls

docs.title: function-uses-loop-variable (B023)
docs.text: Derived from the flake8-bugbear linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for function definitions that use a loop variable.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
The loop variable is not bound in the function definition, so it will always have the value it had in the last iteration when the function is called.

Instead, consider using a default argument to bind the loop variable at function definition time. Or, use functools.partial.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
adders = [lambda x: x + i for i in range(3)]
values = [adder(1) for adder in adders]  # [3, 3, 3]

Use instead:

adders = [lambda x, i=i: x + i for i in range(3)]
values = [adder(1) for adder in adders]  # [1, 2, 3]

Or:

from functools import partial

adders = [partial(lambda x, i: x + i, i=i) for i in range(3)]
values = [adder(1) for adder in adders]  # [1, 2, 3]

docs.title: References
docs.text:
• The Hitchhiker's Guide to Python: Late Binding Closures
  • Python documentation: functools.partial

docs.title: future-annotations-in-stub (PYI044)
docs.text:
Derived from the flake8-pyi linter.

Fix is sometimes available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for the presence of the from __future__ import annotations import statement in stub files.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: Stub files natively support forward references in all contexts, as stubs are never executed at runtime. (They should be thought of as "data files" for type checkers.) As such, the from __future__ import annotations import statement has no effect and should be omitted.

docs.title: References
docs.text: • Typing Style Guide

docs.title: future-feature-not-defined (F407)
docs.text: Derived from the Pyflakes linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for __future__ imports that are not defined in the current Python version.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: Importing undefined or unsupported members from the __future__ module is a SyntaxError.

docs.title: References
docs.text: • Python documentation: __future__

docs.title: future-required-type-annotation (FA102)
docs.text:
Derived from the flake8-future-annotations linter.

Fix is always available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for uses of PEP 585- and PEP 604-style type annotations in Python modules that lack the required from __future__ import annotations import for compatibility with older Python versions.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
Using PEP 585 and PEP 604 style annotations without a from __future__ import annotations import will cause runtime errors on Python versions prior to 3.9 and 3.10, respectively.

By adding the __future__ import, the interpreter will no longer interpret annotations at evaluation time, making the code compatible with both past and future Python versions.

This rule respects the target-version setting. For example, if your project targets Python 3.10 and above, adding from __future__ import annotations does not impact your ability to leverage PEP 604-style unions (e.g., to convert Optional[str] to str | None). As such, this rule will only flag such usages if your project targets Python 3.9 or below.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
def func(obj: dict[str, int | None]) -> None: ...

Use instead:

from __future__ import annotations


def func(obj: dict[str, int | None]) -> None: ...

docs.title: Fix safety
docs.text: This rule's fix is marked as unsafe, as adding from __future__ import annotations may change the semantics of the program.

docs.title: Options
docs.text: • target-version

docs.title: future-rewritable-type-annotation (FA100)
docs.text:
Derived from the flake8-future-annotations linter.

Fix is always available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for missing from __future__ import annotations imports upon detecting type annotations that can be written more succinctly under PEP 563.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
PEP 585 enabled the use of a number of convenient type annotations, such as list[str] instead of List[str]. However, these annotations are only available on Python 3.9 and higher, unless the from __future__ import annotations import is present.

Similarly, PEP 604 enabled the use of the | operator for unions, such as str | None instead of Optional[str]. However, these annotations are only available on Python 3.10 and higher, unless the from __future__ import annotations import is present.

By adding the __future__ import, the pyupgrade rules can automatically migrate existing code to use the new syntax, even for older Python versions. This rule thus pairs well with pyupgrade and with Ruff's pyupgrade rules.

This rule respects the target-version setting. For example, if your project targets Python 3.10 and above, adding from __future__ import annotations does not impact your ability to leverage PEP 604-style unions (e.g., to convert Optional[str] to str | None). As such, this rule will only flag such usages if your project targets Python 3.9 or below.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
from typing import List, Dict, Optional


def func(obj: Dict[str, Optional[int]]) -> None: ...

Use instead:

from __future__ import annotations

from typing import List, Dict, Optional


def func(obj: Dict[str, Optional[int]]) -> None: ...

After running the additional pyupgrade rules:

from __future__ import annotations


def func(obj: dict[str, int | None]) -> None: ...

docs.title: Fix safety
docs.text: This rule's fix is marked as unsafe, as adding from __future__ import annotations may change the semantics of the program.

docs.title: Options
docs.text: • target-version

docs.title: generator-return-from-iter-method (PYI058)
docs.text:
Derived from the flake8-pyi linter.

Fix is sometimes available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for simple __iter__ methods that return Generator, and for simple __aiter__ methods that return AsyncGenerator.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
Using (Async)Iterator for these methods is simpler and more elegant. More importantly, it also reflects the fact that the precise kind of iterator returned from an __iter__ method is usually an implementation detail that could change at any time. Type annotations help define a contract for a function; implementation details should not leak into that contract.

For example:

from collections.abc import AsyncGenerator, Generator
from typing import Any


class CustomIterator:
    def __iter__(self) -> Generator:
        yield from range(42)


class CustomIterator2:
    def __iter__(self) -> Generator[str, Any, None]:
        yield from "abcdefg"

Use instead:

from collections.abc import Iterator


class CustomIterator:
    def __iter__(self) -> Iterator:
        yield from range(42)


class CustomIterator2:
    def __iter__(self) -> Iterator[str]:
        yield from "abdefg"

docs.title: Fix safety
docs.text: This rule tries hard to avoid false-positive errors, and the rule's fix should always be safe for .pyi stub files. However, there is a slightly higher chance that a false positive might be emitted by this rule when applied to runtime Python (.py files). As such, the fix is marked as unsafe for any __iter__ or __aiter__ method in a .py file that has more than two statements (including docstrings) in its body.

docs.title: generic-not-last-base-class (PYI059)
docs.text:
Derived from the flake8-pyi linter.

Fix is sometimes available.

This rule is unstable and in preview. The --preview flag is required for use.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for classes inheriting from typing.Generic[] where Generic[] is not the last base class in the bases tuple.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
If Generic[] is not the final class in the bases tuple, unexpected behaviour can occur at runtime (See this CPython issue for an example).

The rule is also applied to stub files, where it won't cause issues at runtime. This is because type checkers may not be able to infer an accurate MRO for the class, which could lead to unexpected or inaccurate results when they analyze your code.

For example:

from collections.abc import Container, Iterable, Sized
from typing import Generic, TypeVar


T = TypeVar("T")
K = TypeVar("K")
V = TypeVar("V")


class LinkedList(Generic[T], Sized):
    def push(self, item: T) -> None:
        self._items.append(item)


class MyMapping(
    Generic[K, V],
    Iterable[tuple[K, V]],
    Container[tuple[K, V]],
):
    ...

Use instead:

from collections.abc import Container, Iterable, Sized
from typing import Generic, TypeVar


T = TypeVar("T")
K = TypeVar("K")
V = TypeVar("V")


class LinkedList(Sized, Generic[T]):
    def push(self, item: T) -> None:
        self._items.append(item)


class MyMapping(
    Iterable[tuple[K, V]],
    Container[tuple[K, V]],
    Generic[K, V],
):
    ...

docs.title: Fix safety
docs.text: This rule's fix is always unsafe because reordering base classes can change the behavior of the code by modifying the class's MRO. The fix will also delete trailing comments after the Generic base class in multi-line base class lists, if any are present.

docs.title: Fix availability
docs.text: This rule's fix is only available when there are no *args present in the base class list.

docs.title: References
docs.text: • typing.Generic documentation

docs.title: get-attr-with-constant (B009)
docs.text:
Derived from the flake8-bugbear linter.

Fix is always available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for uses of getattr that take a constant attribute value as an argument (e.g., getattr(obj, "foo")).

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: getattr is used to access attributes dynamically. If the attribute is defined as a constant, it is no safer than a typical property access. When possible, prefer property access over getattr calls, as the former is more concise and idiomatic.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
getattr(obj, "foo")

Use instead:

obj.foo

docs.text: • Python documentation: getattr

docs.title: glob (PTH207)
docs.text: Derived from the flake8-use-pathlib linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for the use of glob.glob() and glob.iglob().

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
pathlib offers a high-level API for path manipulation, as compared to the lower-level API offered by os and glob.

When possible, using Path object methods such as Path.glob() can improve readability over their low-level counterparts (e.g., glob.glob()).

Note that glob.glob() and Path.glob() are not exact equivalents:

glob-module functions Path.glob() Hidden files Hidden files are excluded by default. On Python 3.11+, the include_hidden keyword can be used to include hidden directories. Includes hidden files by default. Eagerness glob.iglob() returns a lazy iterator. Under the hood, glob.glob() simply converts the iterator to a list. Path.glob() returns a lazy iterator. Working directory glob.glob() and glob.iglob() take a root_dir keyword to set the current working directory. Path.rglob() can be used to return the relative path. Globstar (**) The recursive flag must be set to True for the ** pattern to match any files and zero or more directories, subdirectories, and symbolic links. The ** pattern in Path.glob() means "this directory and all subdirectories, recursively". In other words, it enables recursive globbing.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
import glob
import os

glob.glob(os.path.join("my_path", "requirements*.txt"))

Use instead:

from pathlib import Path

Path("my_path").glob("requirements*.txt")

docs.title: Known issues
docs.text: While using pathlib can improve the readability and type safety of your code, it can be less performant than the lower-level alternatives that work directly with strings, especially on older versions of Python.

docs.title: global-at-module-level (PLW0604)
docs.text: Derived from the Pylint linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for uses of the global keyword at the module level.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
The global keyword is used within functions to indicate that a name refers to a global variable, rather than a local variable.

At the module level, all names are global by default, so the global keyword is redundant.

docs.title: global-statement (PLW0603)
docs.text: Derived from the Pylint linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for the use of global statements to update identifiers.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: Pylint discourages the use of global variables as global mutable state is a common source of bugs and confusing behavior.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
var = 1


def foo():
    global var  # [global-statement]
    var = 10
    print(var)


foo()
print(var)

Use instead:

var = 1


def foo():
    var = 10
    print(var)
    return var


var = foo()
print(var)

docs.title: global-variable-not-assigned (PLW0602)
docs.text: Derived from the Pylint linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for global variables that are not assigned a value in the current scope.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: The global keyword allows an inner scope to modify a variable declared in the outer scope. If the variable is not modified within the inner scope, there is no need to use global.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
DEBUG = True


def foo():
    global DEBUG
    if DEBUG:
        print("foo() called")
    ...

Use instead:

DEBUG = True


def foo():
    if DEBUG:
        print("foo() called")
    ...

Instead, bind to specific interfaces.

Instead, store passwords and other secrets in configuration files, environment variables, or other sources that are excluded from version control.

def connect_to_server(password="hunter2"): ...

docs.title: hardcoded-temp-file (S108)
docs.text: Derived from the flake8-bandit linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for the use of hardcoded temporary file or directory paths.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
The use of hardcoded paths for temporary files can be insecure. If an attacker discovers the location of a hardcoded path, they can replace the contents of the file or directory with a malicious payload.

Other programs may also read or write contents to these hardcoded paths, causing unexpected behavior.

with open("/tmp/foo.txt", "w") as file:
    ...

import tempfile

with tempfile.NamedTemporaryFile() as file:

docs.title: hashlib-digest-hex (FURB181)
docs.text:
Derived from the refurb linter.

Fix is sometimes available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for the use of .digest().hex() on a hashlib hash, like sha512.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: When generating a hex digest from a hash, it's preferable to use the .hexdigest() method, rather than calling .digest() and then .hex(), as the former is more concise and readable.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
from hashlib import sha512

hashed = sha512(b"some data").digest().hex()

Use instead:

from hashlib import sha512

hashed = sha512(b"some data").hexdigest()

docs.text: • Python documentation: hashlib

docs.title: hashlib-insecure-hash-function (S324)
docs.text: Derived from the flake8-bandit linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for uses of weak or broken cryptographic hash functions in hashlib and crypt libraries.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
Weak or broken cryptographic hash functions may be susceptible to collision attacks (where two different inputs produce the same hash) or pre-image attacks (where an attacker can find an input that produces a given hash). This can lead to security vulnerabilities in applications that rely on these hash functions.

Avoid using weak or broken cryptographic hash functions in security contexts. Instead, use a known secure hash function such as SHA256.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
import hashlib


def certificate_is_valid(certificate: bytes, known_hash: str) -> bool:
    hash = hashlib.md5(certificate).hexdigest()
    return hash == known_hash

Use instead:

import hashlib


def certificate_is_valid(certificate: bytes, known_hash: str) -> bool:
    hash = hashlib.sha256(certificate).hexdigest()
    return hash == known_hash

or add usedforsecurity=False if the hashing algorithm is not used in a security context, e.g. as a non-cryptographic one-way compression function:

import hashlib


def certificate_is_valid(certificate: bytes, known_hash: str) -> bool:
    hash = hashlib.md5(certificate, usedforsecurity=False).hexdigest()
    return hash == known_hash

docs.title: if-else-block-instead-of-dict-get (SIM401)
docs.text:
Derived from the flake8-simplify linter.

Fix is sometimes available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for if statements that can be replaced with dict.get calls.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
dict.get() calls can be used to replace if statements that assign a value to a variable in both branches, falling back to a default value if the key is not found. When possible, using dict.get is more concise and more idiomatic.

Under preview mode, this rule will also suggest replacing if-else expressions with dict.get calls.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
foo = {}
if "bar" in foo:
    value = foo["bar"]
else:
    value = 0

Use instead:

foo = {}
value = foo.get("bar", 0)

If preview mode is enabled:

value = foo["bar"] if "bar" in foo else 0

Use instead:

value = foo.get("bar", 0)

docs.title: References
docs.text: • Python documentation: Mapping Types

docs.title: if-else-block-instead-of-dict-lookup (SIM116)
docs.text: Derived from the flake8-simplify linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for three or more consecutive if-statements with direct returns

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: These can be simplified by using a dictionary

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
def find_phrase(x):
    if x == 1:
        return "Hello"
    elif x == 2:
        return "Goodbye"
    elif x == 3:
        return "Good morning"
    else:
        return "Goodnight"

Use instead:

def find_phrase(x):
    phrases = {1: "Hello", 2: "Goodye", 3: "Good morning"}
    return phrases.get(x, "Goodnight")

docs.title: if-else-block-instead-of-if-exp (SIM108)
docs.text:
Derived from the flake8-simplify linter.

Fix is sometimes available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text:
Check for if-else-blocks that can be replaced with a ternary or binary operator.

The lint is suppressed if the suggested replacement would exceed the maximum line length configured in pycodestyle.max-line-length.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: if-else-blocks that assign a value to a variable in both branches can be expressed more concisely by using a ternary or binary operator.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
if foo:
    bar = x
else:
    bar = y

Use instead:

bar = x if foo else y

Or:

if cond:
    z = cond
else:
    z = other_cond

Use instead:

z = cond or other_cond

docs.title: Known issues
docs.text: This is an opinionated style rule that may not always be to everyone's taste, especially for code that makes use of complex if conditions. Ternary operators can also make it harder to measure code coverage with tools that use line profiling.

docs.title: References
docs.text: • Python documentation: Conditional expressions

docs.title: if-exp-instead-of-or-operator (FURB110)
docs.text:
Derived from the refurb linter.

Fix is sometimes available.

This rule is unstable and in preview. The --preview flag is required for use.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for ternary if expressions that can be replaced with the or operator.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: Ternary if expressions are more verbose than or expressions while providing the same functionality.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
z = x if x else y

Use instead:

z = x or y

docs.title: Fix safety
docs.text:
This rule's fix is marked as unsafe in the event that the body of the if expression contains side effects.

For example, foo will be called twice in foo() if foo() else bar() (assuming foo() returns a truthy value), but only once in foo() or bar().

docs.title: if-expr-min-max (FURB136)
docs.text:
Derived from the refurb linter.

Fix is sometimes available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for if expressions that can be replaced with min() or max() calls.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: An if expression that selects the lesser or greater of two sub-expressions can be replaced with a min() or max() call respectively. When possible, prefer min() and max(), as they're more concise and readable than the equivalent if expression.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
highest_score = score1 if score1 > score2 else score2

Use instead:

highest_score = max(score2, score1)

docs.title: Why is this bad?

False if a else True

Derived from the flake8-simplify linter.

Fix is sometimes available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for if expressions that can be replaced with bool() calls.

docs.title: Why is this bad?

While the fix will try to wrap non-boolean values in a call to bool, custom implementations of comparison functions like __eq__ can avoid the bool call and still lead to altered behavior. Derived from the Pylint linter.

docs.title: What it does

docs.title: implicit-class-var-in-dataclass (RUF045)
docs.text: This rule is unstable and in preview. The --preview flag is required for use.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text:
Checks for implicit class variables in dataclasses.

Variables matching the lint.dummy-variable-rgx are excluded from this rule.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
Class variables are shared between all instances of that class. In dataclasses, fields with no annotations at all are implicitly considered class variables, and a TypeError is raised if a user attempts to initialize an instance of the class with this field.

@dataclass
class C:
    a = 1
    b: str = ""

C(a = 42)  # TypeError: C.__init__() got an unexpected keyword argument 'a'

docs.text:
@dataclass
class C:
    a = 1

Use instead:

class C:
    a: ClassVar[int] = 1

docs.text: When looking up the current directory, prefer Path.cwd() over Path().resolve(), as Path.cwd() is more explicit in its intent.

from pathlib import Path

docs.title: implicit-namespace-package (INP001)
docs.text: Derived from the flake8-no-pep420 linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for packages that are missing an __init__.py file.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
Python packages are directories that contain a file named __init__.py. The existence of this file indicates that the directory is a Python package, and so it can be imported the same way a module can be imported.

Directories that lack an __init__.py file can still be imported, but they're indicative of a special kind of package, known as a "namespace package" (see: PEP 420). Namespace packages are less widely used, so a package that lacks an __init__.py file is typically meant to be a regular package, and the absence of the __init__.py file is probably an oversight.

docs.title: Options
docs.text: • namespace-packages

docs.title: implicit-optional (RUF013)
docs.text: Fix is sometimes available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for the use of implicit Optional in type annotations when the default parameter value is None.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
Implicit Optional is prohibited by PEP 484. It is confusing and inconsistent with the rest of the type system.

It's recommended to use Optional[T] instead. For Python 3.10 and later, you can also use T | None.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
def foo(arg: int = None):
    pass

Use instead:

from typing import Optional


def foo(arg: Optional[int] = None):
    pass

Or, for Python 3.10 and later:

def foo(arg: int | None = None):
    pass

If you want to use the | operator in Python 3.9 and earlier, you can use future imports:

from __future__ import annotations


def foo(arg: int | None = None):
    pass

docs.title: Limitations
docs.text:
Type aliases are not supported and could result in false negatives. For example, the following code will not be flagged:

Text = str | bytes


def foo(arg: Text = None):
    pass

docs.title: Options

• target-version

docs.text: When [preview] is enabled, if lint.future-annotations is set to true, from __future__ import annotations will be added if doing so would allow using the | operator on a Python version before 3.10.

docs.title: Fix safety
docs.text: This fix is always marked as unsafe because it can change the behavior of code that relies on type hints, and it assumes the default value is always appropriate—which might not be the case.

docs.title: implicit-return-value (RET502)
docs.text:
Derived from the flake8-return linter.

Fix is always available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for the presence of a return statement with no explicit value, for functions that return non-None values elsewhere.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: Including a return statement with no explicit value can cause confusion when other return statements in the function return non-None values. Python implicitly assumes return None if no other return value is present. Adding an explicit return None can make the code more readable by clarifying intent.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
def foo(bar):
    if not bar:
        return
    return 1

Use instead:

def foo(bar):
    if not bar:
        return None
    return 1

docs.title: implicit-return (RET503)
docs.text:
Derived from the flake8-return linter.

Fix is always available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for missing explicit return statements at the end of functions that can return non-None values.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: The lack of an explicit return statement at the end of a function that can return non-None values can cause confusion. Python implicitly returns None if no other return value is present. Adding an explicit return None can make the code more readable by clarifying intent.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
def foo(bar):
    if not bar:
        return 1

Use instead:

def foo(bar):
    if not bar:
        return 1
    return None

docs.title: import-outside-top-level (PLC0415)
docs.text: Derived from the Pylint linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for import statements outside of a module's top-level scope, such as within a function or class definition.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
PEP 8 recommends placing imports not only at the top-level of a module, but at the very top of the file, "just after any module comments and docstrings, and before module globals and constants."

import statements have effects that are global in scope; defining them at the top level has a number of benefits. For example, it makes it easier to identify the dependencies of a module, and ensures that any invalid imports are caught regardless of whether a specific function is called or class is instantiated.

An import statement would typically be placed within a function only to avoid a circular dependency, to defer a costly module load, or to avoid loading a dependency altogether in a certain runtime environment.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
def print_python_version():
    import platform

    print(platform.python_version())

Use instead:

import platform


def print_python_version():
    print(platform.python_version())

docs.title: See also
docs.text: This rule will ignore import statements configured in lint.flake8-tidy-imports.banned-module-level-imports if the rule banned-module-level-imports is enabled.

docs.title: import-private-name (PLC2701)
docs.text:
Derived from the Pylint linter.

This rule is unstable and in preview. The --preview flag is required for use.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for import statements that import a private name (a name starting with an underscore _) from another module.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
PEP 8 states that names starting with an underscore are private. Thus, they are not intended to be used outside of the module in which they are defined.

Further, as private imports are not considered part of the public API, they are prone to unexpected changes, especially outside of semantic versioning.

Instead, consider using the public API of the module.

This rule ignores private name imports that are exclusively used in type annotations. Ideally, types would be public; however, this is not always possible when using third-party libraries.

docs.title: Known problems
docs.text: Does not ignore private name imports from within the module that defines the private name if the module is defined with PEP 420 namespace packages (i.e., directories that omit the __init__.py file). Namespace packages must be configured via the namespace-packages setting.

docs.title: Example
docs.text: from foo import _bar

docs.title: Options
docs.text: • namespace-packages

docs.title: References
docs.text:
• PEP 8: Naming Conventions
  • Semantic Versioning

docs.title: import-self (PLW0406)
docs.text: Derived from the Pylint linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for import statements that import the current module.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: Importing a module from itself is a circular dependency and results in an ImportError exception.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
# file: this_file.py
from this_file import foo


def foo(): ...

docs.title: import-shadowed-by-loop-var (F402)
docs.text: Derived from the Pyflakes linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for import bindings that are shadowed by loop variables.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
Shadowing an import with loop variables makes the code harder to read and reason about, as the identify of the imported binding is no longer clear. It's also often indicative of a mistake, as it's unlikely that the loop variable is intended to be used as the imported binding.

Consider using a different name for the loop variable.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
from os import path

for path in files:
    print(path)

Use instead:

from os import path


for filename in files:
    print(filename)

docs.title: in-dict-keys (SIM118)
docs.text:
Derived from the flake8-simplify linter.

Fix is always available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for key-existence checks against dict.keys() calls.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: When checking for the existence of a key in a given dictionary, using key in dict is more readable and efficient than key in dict.keys(), while having the same semantics.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
key in foo.keys()

Use instead:

key in foo

docs.title: Fix safety
docs.text: Given key in obj.keys(), obj could be a dictionary, or it could be another type that defines a .keys() method. In the latter case, removing the .keys() attribute could lead to a runtime error. The fix is marked as safe when the type of obj is known to be a dictionary; otherwise, it is marked as unsafe.

docs.title: References
docs.text: • Python documentation: Mapping Types

docs.title: in-empty-collection (RUF060)
docs.text: This rule is unstable and in preview. The --preview flag is required for use.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for membership tests on empty collections (such as list, tuple, set or dict).

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: If the collection is always empty, the check is unnecessary, and can be removed.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
if 1 not in set():
    print("got it!")

Use instead:

print("got it!")

docs.title: incorrect-blank-line-after-class (D204)
docs.text:
Derived from the pydocstyle linter.

Fix is always available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for class methods that are not separated from the class's docstring by a blank line.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
PEP 257 recommends the use of a blank line to separate a class's docstring from its methods.

This rule may not apply to all projects; its applicability is a matter of convention. By default, this rule is enabled when using the numpy and pep257 conventions, and disabled when using the google convention.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
class PhotoMetadata:
    """Metadata about a photo."""
    def __init__(self, file: Path):
        ...

Use instead:

class PhotoMetadata:
    """Metadata about a photo."""

    def __init__(self, file: Path):
        ...

docs.title: Options
docs.text: • lint.pydocstyle.convention

docs.title: References
docs.text:
• PEP 257 – Docstring Conventions
  • NumPy Style Guide
  • Google Python Style Guide - Docstrings

docs.title: incorrect-blank-line-before-class (D203)
docs.text:
Derived from the pydocstyle linter.

Fix is always available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for docstrings on class definitions that are not preceded by a blank line.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
Use a blank line to separate the docstring from the class definition, for consistency.

This rule may not apply to all projects; its applicability is a matter of convention. By default, this rule is disabled when using the google, numpy, and pep257 conventions.

For an alternative, see D211.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
class PhotoMetadata:
    """Metadata about a photo."""

Use instead:

class PhotoMetadata:

    """Metadata about a photo."""
