docs.text: • lint.pydocstyle.convention

docs.title: incorrect-dict-iterator (PERF102)
docs.text:
Derived from the Perflint linter.

Fix is always available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for uses of dict.items() that discard either the key or the value when iterating over the dictionary.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
If you only need the keys or values of a dictionary, you should use dict.keys() or dict.values() respectively, instead of dict.items(). These specialized methods are more efficient than dict.items(), as they avoid allocating tuples for every item in the dictionary. They also communicate the intent of the code more clearly.

Note that, as with all perflint rules, this is only intended as a micro-optimization, and will have a negligible impact on performance in most cases.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
obj = {"a": 1, "b": 2}
for key, value in obj.items():
    print(value)

Use instead:

obj = {"a": 1, "b": 2}
for value in obj.values():
    print(value)

docs.title: Fix safety
docs.text: The fix does not perform any type analysis and, as such, may suggest an incorrect fix if the object in question does not duck-type as a mapping (e.g., if it is missing a .keys() or .values() method, or if those methods behave differently than they do on standard mapping types).

docs.title: incorrectly-parenthesized-tuple-in-subscript (RUF031)
docs.text:
Fix is always available.

This rule is unstable and in preview. The --preview flag is required for use.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text:
Checks for consistent style regarding whether nonempty tuples in subscripts are parenthesized.

The exact nature of this violation depends on the setting lint.ruff.parenthesize-tuple-in-subscript. By default, the use of parentheses is considered a violation.

This rule is not applied inside "typing contexts" (type annotations, type aliases and subscripted class bases), as these have their own specific conventions around them.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: It is good to be consistent and, depending on the codebase, one or the other convention may be preferred.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
directions = {(0, 1): "North", (1, 0): "East", (0, -1): "South", (-1, 0): "West"}
directions[(0, 1)]

Use instead (with default setting):

directions = {(0, 1): "North", (1, 0): "East", (0, -1): "South", (-1, 0): "West"}
directions[0, 1]

docs.title: Options
docs.text: • lint.ruff.parenthesize-tuple-in-subscript

docs.title: indentation-with-invalid-multiple-comment (E114)
docs.text:
Derived from the pycodestyle linter.

This rule is unstable and in preview. The --preview flag is required for use.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for indentation of comments with a non-multiple of 4 spaces.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: According to PEP 8, 4 spaces per indentation level should be preferred.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
if True:
   # a = 1
    ...

Use instead:

if True:
    # a = 1
    ...

docs.title: Formatter compatibility
docs.text:
We recommend against using this rule alongside the formatter. The formatter enforces consistent indentation, making the rule redundant.

The rule is also incompatible with the formatter when using indent-width with a value other than 4.

docs.text: • indent-width

docs.text:
Derived from the pycodestyle linter.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: According to PEP 8, 4 spaces per indentation level should be preferred.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
if True:
   a = 1

Use instead:

    a = 1

docs.title: indented-form-feed (RUF054)
docs.text: This rule is unstable and in preview. The --preview flag is required for use.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for form feed characters preceded by either a space or a tab.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
The language reference states:

A formfeed character may be present at the start of the line; it will be ignored for the indentation calculations above. Formfeed characters occurring elsewhere in the leading whitespace have an undefined effect (for instance, they may reset the space count to zero).

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
if foo():\n    \fbar()

Use instead:

if foo():\n    bar()

docs.title: int-on-sliced-str (FURB166)
docs.text:
Derived from the refurb linter.

Fix is always available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for uses of int with an explicit base in which a string expression is stripped of its leading prefix (i.e., 0b, 0o, or 0x).

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
Given an integer string with a prefix (e.g., 0xABC), Python can automatically determine the base of the integer by the prefix without needing to specify it explicitly.

Instead of int(num[2:], 16), use int(num, 0), which will automatically deduce the base based on the prefix.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
num = "0xABC"

if num.startswith("0b"):
    i = int(num[2:], 2)
elif num.startswith("0o"):
    i = int(num[2:], 8)
elif num.startswith("0x"):
    i = int(num[2:], 16)

print(i)

Use instead:

num = "0xABC"

i = int(num, 0)

print(i)

docs.title: Fix safety
docs.text: The rule's fix is marked as unsafe, as Ruff cannot guarantee that the argument to int will remain valid when its base is included in the function call.

docs.title: References
docs.text: • Python documentation: int

docs.title: invalid-all-format (PLE0605)
docs.text: Derived from the Pylint linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for invalid assignments to __all__.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
In Python, __all__ should contain a sequence of strings that represent the names of all "public" symbols exported by a module.

Assigning anything other than a tuple or list of strings to __all__ is invalid.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
__all__ = "Foo"

Use instead:

__all__ = ("Foo",)

docs.title: References
docs.text: • Python documentation: The import statement

docs.title: invalid-all-object (PLE0604)
docs.text: Derived from the Pylint linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for the inclusion of invalid objects in __all__.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
In Python, __all__ should contain a sequence of strings that represent the names of all "public" symbols exported by a module.

Assigning anything other than a tuple or list of strings to __all__ is invalid.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
__all__ = [Foo, 1, None]

Use instead:

__all__ = ["Foo", "Bar", "Baz"]

docs.title: References
docs.text: • Python documentation: The import statement

docs.title: invalid-argument-name (N803)
docs.text: Derived from the pep8-naming linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for argument names that do not follow the snake_case convention.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
PEP 8 recommends that function names should be lower case and separated by underscores (also known as snake_case).

Function names should be lowercase, with words separated by underscores as necessary to improve readability.

Variable names follow the same convention as function names.

mixedCase is allowed only in contexts where that’s already the prevailing style (e.g. threading.py), to retain backwards compatibility.

Methods decorated with @typing.override are ignored.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
def my_function(A, myArg):
    pass

Use instead:

def my_function(a, my_arg):
    pass

docs.title: Options
docs.text:
• lint.pep8-naming.ignore-names
  • lint.pep8-naming.extend-ignore-names

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for invalid use of literals in assert message arguments.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: An assert message which is a non-string literal was likely intended to be used in a comparison assertion, rather than as a message.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
fruits = ["apples", "plums", "pears"]
fruits.filter(lambda fruit: fruit.startwith("p"))
assert len(fruits), 2  # True unless the list is empty

Use instead:

fruits = ["apples", "plums", "pears"]
fruits.filter(lambda fruit: fruit.startwith("p"))
assert len(fruits) == 2

docs.title: invalid-bool-return-type (PLE0304)
docs.text:
Derived from the Pylint linter.

This rule is unstable and in preview. The --preview flag is required for use.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for __bool__ implementations that return a type other than bool.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: The __bool__ method should return a bool object. Returning a different type may cause unexpected behavior.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
class Foo:
    def __bool__(self):
        return 2

Use instead:

class Foo:
    def __bool__(self):
        return True

docs.title: References
docs.text: • Python documentation: The __bool__ method

docs.title: invalid-bytes-return-type (PLE0308)
docs.text: Derived from the Pylint linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for __bytes__ implementations that return types other than bytes.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: The __bytes__ method should return a bytes object. Returning a different type may cause unexpected behavior.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
class Foo:
    def __bytes__(self):
        return 2

Use instead:

class Foo:
    def __bytes__(self):
        return b"2"

docs.title: References

docs.title: invalid-character-backspace (PLE2510)
docs.text:
Derived from the Pylint linter.

Fix is sometimes available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for strings that contain the control character BS.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
Control characters are displayed differently by different text editors and terminals.

By using the \b sequence in lieu of the BS control character, the string will contain the same value, but will render visibly in all editors.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
x = ""

Use instead:

x = "\b"

docs.title: Why is this bad?

By using the \x1b sequence in lieu of the ESC control character, the string will contain the same value, but will render visibly in all editors.

docs.text:

docs.title: Why is this bad?

docs.title: invalid-character-zero-width-space (PLE2515)
docs.text:
Derived from the Pylint linter.

Fix is sometimes available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for strings that contain the zero width space character.

docs.title: Why is this bad?

This character is rendered invisibly in some text editors and terminals.

docs.title: invalid-class-name (N801)
docs.text: Derived from the pep8-naming linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for class names that do not follow the CamelCase convention.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
PEP 8 recommends the use of the CapWords (or CamelCase) convention for class names:

Class names should normally use the CapWords convention.

The naming convention for functions may be used instead in cases where the interface is documented and used primarily as a callable.

Note that there is a separate convention for builtin names: most builtin names are single words (or two words run together), with the CapWords convention used only for exception names and builtin constants.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
class my_class:
    pass

Use instead:

class MyClass:
    pass

docs.title: Options
docs.text:
• lint.pep8-naming.ignore-names
  • lint.pep8-naming.extend-ignore-names

docs.title: invalid-envvar-default (PLW1508)
docs.text: Derived from the Pylint linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for os.getenv calls with invalid default values.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
If an environment variable is set, os.getenv will return its value as a string. If the environment variable is not set, os.getenv will return None, or the default value if one is provided.

If the default value is not a string or None, then it will be inconsistent with the return type of os.getenv, which can lead to confusing behavior.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
import os

int(os.getenv("FOO", 1))

Use instead:

import os

int(os.getenv("FOO", "1"))

docs.title: invalid-envvar-value (PLE1507)
docs.text: Derived from the Pylint linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for os.getenv calls with an invalid key argument.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
os.getenv only supports strings as the first argument (key).

If the provided argument is not a string, os.getenv will throw a TypeError at runtime.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
import os

os.getenv(1)

Use instead:

import os

os.getenv("1")

docs.title: invalid-escape-sequence (W605)
docs.text:
Derived from the pycodestyle linter.

Fix is always available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for invalid escape sequences.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: Invalid escape sequences are deprecated in Python 3.6.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
regex = "\.png$"

Use instead:

regex = r"\.png$"

Or, if the string already contains a valid escape sequence:

value = "new line\nand invalid escape \_ here"

Use instead:

value = "new line\nand invalid escape \\_ here"

docs.title: References
docs.text: • Python documentation: String and Bytes literals

docs.title: invalid-first-argument-name-for-class-method (N804)
docs.text:
Derived from the pep8-naming linter.

Fix is sometimes available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text:
Checks for class methods that use a name other than cls for their first argument.

The method __new__ is exempted from this check and the corresponding violation is caught by bad-staticmethod-argument.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
PEP 8 recommends the use of cls as the first argument for all class methods:

Always use cls for the first argument to class methods.

If a function argument’s name clashes with a reserved keyword, it is generally better to append a single trailing underscore rather than use an abbreviation or spelling corruption. Thus class_ is better than clss. (Perhaps better is to avoid such clashes by using a synonym.)

Names can be excluded from this rule using the lint.pep8-naming.ignore-names or lint.pep8-naming.extend-ignore-names configuration options. For example, to allow the use of klass as the first argument to class methods, set the lint.pep8-naming.extend-ignore-names option to ["klass"].

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
class Example:
    @classmethod
    def function(self, data): ...

Use instead:

class Example:
    @classmethod
    def function(cls, data): ...

docs.title: Fix safety
docs.text: This rule's fix is marked as unsafe, as renaming a method parameter can change the behavior of the program.

docs.title: Options
docs.text:

docs.text:
Derived from the pep8-naming linter.

docs.title: Why is this bad?

Always use self for the first argument to instance methods.

If a function argument’s name clashes with a reserved keyword, it is generally better to append a single trailing underscore rather than use an abbreviation or spelling corruption. Thus class_ is better than clss. (Perhaps better is to avoid such clashes by using a synonym.)

Names can be excluded from this rule using the lint.pep8-naming.ignore-names or lint.pep8-naming.extend-ignore-names configuration options. For example, to allow the use of this as the first argument to instance methods, set the lint.pep8-naming.extend-ignore-names option to ["this"].

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
class Example:
    def function(cls, data): ...

Use instead:

    def function(self, data): ...

docs.title: Fix safety
docs.text: This rule's fix is marked as unsafe, as renaming a method parameter can change the behavior of the program.

  • lint.pep8-naming.ignore-names
  • lint.pep8-naming.extend-ignore-names

docs.title: invalid-formatter-suppression-comment (RUF028)
docs.text: Fix is always available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for formatter suppression comments that are ineffective or incompatible with Ruff's formatter.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: Suppression comments that do not actually prevent formatting could cause unintended changes when the formatter is run.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
In the following example, all suppression comments would cause a rule violation.

def decorator():
    pass


@decorator
# fmt: off
def example():
    if True:
        # fmt: skip
        expression = [
            # fmt: off
            1,
            2,
        ]
        # yapf: disable
    # fmt: on
    # yapf: enable

docs.title: Fix safety
docs.text: This fix is always marked as unsafe because it deletes the invalid suppression comment, rather than trying to move it to a valid position, which the user more likely intended.

docs.title: invalid-function-name (N802)
docs.text: Derived from the pep8-naming linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for functions names that do not follow the snake_case naming convention.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
PEP 8 recommends that function names follow snake_case:

Function names should be lowercase, with words separated by underscores as necessary to improve readability. mixedCase is allowed only in contexts where that’s already the prevailing style (e.g. threading.py), to retain backwards compatibility.

Names can be excluded from this rule using the lint.pep8-naming.ignore-names or lint.pep8-naming.extend-ignore-names configuration options. For example, to ignore all functions starting with test_ from this rule, set the lint.pep8-naming.extend-ignore-names option to ["test_*"].

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
def myFunction():
    pass

Use instead:

def my_function():
    pass

docs.title: Options
docs.text:
• lint.pep8-naming.ignore-names
  • lint.pep8-naming.extend-ignore-names

docs.title: invalid-get-logger-argument (LOG002)
docs.text:
Derived from the flake8-logging linter.

Fix is sometimes available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for any usage of __cached__ and __file__ as an argument to logging.getLogger().

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
The logging documentation recommends this pattern:

logging.getLogger(__name__)

Here, __name__ is the fully qualified module name, such as foo.bar, which is the intended format for logger names.

This rule detects probably-mistaken usage of similar module-level dunder constants:

  • __cached__ - the pathname of the module's compiled version, such as foo/__pycache__/bar.cpython-311.pyc.
  • __file__ - the pathname of the module, such as foo/bar.py.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
import logging

logger = logging.getLogger(__file__)

Use instead:

import logging

logger = logging.getLogger(__name__)

docs.title: Fix safety
docs.text: This fix is always unsafe, as changing the arguments to getLogger can change the received logger object, and thus program behavior.

docs.title: invalid-hash-return-type (PLE0309)
docs.text: Derived from the Pylint linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for __hash__ implementations that return non-integer values.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
The __hash__ method should return an integer. Returning a different type may cause unexpected behavior.

Note: bool is a subclass of int, so it's technically valid for __hash__ to return True or False. However, for consistency with other rules, Ruff will still emit a diagnostic when __hash__ returns a bool.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
class Foo:
    def __hash__(self):
        return "2"

Use instead:

class Foo:
    def __hash__(self):
        return 2

docs.title: References
docs.text: • Python documentation: The __hash__ method

docs.title: invalid-index-return-type (PLE0305)
docs.text: Derived from the Pylint linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for __index__ implementations that return non-integer values.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
The __index__ method should return an integer. Returning a different type may cause unexpected behavior.

Note: bool is a subclass of int, so it's technically valid for __index__ to return True or False. However, a DeprecationWarning (DeprecationWarning: __index__ returned non-int (type bool)) for such cases was already introduced, thus this is a conscious difference between the original pylint rule and the current ruff implementation.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
class Foo:
    def __index__(self):
        return "2"

Use instead:

class Foo:
    def __index__(self):
        return 2

docs.title: References
docs.text: • Python documentation: The __index__ method

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for indexed access to lists, strings, tuples, bytes, and comprehensions using a type other than an integer or slice.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: Only integers or slices can be used as indices to these types. Using other types will result in a TypeError at runtime and a SyntaxWarning at import time.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
var = [1, 2, 3]["x"]

Use instead:

var = [1, 2, 3][0]

docs.title: invalid-length-return-type (PLE0303)
docs.text: Derived from the Pylint linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for __len__ implementations that return values that are not non-negative integers.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
The __len__ method should return a non-negative integer. Returning a different value may cause unexpected behavior.

Note: bool is a subclass of int, so it's technically valid for __len__ to return True or False. However, for consistency with other rules, Ruff will still emit a diagnostic when __len__ returns a bool.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
class Foo:
    def __len__(self):
        return "2"

Use instead:

class Foo:
    def __len__(self):
        return 2

docs.title: References
docs.text: • Python documentation: The __len__ method

docs.title: invalid-mock-access (PGH005)
docs.text: Derived from the pygrep-hooks linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for common mistakes when using mock objects.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
The mock module exposes an assertion API that can be used to verify that mock objects undergo expected interactions. This rule checks for common mistakes when using this API.

For example, it checks for mock attribute accesses that should be replaced with mock method calls.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
my_mock.assert_called

Use instead:

my_mock.assert_called()

docs.title: invalid-module-name (N999)
docs.text: Derived from the pep8-naming linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for module names that do not follow the snake_case naming convention or are otherwise invalid.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
PEP 8 recommends the use of the snake_case naming convention for module names:

Modules should have short, all-lowercase names. Underscores can be used in the module name if it improves readability. Python packages should also have short, all-lowercase names, although the use of underscores is discouraged.

When an extension module written in C or C++ has an accompanying Python module that provides a higher level (e.g. more object-oriented) interface, the C/C++ module has a leading underscore (e.g. _socket).

Further, in order for Python modules to be importable, they must be valid identifiers. As such, they cannot start with a digit, or collide with hard keywords, like import or class.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
• Instead of example-module-name or example module name, use example_module_name.
  • Instead of ExampleModule, use example_module.

docs.title: invalid-pathlib-with-suffix (PTH210)
docs.text:
Derived from the flake8-use-pathlib linter.

Fix is sometimes available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for pathlib.Path.with_suffix() calls where the given suffix does not have a leading dot or the given suffix is a single dot "." and the Python version is less than 3.14.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: Path.with_suffix() will raise an error at runtime if the given suffix is not prefixed with a dot or, in versions prior to Python 3.14, if it is a single dot ".".

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
from pathlib import Path

path = Path()

path.with_suffix("py")

Use instead:

from pathlib import Path

path = Path()

path.with_suffix(".py")

docs.title: Known problems
docs.text: This rule is likely to have false negatives, as Ruff can only emit the lint if it can say for sure that a binding refers to a Path object at runtime. Due to type inference limitations, Ruff is currently only confident about this if it can see that the binding originates from a function parameter annotated with Path or from a direct assignment to a Path() constructor call.

docs.title: Fix safety
docs.text:
The fix for this rule adds a leading period to the string passed to the with_suffix() call. This fix is marked as unsafe, as it changes runtime behaviour: the call would previously always have raised an exception, but no longer will.

Moreover, it's impossible to determine if this is the correct fix for a given situation (it's possible that the string was correct but was being passed to the wrong method entirely, for example).

No fix is offered if the suffix "." is given, since the intent is unclear.

docs.title: invalid-print-syntax (F633)
docs.text: Derived from the Pyflakes linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for print statements that use the >> syntax.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
In Python 2, the print statement can be used with the >> syntax to print to a file-like object. This print >> sys.stderr syntax no longer exists in Python 3, where print is only a function, not a statement.

Instead, use the file keyword argument to the print function, the sys.stderr.write function, or the logging module.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
from __future__ import print_function
import sys

print >> sys.stderr, "Hello, world!"

Use instead:

print("Hello, world!", file=sys.stderr)

Or:

import sys

sys.stderr.write("Hello, world!\n")

Or:

import logging

logging.error("Hello, world!")

docs.title: References
docs.text: • Python documentation: print

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for any pyproject.toml that does not conform to the schema from the relevant PEPs.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: Your project may contain invalid metadata or configuration without you noticing

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
[project]
name = "crab"
version = "1.0.0"
authors = ["Ferris the Crab <ferris@example.org>"]

Use instead:

[project]
name = "crab"
version = "1.0.0"
authors = [
  { name = "Ferris the Crab", email = "ferris@example.org" }
]

docs.title: References
docs.text:
• Specification of [project] in pyproject.toml
  • Specification of [build-system] in pyproject.toml
  • Draft but implemented license declaration extensions

docs.title: invalid-rule-code (RUF102)
docs.text:
Fix is always available.

This rule is unstable and in preview. The --preview flag is required for use.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for noqa codes that are invalid.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: Invalid rule codes serve no purpose and may indicate outdated code suppressions.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
import os  # noqa: XYZ999

Use instead:

import os

Or if there are still valid codes needed:

import os  # noqa: E402

docs.title: Options
docs.text: • lint.external

docs.title: invalid-str-return-type (PLE0307)
docs.text: Derived from the Pylint linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for __str__ implementations that return a type other than str.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: The __str__ method should return a str object. Returning a different type may cause unexpected behavior.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
class Foo:
    def __str__(self):
        return True

Use instead:

class Foo:
    def __str__(self):
        return "Foo"

docs.title: References
docs.text: • Python documentation: The __str__ method

docs.title: invalid-todo-capitalization (TD006)
docs.text:
Derived from the flake8-todos linter.

Fix is always available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks that a "TODO" tag is properly capitalized (i.e., that the tag is uppercase).

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: Capitalizing the "TODO" in a TODO comment is a convention that makes it easier for future readers to identify TODOs.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
# todo(charlie): capitalize this

Use instead:

# TODO(charlie): this is capitalized

docs.title: invalid-todo-tag (TD001)
docs.text: Derived from the flake8-todos linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks that a TODO comment is labelled with "TODO".

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
Ambiguous tags reduce code visibility and can lead to dangling TODOs. For example, if a comment is tagged with "FIXME" rather than "TODO", it may be overlooked by future readers.

Note that this rule will only flag "FIXME" and "XXX" tags as incorrect.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
# FIXME(ruff): this should get fixed!

Use instead:

# TODO(ruff): this is now fixed!

docs.title: io-error (E902)
docs.text: Derived from the pycodestyle linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: This is not a regular diagnostic; instead, it's raised when a file cannot be read from disk.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: An IOError indicates an error in the development setup. For example, the user may not have permissions to read a given file, or the filesystem may contain a broken symlink.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
On Linux or macOS:

$ echo 'print("hello world!")' > a.py
$ chmod 000 a.py
$ ruff a.py
a.py:1:1: E902 Permission denied (os error 13)
Found 1 error.

docs.title: References
docs.text:
• UNIX Permissions introduction
  • Command Line Basics: Symbolic Links

docs.title: is-literal (F632)
docs.text:
Derived from the Pyflakes linter.

Fix is always available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for is and is not comparisons against literals, like integers, strings, or lists.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
The is and is not comparators operate on identity, in that they check whether two objects are the same object. If the objects are not the same object, the comparison will always be False. Using is and is not with constant literals often works "by accident", but are not guaranteed to produce the expected result.

As of Python 3.8, using is and is not with constant literals will produce a SyntaxWarning.

This rule will also flag is and is not comparisons against non-constant literals, like lists, sets, and dictionaries. While such comparisons will not raise a SyntaxWarning, they are still likely to be incorrect, as they will compare the identities of the objects instead of their values, which will always evaluate to False.

Instead, use == and != to compare literals, which will compare the values of the objects instead of their identities.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
x = 200
if x is 200:
    print("It's 200!")

Use instead:

x = 200
if x == 200:
    print("It's 200!")

docs.title: References
docs.text:
• Python documentation: Identity comparisons
  • Python documentation: Value comparisons
  • Why does Python log a SyntaxWarning for ‘is’ with literals? by Adam Johnson

docs.title: isinstance-type-none (FURB168)
docs.text:
Derived from the refurb linter.

Fix is sometimes available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for uses of isinstance that check if an object is of type None.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: There is only ever one instance of None, so it is more efficient and readable to use the is operator to check if an object is None.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
isinstance(obj, type(None))

Use instead:

obj is None

docs.title: Fix safety
docs.text: The fix will be marked as unsafe if there are any comments within the call.

docs.title: References
docs.text:
• Python documentation: isinstance
  • Python documentation: None
  • Python documentation: type
  • Python documentation: Identity comparisons

docs.title: iter-method-return-iterable (PYI045)
docs.text: Derived from the flake8-pyi linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for __iter__ methods in stubs that return Iterable[T] instead of an Iterator[T].

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
__iter__ methods should always should return an Iterator of some kind, not an Iterable.

In Python, an Iterable is an object that has an __iter__ method; an Iterator is an object that has __iter__ and __next__ methods. All __iter__ methods are expected to return Iterators. Type checkers may not always recognize an object as being iterable if its __iter__ method does not return an Iterator.

Every Iterator is an Iterable, but not every Iterable is an Iterator. For example, list is an Iterable, but not an Iterator; you can obtain an iterator over a list's elements by passing the list to iter():

>>> import collections.abc
>>> x = [42]
>>> isinstance(x, collections.abc.Iterable)
True
>>> isinstance(x, collections.abc.Iterator)
False
>>> next(x)
Traceback (most recent call last):
 File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
TypeError: 'list' object is not an iterator
>>> y = iter(x)
>>> isinstance(y, collections.abc.Iterable)
True
>>> isinstance(y, collections.abc.Iterator)
True
>>> next(y)
42

Using Iterable rather than Iterator as a return type for an __iter__ methods would imply that you would not necessarily be able to call next() on the returned object, violating the expectations of the interface.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
import collections.abc


class Klass:
    def __iter__(self) -> collections.abc.Iterable[str]: ...

Use instead:

import collections.abc


class Klass:
    def __iter__(self) -> collections.abc.Iterator[str]: ...

docs.title: iteration-over-set (PLC0208)
docs.text:
Derived from the Pylint linter.

Fix is always available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for iteration over a set literal where each element in the set is itself a literal value.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: Iterating over a set is less efficient than iterating over a sequence type, like list or tuple.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
for number in {1, 2, 3}:
    ...

Use instead:

for number in (1, 2, 3):
    ...

docs.title: References
docs.text: • Python documentation: set

docs.title: jinja2-autoescape-false (S701)
docs.text: Derived from the flake8-bandit linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for jinja2 templates that use autoescape=False.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
jinja2 templates that use autoescape=False are vulnerable to cross-site scripting (XSS) attacks that allow attackers to execute arbitrary JavaScript.

By default, jinja2 sets autoescape to False, so it is important to set autoescape=True or use the select_autoescape function to mitigate XSS vulnerabilities.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
import jinja2

jinja2.Environment(loader=jinja2.FileSystemLoader("."))

Use instead:

import jinja2

jinja2.Environment(loader=jinja2.FileSystemLoader("."), autoescape=True)

docs.title: References
docs.text:
• Jinja documentation: API
  • Common Weakness Enumeration: CWE-94

docs.title: jump-statement-in-finally (B012)
docs.text: Derived from the flake8-bugbear linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for break, continue, and return statements in finally blocks.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
The use of break, continue, and return statements in finally blocks can cause exceptions to be silenced.

finally blocks execute regardless of whether an exception is raised. If a break, continue, or return statement is reached in a finally block, any exception raised in the try or except blocks will be silenced.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
def speed(distance, time):
    try:
        return distance / time
    except ZeroDivisionError:
        raise ValueError("Time cannot be zero")
    finally:
        return 299792458  # `ValueError` is silenced

Use instead:

def speed(distance, time):
    try:
        return distance / time
    except ZeroDivisionError:
        raise ValueError("Time cannot be zero")

docs.title: References
docs.text: • Python documentation: The try statement

docs.title: lambda-assignment (E731)
docs.text:
Derived from the pycodestyle linter.

Fix is sometimes available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for lambda expressions which are assigned to a variable.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
Per PEP 8, you should "Always use a def statement instead of an assignment statement that binds a lambda expression directly to an identifier."

Using a def statement leads to better tracebacks, and the assignment itself negates the primary benefit of using a lambda expression (i.e., that it can be embedded inside another expression).

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
f = lambda x: 2 * x

Use instead:

def f(x):
    return 2 * x

docs.title: late-future-import (F404)
docs.text: Derived from the Pyflakes linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for __future__ imports that are not located at the beginning of a file.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: Imports from __future__ must be placed the beginning of the file, before any other statements (apart from docstrings). The use of __future__ imports elsewhere is invalid and will result in a SyntaxError.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
from pathlib import Path

from __future__ import annotations

Use instead:

from __future__ import annotations

from pathlib import Path

docs.title: References
docs.text: • Python documentation: Future statements

docs.title: legacy-form-pytest-raises (RUF061)
docs.text:
Fix is sometimes available.

This rule is unstable and in preview. The --preview flag is required for use.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for non-contextmanager use of pytest.raises, pytest.warns, and pytest.deprecated_call.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: The context-manager form is more readable, easier to extend, and supports additional kwargs.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
import pytest


excinfo = pytest.raises(ValueError, int, "hello")
pytest.warns(UserWarning, my_function, arg)
pytest.deprecated_call(my_deprecated_function, arg1, arg2)

Use instead:

import pytest


with pytest.raises(ValueError) as excinfo:
    int("hello")
with pytest.warns(UserWarning):
    my_function(arg)
with pytest.deprecated_call():
    my_deprecated_function(arg1, arg2)

docs.title: References
docs.text:
• pytest documentation: pytest.raises
  • pytest documentation: pytest.warns
  • pytest documentation: pytest.deprecated_call

docs.title: len-test (PLC1802)
docs.text:
Derived from the Pylint linter.

Fix is always available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for len calls on sequences in a boolean test context.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: Empty sequences are considered false in a boolean context. You can either remove the call to len or compare the length against a scalar.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
fruits = ["orange", "apple"]
vegetables = []

if len(fruits):
    print(fruits)

if not len(vegetables):
    print(vegetables)

Use instead:

fruits = ["orange", "apple"]
vegetables = []

if fruits:
    print(fruits)

if not vegetables:
    print(vegetables)

docs.title: Fix safety
docs.text:
This rule's fix is marked as unsafe when the len call includes a comment, as the comment would be removed.

For example, the fix would be marked as unsafe in the following case:

fruits = []
if len(
    fruits  # comment
):
    ...

docs.title: References
docs.text: PEP 8: Programming Recommendations

docs.title: line-contains-fixme (FIX001)
docs.text: Derived from the flake8-fixme linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for "FIXME" comments.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
"FIXME" comments are used to describe an issue that should be resolved (usually, a bug or unexpected behavior).

Consider resolving the issue before deploying the code.

Note that if you use "FIXME" comments as a form of documentation, this rule may not be appropriate for your project.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
def speed(distance, time):
    return distance / time  # FIXME: Raises ZeroDivisionError for time = 0.

docs.title: line-contains-hack (FIX004)
docs.text: Derived from the flake8-fixme linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for "HACK" comments.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
"HACK" comments are used to describe an issue that should be resolved (usually, a suboptimal solution or temporary workaround).

Consider resolving the issue before deploying the code.

Note that if you use "HACK" comments as a form of documentation, this rule may not be appropriate for your project.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
import os


def running_windows():  # HACK: Use platform module instead.
    try:
        os.mkdir("C:\\Windows\\System32\\")
    except FileExistsError:
        return True
    else:
        os.rmdir("C:\\Windows\\System32\\")
        return False

docs.title: line-contains-todo (FIX002)
docs.text: Derived from the flake8-fixme linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for "TODO" comments.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
"TODO" comments are used to describe an issue that should be resolved (usually, a missing feature, optimization, or refactoring opportunity).

Consider resolving the issue before deploying the code.

Note that if you use "TODO" comments as a form of documentation (e.g., to provide context for future work), this rule may not be appropriate for your project.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
def greet(name):
    return f"Hello, {name}!"  # TODO: Add support for custom greetings.

docs.title: line-contains-xxx (FIX003)
docs.text: Derived from the flake8-fixme linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for "XXX" comments.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
"XXX" comments are used to describe an issue that should be resolved.

Consider resolving the issue before deploying the code, or, at minimum, using a more descriptive comment tag (e.g, "TODO").

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
def speed(distance, time):
    return distance / time  # XXX: Raises ZeroDivisionError for time = 0.

docs.title: line-too-long (E501)
docs.text: Derived from the pycodestyle linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for lines that exceed the specified maximum character length.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
Overlong lines can hurt readability. PEP 8, for example, recommends limiting lines to 79 characters. By default, this rule enforces a limit of 88 characters for compatibility with Black and the Ruff formatter, though that limit is configurable via the line-length setting.

In the interest of pragmatism, this rule makes a few exceptions when determining whether a line is overlong. Namely, it:

  1. Ignores lines that consist of a single "word" (i.e., without any whitespace between its characters).
  2. Ignores lines that end with a URL, as long as the URL starts before the line-length threshold.
  3. Ignores line that end with a pragma comment (e.g., # type: ignore or # noqa), as long as the pragma comment starts before the line-length threshold. That is, a line will not be flagged as overlong if a pragma comment causes it to exceed the line length. (This behavior aligns with that of the Ruff formatter.)
  4. Ignores SPDX license identifiers and copyright notices (e.g., # SPDX-License-Identifier: MIT), which are machine-readable and should not wrap over multiple lines.

If lint.pycodestyle.ignore-overlong-task-comments is true, this rule will also ignore comments that start with any of the specified lint.task-tags (e.g., # TODO:).

docs.title: list-reverse-copy (FURB187)
docs.text:
Derived from the refurb linter.

Fix is always available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for list reversals that can be performed in-place in lieu of creating a new list.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: When reversing a list, it's more efficient to use the in-place method .reverse() instead of creating a new list, if the original list is no longer needed.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
l = [1, 2, 3]
l = reversed(l)

l = [1, 2, 3]
l = list(reversed(l))

l = [1, 2, 3]
l = l[::-1]

Use instead:

l = [1, 2, 3]
l.reverse()

docs.title: Fix safety
docs.text:
This rule's fix is marked as unsafe, as calling .reverse() on a list will mutate the list in-place, unlike reversed, which creates a new list and leaves the original list unchanged.

If the list is referenced elsewhere, this could lead to unexpected behavior.

docs.title: logging-exc-info (G201)
docs.text: Derived from the flake8-logging-format linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for uses of logging.error that pass exc_info=True.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: Calling logging.error with exc_info=True is equivalent to calling logging.exception. Using logging.exception is more concise, more readable, and conveys the intent of the logging statement more clearly.

docs.title: Known problems
docs.text:
This rule detects uses of the logging module via a heuristic. Specifically, it matches against:

  • Uses of the logging module itself (e.g., import logging; logging.info(...)).
  • Uses of flask.current_app.logger (e.g., from flask import current_app; current_app.logger.info(...)).
  • Objects whose name starts with log or ends with logger or logging, when used in the same file in which they are defined (e.g., logger = logging.getLogger(); logger.info(...)).
  • Imported objects marked as loggers via the lint.logger-objects setting, which can be used to enforce these rules against shared logger objects (e.g., from module import logger; logger.info(...), when lint.logger-objects is set to ["module.logger"]).

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
import logging

try:
    ...
except ValueError:
    logging.error("Exception occurred", exc_info=True)

Use instead:

import logging

try:
    ...
except ValueError:
    logging.exception("Exception occurred")

docs.title: logging-f-string (G004)
docs.text:
Derived from the flake8-logging-format linter.

Fix is sometimes available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for uses of f-strings to format logging messages.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
The logging module provides a mechanism for passing additional values to be logged using the extra keyword argument. This is more consistent, more efficient, and less error-prone than formatting the string directly.

Using f-strings to format a logging message requires that Python eagerly format the string, even if the logging statement is never executed (e.g., if the log level is above the level of the logging statement), whereas using the extra keyword argument defers formatting until required.

Additionally, the use of extra will ensure that the values are made available to all handlers, which can then be configured to log the values in a consistent manner.

As an alternative to extra, passing values as arguments to the logging method can also be used to defer string formatting until required.

docs.text: Checks for the use of unnamed numerical constants ("magic") values in comparisons.

docs.text:
The use of "magic" values can make code harder to read and maintain, as readers will have to infer the meaning of the value from the context. Such values are discouraged by PEP 8.

For convenience, this rule excludes a variety of common values from the "magic" value definition, such as 0, 1, "", and "__main__".

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
def apply_discount(price: float) -> float:
    if price <= 100:
        return price / 2
    else:
        return price

Use instead:

MAX_DISCOUNT = 100


def apply_discount(price: float) -> float:
    if price <= MAX_DISCOUNT:
        return price / 2
    else:
        return price

docs.text: • lint.pylint.allow-magic-value-types

docs.title: mako-templates (S702)
docs.text: Derived from the flake8-bandit linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for uses of the mako templates.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: Mako templates allow HTML and JavaScript rendering by default, and are inherently open to XSS attacks. Ensure variables in all templates are properly sanitized via the n, h or x flags (depending on context). For example, to HTML escape the variable data, use ${ data |h }.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
from mako.template import Template

Template("hello")

Use instead:

from mako.template import Template

Template("hello |h")

docs.title: manual-dict-comprehension (PERF403)
docs.text:
Derived from the Perflint linter.

Fix is sometimes available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for for loops that can be replaced by a dictionary comprehension.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
When creating or extending a dictionary in a for-loop, prefer a dictionary comprehension. Comprehensions are more readable and more performant.

For example, when comparing {x: x for x in list(range(1000))} to the for loop version, the comprehension is ~10% faster on Python 3.11.

Note that, as with all perflint rules, this is only intended as a micro-optimization, and will have a negligible impact on performance in most cases.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
pairs = (("a", 1), ("b", 2))
result = {}
for x, y in pairs:
    if y % 2:
        result[x] = y

Use instead:

pairs = (("a", 1), ("b", 2))
result = {x: y for x, y in pairs if y % 2}

If you're appending to an existing dictionary, use the update method instead:

pairs = (("a", 1), ("b", 2))
result.update({x: y for x, y in pairs if y % 2})

docs.title: Why is this bad?

Use instead:

docs.title: manual-list-comprehension (PERF401)
docs.text:
Derived from the Perflint linter.

Fix is sometimes available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for for loops that can be replaced by a list comprehension.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
When creating a transformed list from an existing list using a for-loop, prefer a list comprehension. List comprehensions are more readable and more performant.

Using the below as an example, the list comprehension is ~10% faster on Python 3.11, and ~25% faster on Python 3.10.

Note that, as with all perflint rules, this is only intended as a micro-optimization, and will have a negligible impact on performance in most cases.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
original = list(range(10000))
filtered = []
for i in original:
    if i % 2:
        filtered.append(i)

Use instead:

original = list(range(10000))
filtered = [x for x in original if x % 2]

If you're appending to an existing list, use the extend method instead:

original = list(range(10000))
filtered.extend(x for x in original if x % 2)

docs.title: manual-list-copy (PERF402)
docs.text: Derived from the Perflint linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for for loops that can be replaced by a making a copy of a list.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
When creating a copy of an existing list using a for-loop, prefer list or list.copy instead. Making a direct copy is more readable and more performant.

Using the below as an example, the list-based copy is ~2x faster on Python 3.11.

Note that, as with all perflint rules, this is only intended as a micro-optimization, and will have a negligible impact on performance in most cases.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
original = list(range(10000))
filtered = []
for i in original:
    filtered.append(i)

Use instead:

original = list(range(10000))
filtered = list(original)

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for calls of the form map(int, __version__.split(".")).

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
__version__ does not always contain integral-like elements.

import matplotlib  # `__version__ == "3.9.1.post-1"` in our environment

# ValueError: invalid literal for int() with base 10: 'post1'
tuple(map(int, matplotlib.__version__.split(".")))

See also Version specifiers | Packaging spec.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
tuple(map(int, matplotlib.__version__.split(".")))

Use instead:

import packaging.version as version

version.parse(matplotlib.__version__)

docs.title: meta-class-abc-meta (FURB180)
docs.text:
Derived from the refurb linter.

Fix is always available.

This rule is unstable and in preview. The --preview flag is required for use.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for uses of metaclass=abc.ABCMeta to define abstract base classes (ABCs).

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: Instead of class C(metaclass=abc.ABCMeta): ..., use class C(ABC): ... to define an abstract base class. Inheriting from the ABC wrapper class is semantically identical to setting metaclass=abc.ABCMeta, but more succinct.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
import abc


class C(metaclass=abc.ABCMeta):
    pass

Use instead:

import abc


class C(abc.ABC):
    pass

docs.title: Fix safety
docs.text: The rule's fix is unsafe if the class has base classes. This is because the base classes might be validating the class's other base classes (e.g., typing.Protocol does this) or otherwise alter runtime behavior if more base classes are added.

docs.title: mismatched-section-underline-length (D409)
docs.text:
Derived from the pydocstyle linter.

Fix is always available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for section underlines in docstrings that do not match the length of the corresponding section header.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
This rule enforces a consistent style for multiline numpy-style docstrings, and helps prevent incorrect syntax in docstrings using reStructuredText.

Multiline numpy-style docstrings are typically composed of a summary line, followed by a blank line, followed by a series of sections. Each section has a section header and a section body, and there should be a series of underline characters in the line following the header. The length of the underline should exactly match the length of the section header.

This rule enforces a consistent style for multiline numpy-style docstrings with sections. If your docstring uses reStructuredText, the rule also helps protect against incorrect reStructuredText syntax, which would cause errors if you tried to use a tool such as Sphinx to generate documentation from the docstring.

This rule is enabled when using the numpy convention, and disabled when using the google or pep257 conventions.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
def calculate_speed(distance: float, time: float) -> float:
    """Calculate speed as distance divided by time.

    Parameters
    ---
    distance : float
        Distance traveled.
    time : float
        Time spent traveling.

    Returns
    ---
    float
        Speed as distance divided by time.

    Raises
    ---
    FasterThanLightError
        If speed is greater than the speed of light.
    """
    try:
        return distance / time
    except ZeroDivisionError as exc:
        raise FasterThanLightError from exc

Use instead:

def calculate_speed(distance: float, time: float) -> float:
    """Calculate speed as distance divided by time.

    Parameters
    ----------
    distance : float
        Distance traveled.
    time : float
        Time spent traveling.

    Returns
    -------
    float
        Speed as distance divided by time.

    Raises
    ------
    FasterThanLightError
        If speed is greater than the speed of light.
    """
    try:
        return distance / time
    except ZeroDivisionError as exc:
        raise FasterThanLightError from exc

docs.title: misplaced-bare-raise (PLE0704)
docs.text: Derived from the Pylint linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for bare raise statements outside of exception handlers.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
A bare raise statement without an exception object will re-raise the last exception that was active in the current scope, and is typically used within an exception handler to re-raise the caught exception.

If a bare raise is used outside of an exception handler, it will generate an error due to the lack of an active exception.

Note that a bare raise within a finally block will work in some cases (namely, when the exception is raised within the try block), but should be avoided as it can lead to confusing behavior.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
from typing import Any


def is_some(obj: Any) -> bool:
    if obj is None:
        raise

Use instead:

from typing import Any


def is_some(obj: Any) -> bool:
    if obj is None:
        raise ValueError("`obj` cannot be `None`")

docs.title: missing-f-string-syntax (RUF027)
docs.text:
Fix is always available.

This rule is unstable and in preview. The --preview flag is required for use.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Searches for strings that look like they were meant to be f-strings, but are missing an f prefix.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: Expressions inside curly braces are only evaluated if the string has an f prefix.

docs.title: Details
docs.text:
There are many possible string literals which are not meant to be f-strings despite containing f-string-like syntax. As such, this lint ignores all strings where one of the following conditions applies:

  1. The string is a standalone expression. For example, the rule ignores all docstrings.
  2. The string is part of a function call with argument names that match at least one variable (for example: format("Message: {value}", value="Hello World"))
  3. The string (or a parent expression of the string) has a direct method call on it (for example: "{value}".format(...))
  4. The string has no {...} expression sections, or uses invalid f-string syntax.
  5. The string references variables that are not in scope, or it doesn't capture variables at all.
  6. Any format specifiers in the potential f-string are invalid.
  7. The string is part of a function call that is known to expect a template string rather than an evaluated f-string: for example, a logging call, a gettext call, or a FastAPI path.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
name = "Sarah"
day_of_week = "Tuesday"
print("Hello {name}! It is {day_of_week} today!")

Use instead:

name = "Sarah"
day_of_week = "Tuesday"
print(f"Hello {name}! It is {day_of_week} today!")

docs.title: Fix safety
docs.text: This fix will always change the behavior of the program and, despite the precautions detailed above, this may be undesired. As such the fix is always marked as unsafe.

docs.title: missing-maxsplit-arg (PLC0207)
docs.text:
Derived from the Pylint linter.

Fix is always available.

This rule is unstable and in preview. The --preview flag is required for use.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for access to the first or last element of str.split() or str.rsplit() without maxsplit=1

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: Calling str.split() or str.rsplit() without passing maxsplit=1 splits on every delimiter in the string. When accessing only the first or last element of the result, it would be more efficient to only split once.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
url = "www.example.com"
prefix = url.split(".")[0]

Use instead:

url = "www.example.com"
prefix = url.split(".", maxsplit=1)[0]

To access the last element, use str.rsplit() instead of str.split():

url = "www.example.com"
suffix = url.rsplit(".", maxsplit=1)[-1]

docs.title: Fix Safety
docs.text: This rule's fix is marked as unsafe for split()/rsplit() calls that contain *args or **kwargs arguments, as adding a maxsplit argument to such a call may lead to duplicated arguments.

docs.title: missing-new-line-after-section-name (D406)
docs.text:
Derived from the pydocstyle linter.

Fix is always available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for section headers in docstrings that are followed by non-newline characters.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
This rule enforces a consistent style for multiline numpy-style docstrings.

Multiline numpy-style docstrings are typically composed of a summary line, followed by a blank line, followed by a series of sections. Each section has a section header and a section body. The section header should be followed by a newline, rather than by some other character (like a colon).

This rule is enabled when using the numpy convention, and disabled when using the google or pep257 conventions.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
# The `Parameters`, `Returns` and `Raises` section headers are all followed
# by a colon in this function's docstring:
def calculate_speed(distance: float, time: float) -> float:
    """Calculate speed as distance divided by time.

    Parameters:
    -----------
    distance : float
        Distance traveled.
    time : float
        Time spent traveling.

    Returns:
    --------
    float
        Speed as distance divided by time.

    Raises:
    -------
    FasterThanLightError
        If speed is greater than the speed of light.
    """
    try:
        return distance / time
    except ZeroDivisionError as exc:
        raise FasterThanLightError from exc

Use instead:

def calculate_speed(distance: float, time: float) -> float:
    """Calculate speed as distance divided by time.

    Parameters

    time : float
        Time spent traveling.

docs.title: missing-return-type-class-method (ANN206)
docs.text:
Derived from the flake8-annotations linter.

Fix is sometimes available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks that class methods have return type annotations.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: Type annotations are a good way to document the return types of functions. They also help catch bugs, when used alongside a type checker, by ensuring that the types of any returned values, and the types expected by callers, match expectation.

docs.text:
class Foo:
    @classmethod
    def bar(cls):
        return 1

Use instead:

class Foo:

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks that "special" methods, like __init__, __new__, and __call__, have return type annotations.

docs.title: missing-section-name-colon (D416)
docs.text:
Derived from the pydocstyle linter.

Fix is always available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for docstring section headers that do not end with a colon.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
This rule enforces a consistent style for multiline Google-style docstrings. If a multiline Google-style docstring consists of multiple sections, each section header should end with a colon.

Multiline docstrings are typically composed of a summary line, followed by a blank line, followed by a series of sections, each with a section header and a section body.

This rule is enabled when using the google convention, and disabled when using the pep257 and numpy conventions.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
def calculate_speed(distance: float, time: float) -> float:
    """Calculate speed as distance divided by time.

    Args
        distance: Distance traveled.
        time: Time spent traveling.

    Returns
        Speed as distance divided by time.

    Raises
        FasterThanLightError: If speed is greater than the speed of light.
    """
    try:
        return distance / time
    except ZeroDivisionError as exc:
        raise FasterThanLightError from exc

Use instead:

def calculate_speed(distance: float, time: float) -> float:
    """Calculate speed as distance divided by time.

    Args:
        distance: Distance traveled.
        time: Time spent traveling.

    Returns:
        Speed as distance divided by time.

    Raises:
        FasterThanLightError: If speed is greater than the speed of light.
    """
    try:
        return distance / time
    except ZeroDivisionError as exc:
        raise FasterThanLightError from exc

docs.title: missing-section-underline-after-name (D408)
docs.text:
Derived from the pydocstyle linter.

Fix is always available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for section underlines in docstrings that are not on the line immediately following the section name.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
This rule enforces a consistent style for multiline numpy-style docstrings, and helps prevent incorrect syntax in docstrings using reStructuredText.

Multiline numpy-style docstrings are typically composed of a summary line, followed by a blank line, followed by a series of sections. Each section has a header and a body. There should be a series of underline characters in the line immediately below the header.

This rule enforces a consistent style for multiline numpy-style docstrings with sections. If your docstring uses reStructuredText, the rule also helps protect against incorrect reStructuredText syntax, which would cause errors if you tried to use a tool such as Sphinx to generate documentation from the docstring.

This rule is enabled when using the numpy convention, and disabled when using the google or pep257 conventions.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
def calculate_speed(distance: float, time: float) -> float:
    """Calculate speed as distance divided by time.

    Parameters

    ----------
    distance : float
        Distance traveled.
    time : float
        Time spent traveling.

    Returns

    -------
    float
        Speed as distance divided by time.

    Raises

    ------
    FasterThanLightError
        If speed is greater than the speed of light.
    """
    try:
        return distance / time
    except ZeroDivisionError as exc:
        raise FasterThanLightError from exc

Use instead:

def calculate_speed(distance: float, time: float) -> float:
    """Calculate speed as distance divided by time.

    Parameters
    ----------
    distance : float
        Distance traveled.
    time : float
        Time spent traveling.

    Returns
    -------
    float
        Speed as distance divided by time.

    Raises
    ------
    FasterThanLightError
        If speed is greater than the speed of light.
    """
    try:
        return distance / time
    except ZeroDivisionError as exc:
        raise FasterThanLightError from exc

docs.title: missing-space-after-todo-colon (TD007)
docs.text: Derived from the flake8-todos linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks that the colon after a "TODO" tag is followed by a space.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
"TODO" tags are typically followed by a parenthesized author name, a colon, a space, and a description of the issue, in that order.

Deviating from this pattern can lead to inconsistent and non-idiomatic comments.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
# TODO(charlie):fix this

Use instead:

# TODO(charlie): fix this

docs.title: missing-terminal-punctuation (D415)
docs.text:
Derived from the pydocstyle linter.

Fix is sometimes available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for docstrings in which the first line does not end in a punctuation mark, such as a period, question mark, or exclamation point.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
The first line of a docstring should end with a period, question mark, or exclamation point, for grammatical correctness and consistency.

This rule may not apply to all projects; its applicability is a matter of convention. By default, this rule is enabled when using the google convention, and disabled when using the numpy and pep257 conventions.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
def average(values: list[float]) -> float:
    """Return the mean of the given values"""

Use instead:

def average(values: list[float]) -> float:
    """Return the mean of the given values."""

docs.title: missing-todo-author (TD002)
docs.text: Derived from the flake8-todos linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks that a TODO comment includes an author.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: Including an author on a TODO provides future readers with context around the issue. While the TODO author is not always considered responsible for fixing the issue, they are typically the individual with the most context.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
# TODO: should assign an author here

Use instead

# TODO(charlie): now an author is assigned

docs.title: missing-todo-colon (TD004)
docs.text: Derived from the flake8-todos linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks that a "TODO" tag is followed by a colon.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
"TODO" tags are typically followed by a parenthesized author name, a colon, a space, and a description of the issue, in that order.

Deviating from this pattern can lead to inconsistent and non-idiomatic comments.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
# TODO(charlie) fix this colon

Used instead:

# TODO(charlie): colon fixed

docs.title: missing-todo-description (TD005)
docs.text: Derived from the flake8-todos linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks that a "TODO" tag contains a description of the issue following the tag itself.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: TODO comments should include a description of the issue to provide context for future readers.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
# TODO(charlie)

Use instead:

# TODO(charlie): fix some issue

docs.title: missing-todo-link (TD003)
docs.text: Derived from the flake8-todos linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks that a TODO comment is associated with a link to a relevant issue or ticket.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: Including an issue link near a TODO makes it easier for resolvers to get context around the issue.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
# TODO: this link has no issue

Use one of these instead:

# TODO(charlie): this comment has an issue link
# https://github.com/astral-sh/ruff/issues/3870

# TODO(charlie): this comment has a 3-digit issue code
# 003

# TODO(charlie): https://github.com/astral-sh/ruff/issues/3870
# this comment has an issue link

# TODO(charlie): #003 this comment has a 3-digit issue code
# with leading character `#`

# TODO(charlie): this comment has an issue code (matches the regex `[A-Z]+\-?\d+`)
# SIXCHR-003

docs.title: missing-trailing-comma (COM812)
docs.text:
Derived from the flake8-commas linter.

Fix is always available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for the absence of trailing commas.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: The presence of a trailing comma can reduce diff size when parameters or elements are added or removed from function calls, function definitions, literals, etc.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
foo = {
    "bar": 1,
    "baz": 2
}

Use instead:

foo = {
    "bar": 1,
    "baz": 2,
}

docs.title: Formatter compatibility
docs.text: We recommend against using this rule alongside the formatter. The formatter enforces consistent use of trailing commas, making the rule redundant.

docs.title: missing-trailing-period (D400)
docs.text:

docs.title: What it does

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
PEP 257 recommends that the first line of a docstring is written in the form of a command, ending in a period.

This rule may not apply to all projects; its applicability is a matter of convention. By default, this rule is enabled when using the numpy and pep257 conventions, and disabled when using the google convention.

docs.text:
def average(values: list[float]) -> float:
    """Return the mean of the given values"""

Use instead:

def average(values: list[float]) -> float:
    """Return the mean of the given values."""

docs.title: missing-type-args (ANN002)
docs.text: Derived from the flake8-annotations linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks that function *args arguments have type annotations.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: Type annotations are a good way to document the types of function arguments. They also help catch bugs, when used alongside a type checker, by ensuring that the types of any provided arguments match expectation.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
def foo(*args): ...

Use instead:

def foo(*args: int): ...

Derived from the flake8-annotations linter.

Warning: This rule has been removed and its documentation is only available for historical reasons.

docs.title: Removed
docs.text: This rule has been removed because type checkers can infer this type without annotation.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks that class method cls arguments have type annotations.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
Type annotations are a good way to document the types of function arguments. They also help catch bugs, when used alongside a type checker, by ensuring that the types of any provided arguments match expectation.

Note that many type checkers will infer the type of cls automatically, so this annotation is not strictly necessary.

docs.text:
Derived from the pycodestyle linter.

docs.title: Example

if(True):

docs.title: missing-whitespace-around-arithmetic-operator (E226)
docs.text:
Derived from the pycodestyle linter.

Fix is always available.

This rule is unstable and in preview. The --preview flag is required for use.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for missing whitespace arithmetic operators.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
PEP 8 recommends never using more than one space, and always having the same amount of whitespace on both sides of a binary operator.

For consistency, this rule enforces one space before and after an arithmetic operator (+, -, /, and *).

(Note that PEP 8 suggests only adding whitespace around the operator with the lowest precedence, but that authors should "use [their] own judgment".)

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
number = 40+2

Use instead:

number = 40 + 2

docs.title: missing-whitespace-around-bitwise-or-shift-operator (E227)
docs.text:
Derived from the pycodestyle linter.

Fix is always available.

This rule is unstable and in preview. The --preview flag is required for use.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for missing whitespace around bitwise and shift operators.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
PEP 8 recommends never using more than one space, and always having the same amount of whitespace on both sides of a binary operator.

For consistency, this rule enforces one space before and after bitwise and shift operators (<<, >>, &, |, ^).

(Note that PEP 8 suggests only adding whitespace around the operator with the lowest precedence, but that authors should "use [their] own judgment".)

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
x = 128<<1

Use instead:

x = 128 << 1

docs.title: missing-whitespace-around-modulo-operator (E228)
docs.text:
Derived from the pycodestyle linter.

Fix is always available.

This rule is unstable and in preview. The --preview flag is required for use.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for missing whitespace around the modulo operator.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
PEP 8 recommends never using more than one space, and always having the same amount of whitespace on both sides of a binary operator.

For consistency, this rule enforces one space before and after a modulo operator (%).

(Note that PEP 8 suggests only adding whitespace around the operator with the lowest precedence, but that authors should "use [their] own judgment".)

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
remainder = 10%2

Use instead:

remainder = 10 % 2

docs.title: missing-whitespace-around-operator (E225)
docs.text:
Derived from the pycodestyle linter.

Fix is always available.

This rule is unstable and in preview. The --preview flag is required for use.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for missing whitespace around all operators.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: According to PEP 8, there should be one space before and after all assignment (=), augmented assignment (+=, -=, etc.), comparison, and Booleans operators.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
if number==42:
    print('you have found the meaning of life')

Use instead:

if number == 42:
    print('you have found the meaning of life')

docs.title: missing-whitespace-around-parameter-equals (E252)
docs.text:
Derived from the pycodestyle linter.

Fix is always available.

This rule is unstable and in preview. The --preview flag is required for use.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for missing whitespace around the equals sign in an annotated function keyword parameter.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
According to PEP 8, the spaces around the equals sign in a keyword parameter should only be omitted when the parameter is unannotated:

Don’t use spaces around the = sign when used to indicate a keyword argument, or when used to indicate a default value for an unannotated function parameter.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
def add(a: int=0) -> int:
    return a + 1

Use instead:

def add(a: int = 0) -> int:
    return a + 1

docs.text:
Derived from the pycodestyle linter.

Fix is always available.

This rule is unstable and in preview. The --preview flag is required for use.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for missing whitespace after ,, ;, and :.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: Missing whitespace after ,, ;, and : makes the code harder to read.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
a = (1,2)

Use instead:
