docs.text: Derived from the flake8-bandit linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for paramiko calls.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: paramiko calls allow users to execute arbitrary shell commands on a remote machine. If the inputs to these calls are not properly sanitized, they can be vulnerable to shell injection attacks.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
import paramiko

client = paramiko.SSHClient()
client.exec_command("echo $HOME")

docs.title: References
docs.text:
• Common Weakness Enumeration: CWE-78
  • Paramiko documentation: SSHClient.exec_command()

docs.title: parenthesize-chained-operators (RUF021)
docs.text: Fix is always available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for chained operators where adding parentheses could improve the clarity of the code.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
and always binds more tightly than or when chaining the two together, but this can be hard to remember (and sometimes surprising). Adding parentheses in these situations can greatly improve code readability, with no change to semantics or performance.

For example:

a, b, c = 1, 0, 2
x = a or b and c

d, e, f = 0, 1, 2
y = d and e or f

Use instead:

a, b, c = 1, 0, 2
x = a or (b and c)

d, e, f = 0, 1, 2
y = (d and e) or f

docs.title: pass-in-class-body (PYI012)
docs.text:
Derived from the flake8-pyi linter.

Fix is always available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for the presence of the pass statement in non-empty class bodies in .pyi files.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: The pass statement is always unnecessary in non-empty class bodies in stubs.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
class MyClass:
    x: int
    pass

Use instead:

class MyClass:
    x: int

docs.title: pass-statement-stub-body (PYI009)
docs.text:
Derived from the flake8-pyi linter.

Fix is always available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for pass statements in empty stub bodies.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: For stylistic consistency, ... should always be used rather than pass in stub files.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
def foo(bar: int) -> list[int]: pass

Use instead:

def foo(bar: int) -> list[int]: ...

docs.title: References
docs.text: • Typing documentation - Writing and Maintaining Stub Files

docs.title: patch-version-comparison (PYI004)
docs.text: Derived from the flake8-pyi linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for Python version comparisons in stubs that compare against patch versions (e.g., Python 3.8.3) instead of major and minor versions (e.g., Python 3.8).

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: Stub files support simple conditionals to test for differences in Python versions and platforms. However, type checkers only understand a limited subset of these conditionals. In particular, type checkers don't support patch versions (e.g., Python 3.8.3), only major and minor versions (e.g., Python 3.8). Therefore, version checks in stubs should only use the major and minor versions.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
import sys

if sys.version_info >= (3, 4, 3): ...

Use instead:

import sys

if sys.version_info >= (3, 4): ...

docs.title: References
docs.text: • Typing documentation: Version and Platform checking

docs.title: path-constructor-current-directory (PTH201)
docs.text:
Derived from the flake8-use-pathlib linter.

Fix is always available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for pathlib.Path objects that are initialized with the current directory.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: The Path() constructor defaults to the current directory, so passing it in explicitly (as ".") is unnecessary.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
from pathlib import Path

_ = Path(".")

Use instead:

from pathlib import Path

_ = Path()

docs.title: Fix safety
docs.text: This fix is marked unsafe if there are comments inside the parentheses, as applying the fix will delete them.

docs.title: References
docs.text: • Python documentation: Path

docs.title: pep484-style-positional-only-parameter (PYI063)
docs.text: Derived from the flake8-pyi linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for the presence of PEP 484-style positional-only parameters.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
Historically, PEP 484 recommended prefixing parameter names with double underscores (__) to indicate to a type checker that they were positional-only. However, PEP 570 (introduced in Python 3.8) introduced dedicated syntax for positional-only arguments. If a forward slash (/) is present in a function signature on Python 3.8+, all parameters prior to the slash are interpreted as positional-only.

The new syntax should be preferred as it is more widely used, more concise and more readable. It is also respected by Python at runtime, whereas the old-style syntax was only understood by type checkers.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
def foo(__x: int) -> None: ...

Use instead:

def foo(x: int, /) -> None: ...

docs.title: Options
docs.text: • target-version

docs.title: percent-format-expected-mapping (F502)
docs.text: Derived from the Pyflakes linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for named placeholders in printf-style format strings without mapping-type values.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: When using named placeholders in printf-style format strings, the values must be a map type (such as a dictionary). Otherwise, the expression will raise a TypeError.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
"%(greeting)s, %(name)s" % ("Hello", "World")

Use instead:

"%(greeting)s, %(name)s" % {"greeting": "Hello", "name": "World"}

Or:

"%s, %s" % ("Hello", "World")

docs.title: References
docs.text: • Python documentation: printf-style String Formatting

docs.title: percent-format-expected-sequence (F503)
docs.text: Derived from the Pyflakes linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for uses of mapping-type values in printf-style format strings without named placeholders.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: When using mapping-type values (such as dict) in printf-style format strings, the keys must be named. Otherwise, the expression will raise a TypeError.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
"%s, %s" % {"greeting": "Hello", "name": "World"}

Use instead:

"%(greeting)s, %(name)s" % {"greeting": "Hello", "name": "World"}

Or:

"%s, %s" % ("Hello", "World")

docs.title: References
docs.text: • Python documentation: printf-style String Formatting

docs.title: percent-format-extra-named-arguments (F504)
docs.text:
Derived from the Pyflakes linter.

Fix is always available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for unused mapping keys in printf-style format strings.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: Unused named placeholders in printf-style format strings are unnecessary, and likely indicative of a mistake. They should be removed.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
"Hello, %(name)s" % {"greeting": "Hello", "name": "World"}

Use instead:

"Hello, %(name)s" % {"name": "World"}

docs.title: Fix safety
docs.text:
This rule's fix is marked as unsafe for mapping key containing function calls with potential side effects, because removing such arguments could change the behavior of the code.

For example, the fix would be marked as unsafe in the following case:

"Hello, %(name)s" % {"greeting": print(1), "name": "World"}

docs.title: References
docs.text: • Python documentation: printf-style String Formatting

docs.title: percent-format-invalid-format (F501)
docs.text: Derived from the Pyflakes linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for invalid printf-style format strings.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: Conversion specifiers are required for printf-style format strings. These specifiers must contain a % character followed by a conversion type.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
"Hello, %" % "world"

Use instead:

"Hello, %s" % "world"

docs.title: References
docs.text: • Python documentation: printf-style String Formatting

docs.title: percent-format-missing-argument (F505)
docs.text: Derived from the Pyflakes linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for named placeholders in printf-style format strings that are not present in the provided mapping.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: Named placeholders that lack a corresponding value in the provided mapping will raise a KeyError.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
"%(greeting)s, %(name)s" % {"name": "world"}

Use instead:

"Hello, %(name)s" % {"name": "world"}

docs.title: References
docs.text: • Python documentation: printf-style String Formatting

docs.title: percent-format-mixed-positional-and-named (F506)
docs.text: Derived from the Pyflakes linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for printf-style format strings that have mixed positional and named placeholders.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: Python does not support mixing positional and named placeholders in printf-style format strings. The use of mixed placeholders will raise a TypeError at runtime.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
"%s, %(name)s" % ("Hello", {"name": "World"})

Use instead:

"%s, %s" % ("Hello", "World")

Or:

"%(greeting)s, %(name)s" % {"greeting": "Hello", "name": "World"}

docs.title: References
docs.text: • Python documentation: printf-style String Formatting

docs.title: percent-format-positional-count-mismatch (F507)
docs.text: Derived from the Pyflakes linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for printf-style format strings that have a mismatch between the number of positional placeholders and the number of substitution values.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: When a printf-style format string is provided with too many or too few substitution values, it will raise a TypeError at runtime.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
"%s, %s" % ("Hello", "world", "!")

Use instead:

"%s, %s" % ("Hello", "world")

docs.title: References
docs.text: • Python documentation: printf-style String Formatting

docs.title: percent-format-star-requires-sequence (F508)
docs.text: Derived from the Pyflakes linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for printf-style format strings that use the * specifier with non-tuple values.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: The use of the * specifier with non-tuple values will raise a TypeError at runtime.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
from math import pi

"%(n).*f" % {"n": (2, pi)}

Use instead:

from math import pi

"%.*f" % (2, pi)  # 3.14

docs.title: References
docs.text: • Python documentation: printf-style String Formatting

docs.title: percent-format-unsupported-format-character (F509)
docs.text: Derived from the Pyflakes linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for printf-style format strings with invalid format characters.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: In printf-style format strings, the % character is used to indicate placeholders. If a % character is not followed by a valid format character, it will raise a ValueError at runtime.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
"Hello, %S" % "world"

Use instead:

"Hello, %s" % "world"

docs.title: References
docs.text: • Python documentation: printf-style String Formatting

docs.title: post-init-default (RUF033)
docs.text: Fix is sometimes available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for __post_init__ dataclass methods with parameter defaults.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
Adding a default value to a parameter in a __post_init__ method has no impact on whether the parameter will have a default value in the dataclass's generated __init__ method. To create an init-only dataclass parameter with a default value, you should use an InitVar field in the dataclass's class body and give that InitVar field a default value.

As the documentation states:

Init-only fields are added as parameters to the generated __init__() method, and are passed to the optional __post_init__() method. They are not otherwise used by dataclasses.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
from dataclasses import InitVar, dataclass


@dataclass
class Foo:
    bar: InitVar[int] = 0

    def __post_init__(self, bar: int = 1, baz: int = 2) -> None:
        print(bar, baz)


foo = Foo()  # Prints '0 2'.

Use instead:

from dataclasses import InitVar, dataclass


@dataclass
class Foo:
    bar: InitVar[int] = 1
    baz: InitVar[int] = 2

    def __post_init__(self, bar: int, baz: int) -> None:
        print(bar, baz)


foo = Foo()  # Prints '1 2'.

docs.title: Fix safety
docs.text: This fix is always marked as unsafe because, although switching to InitVar is usually correct, it is incorrect when the parameter is not intended to be part of the public API or when the value is meant to be shared across all instances.

docs.title: References
docs.text:
• Python documentation: Post-init processing
  • Python documentation: Init-only variables

docs.title: potential-index-error (PLE0643)
docs.text: Derived from the Pylint linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for hard-coded sequence accesses that are known to be out of bounds.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: Attempting to access a sequence with an out-of-bounds index will cause an IndexError to be raised at runtime. When the sequence and index are defined statically (e.g., subscripts on list and tuple literals, with integer indexes), such errors can be detected ahead of time.

docs.title: Example
docs.text: print([0, 1, 2][3])

docs.title: print-empty-string (FURB105)
docs.text:
Derived from the refurb linter.

Fix is sometimes available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for print calls with unnecessary empty strings as positional arguments and unnecessary sep keyword arguments.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
Prefer calling print without any positional arguments, which is equivalent and more concise.

Similarly, when printing one or fewer items, the sep keyword argument, (used to define the string that separates the print arguments) can be omitted, as it's redundant when there are no items to separate.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
print("")

Use instead:

print()

docs.title: References
docs.text: • Python documentation: print

docs.title: print (T201)
docs.text:
Derived from the flake8-print linter.

Fix is sometimes available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for print statements.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
print statements used for debugging should be omitted from production code. They can lead the accidental inclusion of sensitive information in logs, and are not configurable by clients, unlike logging statements.

print statements used to produce output as a part of a command-line interface program are not typically a problem.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
def sum_less_than_four(a, b):
    print(f"Calling sum_less_than_four")
    return a + b < 4

The automatic fix will remove the print statement entirely:

def sum_less_than_four(a, b):
    return a + b < 4

To keep the line for logging purposes, instead use something like:

import logging

logging.basicConfig(level=logging.INFO)


def sum_less_than_four(a, b):
    logging.debug("Calling sum_less_than_four")
    return a + b < 4

docs.title: Fix safety
docs.text: This rule's fix is marked as unsafe, as it will remove print statements that are used beyond debugging purposes.

docs.title: printf-in-get-text-func-call (INT003)
docs.text: Derived from the flake8-gettext linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for printf-style formatted strings in gettext function calls.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
In the gettext API, the gettext function (often aliased to _) returns a translation of its input argument by looking it up in a translation catalog.

Calling gettext with a formatted string as its argument can cause unexpected behavior. Since the formatted string is resolved before the function call, the translation catalog will look up the formatted string, rather than the printf-style template.

Instead, format the value returned by the function call, rather than its argument.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
from gettext import gettext as _

name = "Maria"
_("Hello, %s!" % name)  # Looks for "Hello, Maria!".

Use instead:

from gettext import gettext as _

name = "Maria"
_("Hello, %s!") % name  # Looks for "Hello, %s!".

docs.title: References
docs.text: • Python documentation: gettext — Multilingual internationalization services

docs.title: printf-string-formatting (UP031)
docs.text:
Derived from the pyupgrade linter.

Fix is sometimes available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for printf-style string formatting, and offers to replace it with str.format calls.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: printf-style string formatting has a number of quirks, and leads to less readable code than using str.format calls or f-strings. In general, prefer the newer str.format and f-strings constructs over printf-style string formatting.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
"%s, %s" % ("Hello", "World")  # "Hello, World"

Use instead:

"{}, {}".format("Hello", "World")  # "Hello, World"

f"{'Hello'}, {'World'}"  # "Hello, World"

docs.title: Fix safety
docs.text:
In cases where the format string contains a single generic format specifier (e.g. %s), and the right-hand side is an ambiguous expression, we cannot offer a safe fix.

For example, given:

"%s" % val

val could be a single-element tuple, or a single value (not contained in a tuple). Both of these would resolve to the same formatted string when using printf-style formatting, but resolve differently when using f-strings:

val = 1
print("%s" % val)  # "1"
print("{}".format(val))  # "1"

val = (1,)
print("%s" % val)  # "1"
print("{}".format(val))  # "(1,)"

docs.title: References
docs.text:
• Python documentation: printf-style String Formatting
  • Python documentation: str.format

docs.title: private-member-access (SLF001)
docs.text: Derived from the flake8-self linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for accesses on "private" class members.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
In Python, the convention is such that class members that are prefixed with a single underscore, or prefixed but not suffixed with a double underscore, are considered private and intended for internal use.

Using such "private" members is considered a misuse of the class, as there are no guarantees that the member will be present in future versions, that it will have the same type, or that it will have the same behavior. Instead, use the class's public interface.

This rule ignores accesses on dunder methods (e.g., __init__) and sunder methods (e.g., _missing_).

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
class Class:
    def __init__(self):
        self._private_member = "..."


var = Class()
print(var._private_member)

Use instead:

class Class:
    def __init__(self):
        self.public_member = "..."


var = Class()
print(var.public_member)

docs.title: Options
docs.text: • lint.flake8-self.ignore-names

docs.title: References
docs.text: • What is the meaning of single or double underscores before an object name?

docs.title: private-type-parameter (UP049)
docs.text:
Derived from the pyupgrade linter.

Fix is sometimes available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for use of PEP 695 type parameters with leading underscores in generic classes and functions.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
PEP 695 type parameters are already restricted in scope to the class or function in which they appear, so leading underscores just hurt readability without the usual privacy benefits.

However, neither a diagnostic nor a fix will be emitted for "sunder" (_T_) or "dunder" (__T__) type parameter names as these are not considered private.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
class GenericClass[_T]:
    var: _T


def generic_function[_T](var: _T) -> list[_T]:
    return var[0]

Use instead:

class GenericClass[T]:
    var: T


def generic_function[T](var: T) -> list[T]:
    return var[0]

docs.title: Fix availability
docs.text: If the name without an underscore would shadow a builtin or another variable, would be a keyword, or would otherwise be an invalid identifier, a fix will not be available. In these situations, you can consider using a trailing underscore or a different name entirely to satisfy the lint rule.

docs.title: See also
docs.text: This rule renames private PEP 695 type parameters but doesn't convert pre-PEP 695 generics to the new format. See non-pep695-generic-function and non-pep695-generic-class for rules that will make this transformation. Those rules do not remove unused type variables after their changes, so you may also want to consider enabling unused-private-type-var to complete the transition to PEP 695 generics.

docs.title: prohibited-trailing-comma (COM819)
docs.text:
Derived from the flake8-commas linter.

Fix is always available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for the presence of prohibited trailing commas.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: Trailing commas are not essential in some cases and can therefore be viewed as unnecessary.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
foo = (1, 2, 3,)

Use instead:

foo = (1, 2, 3)

docs.title: Formatter compatibility
docs.text: We recommend against using this rule alongside the formatter. The formatter enforces consistent use of trailing commas, making the rule redundant.

docs.title: property-with-parameters (PLR0206)
docs.text: Derived from the Pylint linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for property definitions that accept function parameters.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
Properties cannot be called with parameters.

If you need to pass parameters to a property, create a method with the desired parameters and call that method instead.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
class Cat:
    @property
    def purr(self, volume): ...

Use instead:

class Cat:
    @property
    def purr(self): ...

    def purr_volume(self, volume): ...

docs.title: References
docs.text: • Python documentation: property

docs.title: py-path (PTH124)
docs.text: Derived from the flake8-use-pathlib linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for uses of the py.path library.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: The py.path library is in maintenance mode. Instead, prefer the standard library's pathlib module, or third-party modules like path (formerly py.path).

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
import py.path

p = py.path.local("/foo/bar").join("baz/qux")

Use instead:

from pathlib import Path

p = Path("/foo/bar") / "bar" / "qux"

docs.title: References
docs.text:
• Python documentation: Pathlib
  • Path repository

docs.title: pytest-assert-always-false (PT015)
docs.text: Derived from the flake8-pytest-style linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for assert statements whose test expression is a falsy value.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: pytest.fail conveys the intent more clearly than assert falsy_value.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
def test_foo():
    if some_condition:
        assert False, "some_condition was True"

Use instead:

import pytest


def test_foo():
    if some_condition:
        pytest.fail("some_condition was True")
    ...

docs.title: References
docs.text: • pytest documentation: pytest.fail

docs.title: pytest-assert-in-except (PT017)
docs.text: Derived from the flake8-pytest-style linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for assert statements in except clauses.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: When testing for exceptions, pytest.raises() should be used instead of assert statements in except clauses, as it's more explicit and idiomatic. Further, pytest.raises() will fail if the exception is not raised, unlike the assert statement.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
def test_foo():
    try:
        1 / 0
    except ZeroDivisionError as e:
        assert e.args

Use instead:

import pytest


def test_foo():
    with pytest.raises(ZeroDivisionError) as exc_info:
        1 / 0
    assert exc_info.value.args

docs.title: References
docs.text: • pytest documentation: pytest.raises

docs.title: pytest-composite-assertion (PT018)
docs.text:
Derived from the flake8-pytest-style linter.

Fix is sometimes available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for assertions that combine multiple independent conditions.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: Composite assertion statements are harder to debug upon failure, as the failure message will not indicate which condition failed.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
def test_foo():
    assert something and something_else


def test_bar():
    assert not (something or something_else)

Use instead:

def test_foo():
    assert something
    assert something_else


def test_bar():
    assert not something
    assert not something_else

docs.title: pytest-deprecated-yield-fixture (PT020)
docs.text: Derived from the flake8-pytest-style linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for pytest.yield_fixture usage.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: pytest.yield_fixture is deprecated. pytest.fixture should be used instead.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
import pytest


@pytest.yield_fixture()
def my_fixture():
    obj = SomeClass()
    yield obj
    obj.cleanup()

Use instead:

import pytest


@pytest.fixture()
def my_fixture():
    obj = SomeClass()
    yield obj
    obj.cleanup()

docs.title: References
docs.text: • pytest documentation: yield_fixture functions

docs.title: pytest-duplicate-parametrize-test-cases (PT014)
docs.text:
Derived from the flake8-pytest-style linter.

Fix is sometimes available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for duplicate test cases in pytest.mark.parametrize.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: Duplicate test cases are redundant and should be removed.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
import pytest


@pytest.mark.parametrize(
    ("param1", "param2"),
    [
        (1, 2),
        (1, 2),
    ],
)
def test_foo(param1, param2): ...

Use instead:

import pytest


@pytest.mark.parametrize(
    ("param1", "param2"),
    [
        (1, 2),
    ],
)
def test_foo(param1, param2): ...

docs.title: Fix safety
docs.text: This rule's fix is marked as unsafe, as tests that rely on mutable global state may be affected by removing duplicate test cases.

docs.title: References
docs.text: • pytest documentation: How to parametrize fixtures and test functions

docs.title: pytest-erroneous-use-fixtures-on-fixture (PT025)
docs.text:
Derived from the flake8-pytest-style linter.

Fix is always available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for pytest.mark.usefixtures decorators applied to pytest fixtures.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: The pytest.mark.usefixtures decorator has no effect on pytest fixtures.

import pytest

def a():
    pass


@pytest.mark.usefixtures("a")
@pytest.fixture()
def b(a):
    pass

Use instead:

import pytest


@pytest.fixture()
def a():
    pass


@pytest.fixture()
def b(a):
    pass

docs.text: pytest.fail calls without a message make it harder to understand and debug test failures.

docs.title: pytest-fixture-finalizer-callback (PT021)
docs.text: Derived from the flake8-pytest-style linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for unnecessary request.addfinalizer usages in pytest fixtures.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
pytest offers two ways to perform cleanup in fixture code. The first is sequential (via the yield statement), the second callback-based (via request.addfinalizer).

The sequential approach is more readable and should be preferred, unless the fixture uses the "factory as fixture" pattern.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
import pytest


@pytest.fixture()
def my_fixture(request):
    resource = acquire_resource()
    request.addfinalizer(resource.release)
    return resource

Use instead:

import pytest


@pytest.fixture()
def my_fixture():
    resource = acquire_resource()
    yield resource
    resource.release()


# "factory-as-fixture" pattern
@pytest.fixture()
def my_factory(request):
    def create_resource(arg):
        resource = acquire_resource(arg)
        request.addfinalizer(resource.release)
        return resource

    return create_resource

docs.title: pytest-fixture-incorrect-parentheses-style (PT001)
docs.text:
Derived from the flake8-pytest-style linter.

Fix is always available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for argument-free @pytest.fixture() decorators with or without parentheses, depending on the lint.flake8-pytest-style.fixture-parentheses setting.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
If a @pytest.fixture() doesn't take any arguments, the parentheses are optional.

Either removing those unnecessary parentheses or requiring them for all fixtures is fine, but it's best to be consistent. The rule defaults to removing unnecessary parentheses, to match the documentation of the official pytest projects.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
import pytest


@pytest.fixture()
def my_fixture(): ...

Use instead:

import pytest


@pytest.fixture
def my_fixture(): ...

docs.title: Fix safety
docs.text:
This rule's fix is marked as unsafe if there's comments in the pytest.fixture decorator.

For example, the fix would be marked as unsafe in the following case:

import pytest


@pytest.fixture(
    # comment
    # scope = "module"
)
def my_fixture(): ...

docs.title: pytest-fixture-param-without-value (PT019)
docs.text: Derived from the flake8-pytest-style linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for pytest test functions that should be decorated with @pytest.mark.usefixtures.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
In pytest, fixture injection is used to activate fixtures in a test function.

Fixtures can be injected either by passing them as parameters to the test function, or by using the @pytest.mark.usefixtures decorator.

If the test function depends on the fixture being activated, but does not use it in the test body or otherwise rely on its return value, prefer the @pytest.mark.usefixtures decorator, to make the dependency explicit and avoid the confusion caused by unused arguments.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
import pytest


@pytest.fixture
def _patch_something(): ...


def test_foo(_patch_something): ...

Use instead:

import pytest


@pytest.fixture
def _patch_something(): ...


@pytest.mark.usefixtures("_patch_something")
def test_foo(): ...

docs.title: pytest-incorrect-fixture-name-underscore (PT005)
docs.text:
Derived from the flake8-pytest-style linter.

Warning: This rule has been removed and its documentation is only available for historical reasons.

docs.title: Removal
docs.text: This rule has been removed because marking fixtures that do not return a value with an underscore isn't a practice recommended by the pytest community.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for pytest fixtures that return a value, but are named with a leading underscore.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
By convention, fixtures that don't return a value should be named with a leading underscore, while fixtures that do return a value should not.

This rule ignores abstract fixtures.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
import pytest


@pytest.fixture()
def _some_object():
    return SomeClass()


@pytest.fixture()
def _some_object_with_cleanup():
    obj = SomeClass()
    yield obj
    obj.cleanup()

Use instead:

import pytest


@pytest.fixture()
def some_object():
    return SomeClass()


@pytest.fixture()
def some_object_with_cleanup():
    obj = SomeClass()
    yield obj
    obj.cleanup()

docs.title: pytest-parametrize-names-wrong-type (PT006)
docs.text:
Derived from the flake8-pytest-style linter.

Fix is sometimes available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for the type of parameter names passed to pytest.mark.parametrize.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: The argnames argument of pytest.mark.parametrize takes a string or a sequence of strings. For a single parameter, it's preferable to use a string. For multiple parameters, it's preferable to use the style configured via the lint.flake8-pytest-style.parametrize-names-type setting.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
import pytest


# single parameter, always expecting string
@pytest.mark.parametrize(("param",), [1, 2, 3])
def test_foo(param): ...


# multiple parameters, expecting tuple
@pytest.mark.parametrize(["param1", "param2"], [(1, 2), (3, 4)])
def test_bar(param1, param2): ...


# multiple parameters, expecting tuple
@pytest.mark.parametrize("param1,param2", [(1, 2), (3, 4)])
def test_baz(param1, param2): ...

Use instead:

import pytest


@pytest.mark.parametrize("param", [1, 2, 3])
def test_foo(param): ...


@pytest.mark.parametrize(("param1", "param2"), [(1, 2), (3, 4)])
def test_bar(param1, param2): ...

docs.title: pytest-parametrize-values-wrong-type (PT007)
docs.text:
Derived from the flake8-pytest-style linter.

Fix is sometimes available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for the type of parameter values passed to pytest.mark.parametrize.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
The argvalues argument of pytest.mark.parametrize takes an iterator of parameter values, which can be provided as lists or tuples.

To aid in readability, it's recommended to use a consistent style for the list of values rows, and, in the case of multiple parameters, for each row of values.

The style for the list of values rows can be configured via the lint.flake8-pytest-style.parametrize-values-type setting, while the style for each row of values can be configured via the lint.flake8-pytest-style.parametrize-values-row-type setting.

For example, lint.flake8-pytest-style.parametrize-values-type will lead to the following expectations:

  • tuple: @pytest.mark.parametrize("value", ("a", "b", "c"))
  • list: @pytest.mark.parametrize("value", ["a", "b", "c"])

Similarly, lint.flake8-pytest-style.parametrize-values-row-type will lead to the following expectations:

  • tuple: @pytest.mark.parametrize(("key", "value"), [("a", "b"), ("c", "d")])
  • list: @pytest.mark.parametrize(("key", "value"), [["a", "b"], ["c", "d"]])

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
import pytest


# expected list, got tuple
@pytest.mark.parametrize("param", (1, 2))
def test_foo(param): ...


# expected top-level list, got tuple
@pytest.mark.parametrize(
    ("param1", "param2"),
    (
        (1, 2),
        (3, 4),
    ),
)
def test_bar(param1, param2): ...


# expected individual rows to be tuples, got lists
@pytest.mark.parametrize(
    ("param1", "param2"),
    [
        [1, 2],
        [3, 4],
    ],
)
def test_baz(param1, param2): ...

Use instead:

import pytest


@pytest.mark.parametrize("param", [1, 2, 3])
def test_foo(param): ...


@pytest.mark.parametrize(("param1", "param2"), [(1, 2), (3, 4)])
def test_bar(param1, param2): ...

docs.title: pytest-patch-with-lambda (PT008)
docs.text: Derived from the flake8-pytest-style linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for mocked calls that use a dummy lambda function instead of return_value.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
When patching calls, an explicit return_value better conveys the intent than a lambda function, assuming the lambda does not use the arguments passed to it.

return_value is also robust to changes in the patched function's signature, and enables additional assertions to verify behavior. For example, return_value allows for verification of the number of calls or the arguments passed to the patched function via assert_called_once_with and related methods.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
def test_foo(mocker):
    mocker.patch("module.target", lambda x, y: 7)

Use instead:

def test_foo(mocker):
    mocker.patch("module.target", return_value=7)

    # If the lambda makes use of the arguments, no diagnostic is emitted.
    mocker.patch("module.other_target", lambda x, y: x)

docs.title: pytest-raises-ambiguous-pattern (RUF043)
docs.text: This rule is unstable and in preview. The --preview flag is required for use.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for non-raw literal string arguments passed to the match parameter of pytest.raises() where the string contains at least one unescaped regex metacharacter.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: The match argument is implicitly converted to a regex under the hood. It should be made explicit whether the string is meant to be a regex or a "plain" pattern by prefixing the string with the r suffix, escaping the metacharacter(s) in the string using backslashes, or wrapping the entire string in a call to re.escape().

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
import pytest


with pytest.raises(Exception, match="A full sentence."):
    do_thing_that_raises()

Use instead:

import pytest


with pytest.raises(Exception, match=r"A full sentence."):
    do_thing_that_raises()

Alternatively:

import pytest
import re


with pytest.raises(Exception, match=re.escape("A full sentence.")):
    do_thing_that_raises()

or:

import pytest
import re


with pytest.raises(Exception, "A full sentence\\."):
    do_thing_that_raises()

docs.title: pytest-raises-too-broad (PT011)
docs.text: Derived from the flake8-pytest-style linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for pytest.raises calls without a match parameter.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: pytest.raises(Error) will catch any Error and may catch errors that are unrelated to the code under test. To avoid this, pytest.raises should be called with a match parameter. The exception names that require a match parameter can be configured via the lint.flake8-pytest-style.raises-require-match-for and lint.flake8-pytest-style.raises-extend-require-match-for settings.

import pytest


def test_foo():
    with pytest.raises(ValueError):
        ...

    # empty string is also an error
    with pytest.raises(ValueError, match=""):
        ...

Use instead:

import pytest


def test_foo():
    with pytest.raises(ValueError, match="expected message"):
        ...

docs.title: pytest-raises-with-multiple-statements (PT012)
docs.text: Derived from the flake8-pytest-style linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text:
Checks for pytest.raises context managers with multiple statements.

This rule allows pytest.raises bodies to contain for loops with empty bodies (e.g., pass or ... statements), to test iterator behavior.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
When a pytest.raises is used as a context manager and contains multiple statements, it can lead to the test passing when it actually should fail.

A pytest.raises context manager should only contain a single simple statement that raises the expected exception.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
import pytest


def test_foo():
    with pytest.raises(MyError):
        setup()
        func_to_test()  # not executed if `setup()` raises `MyError`
        assert foo()  # not executed

Use instead:

import pytest


def test_foo():
    setup()
    with pytest.raises(MyError):
        func_to_test()
    assert foo()

        ...

    # empty string is also an error
    with pytest.warns(Warning, match=""):
        ...

Use instead:

import pytest


def test_foo():
    with pytest.warns(Warning, match="expected message"):
        ...

docs.title: pytest-warns-with-multiple-statements (PT031)
docs.text: Derived from the flake8-pytest-style linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text:
Checks for pytest.warns context managers with multiple statements.

This rule allows pytest.warns bodies to contain for loops with empty bodies (e.g., pass or ... statements), to test iterator behavior.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
When pytest.warns is used as a context manager and contains multiple statements, it can lead to the test passing when it should instead fail.

A pytest.warns context manager should only contain a single simple statement that triggers the expected warning.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
import pytest


def test_foo_warns():
    with pytest.warns(Warning):
        setup()  # False negative if setup triggers a warning but foo does not.
        foo()

Use instead:

import pytest


def test_foo_warns():
    setup()
    with pytest.warns(Warning):
        foo()

docs.title: References
docs.text: • pytest documentation: pytest.warns

docs.title: pytest-warns-without-warning (PT029)
docs.text:
Derived from the flake8-pytest-style linter.

This rule is unstable and in preview. The --preview flag is required for use.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for pytest.warns calls without an expected warning.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: pytest.warns expects to receive an expected warning as its first argument. If omitted, the pytest.warns call will fail at runtime.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
import pytest


def test_foo():
    with pytest.warns():
        do_something()

Use instead:

import pytest


def test_foo():
    with pytest.warns(SomeWarning):
        do_something()

docs.title: quadratic-list-summation (RUF017)
docs.text: Fix is always available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for the use of sum() to flatten lists of lists, which has quadratic complexity.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
The use of sum() to flatten lists of lists is quadratic in the number of lists, as sum() creates a new list for each element in the summation.

Instead, consider using another method of flattening lists to avoid quadratic complexity. The following methods are all linear in the number of lists:

  • functools.reduce(operator.iadd, lists, [])
  • list(itertools.chain.from_iterable(lists))
  • [item for sublist in lists for item in sublist]

When fixing relevant violations, Ruff defaults to the functools.reduce form, which outperforms the other methods in microbenchmarks.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
lists = [[1, 2, 3], [4, 5, 6], [7, 8, 9]]
joined = sum(lists, [])

Use instead:

import functools
import operator


lists = [[1, 2, 3], [4, 5, 6], [7, 8, 9]]
functools.reduce(operator.iadd, lists, [])

docs.title: Fix safety
docs.text: This fix is always marked as unsafe because sum uses the __add__ magic method while operator.iadd uses the __iadd__ magic method, and these behave differently on lists. The former requires the right summand to be a list, whereas the latter allows for any iterable. Therefore, the fix could inadvertently cause code that previously raised an error to silently succeed. Moreover, the fix could remove comments from the original code.

docs.title: References
docs.text:
• How Not to Flatten a List of Lists in Python
  • How do I make a flat list out of a list of lists?

docs.title: quoted-annotation-in-stub (PYI020)
docs.text:
Derived from the flake8-pyi linter.

Fix is always available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for quoted type annotations in stub (.pyi) files, which should be avoided.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: Stub files natively support forward references in all contexts, as stubs are never executed at runtime. (They should be thought of as "data files" for type checkers and IDEs.) As such, quotes are never required for type annotations in stub files, and should be omitted.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
def function() -> "int": ...

Use instead:

def function() -> int: ...

docs.title: References
docs.text: • Typing documentation - Writing and Maintaining Stub Files

docs.title: quoted-annotation (UP037)
docs.text:
Derived from the pyupgrade linter.

Fix is always available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for the presence of unnecessary quotes in type annotations.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
In Python, type annotations can be quoted to avoid forward references.

However, if from __future__ import annotations is present, Python will always evaluate type annotations in a deferred manner, making the quotes unnecessary.

Similarly, if the annotation is located in a typing-only context and won't be evaluated by Python at runtime, the quotes will also be considered unnecessary. For example, Python does not evaluate type annotations on assignments in function bodies.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
Given:

from __future__ import annotations


def foo(bar: "Bar") -> "Bar": ...

Use instead:

from __future__ import annotations


def foo(bar: Bar) -> Bar: ...

Given:

def foo() -> None:
    bar: "Bar"

Use instead:

def foo() -> None:
    bar: Bar

docs.title: Preview
docs.text: When preview is enabled, if lint.future-annotations is set to true, from __future__ import annotations will be added if doing so would allow an annotation to be unquoted.

docs.title: Fix safety
docs.text: The rule's fix is marked as safe, unless preview and lint.future-annotations are enabled and a from __future__ import annotations import is added. Such an import may change the behavior of all annotations in the file.

docs.title: Options
docs.text: • lint.future-annotations

docs.title: See also
docs.text:
• quoted-annotation-in-stub: A rule that removes all quoted annotations from stub files
  • quoted-type-alias: A rule that removes unnecessary quotes from type aliases.

docs.title: References
docs.text:
• PEP 563 – Postponed Evaluation of Annotations
  • Python documentation: __future__

docs.title: quoted-type-alias (TC008)
docs.text:
Derived from the flake8-type-checking linter.

Fix is always available.

This rule is unstable and in preview. The --preview flag is required for use.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for unnecessary quotes in PEP 613 explicit type aliases and PEP 695 type statements.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
Unnecessary string forward references can lead to additional overhead in runtime libraries making use of type hints. They can also have bad interactions with other runtime uses like PEP 604 type unions.

PEP-613 type aliases are only flagged by the rule if Ruff can have high confidence that the quotes are unnecessary. Specifically, any PEP-613 type alias where the type expression on the right-hand side contains subscripts or attribute accesses will not be flagged. This is because type aliases can reference types that are, for example, generic in stub files but not at runtime. That can mean that a type checker expects the referenced type to be subscripted with type arguments despite the fact that doing so would fail at runtime if the type alias value was not quoted. Similarly, a type alias might need to reference a module-level attribute that exists in a stub file but not at runtime, meaning that the type alias value would need to be quoted to avoid a runtime error.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
Given:

from typing import TypeAlias

OptInt: TypeAlias = "int | None"

Use instead:

from typing import TypeAlias

OptInt: TypeAlias = int | None

Given:

type OptInt = "int | None"

Use instead:

type OptInt = int | None

docs.title: Fix safety
docs.text: This rule's fix is marked as safe, unless the type annotation contains comments.

docs.title: See also
docs.text:
This rule only applies to type aliases in non-stub files. For removing quotes in other contexts or in stub files, see:

  • quoted-annotation-in-stub: A rule that removes all quoted annotations from stub files
  • quoted-annotation: A rule that removes unnecessary quotes from annotations in runtime files.

docs.title: References
docs.text:
• PEP 613 – Explicit Type Aliases
  • PEP 695: Generic Type Alias
  • PEP 604 – Allow writing union types as X | Y

docs.title: raise-literal (B016)
docs.text: Derived from the flake8-bugbear linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for raise statements that raise a literal value.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: raise must be followed by an exception instance or an exception class, and exceptions must be instances of BaseException or a subclass thereof. Raising a literal will raise a TypeError at runtime.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
raise "foo"

Use instead:

raise Exception("foo")

docs.title: References
docs.text: • Python documentation: raise statement

docs.title: raise-not-implemented (F901)
docs.text:
Derived from the Pyflakes linter.

Fix is sometimes available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for raise statements that raise NotImplemented.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
NotImplemented is an exception used by binary special methods to indicate that an operation is not implemented with respect to a particular type.

NotImplemented should not be raised directly. Instead, raise NotImplementedError, which is used to indicate that the method is abstract or not implemented in the derived class.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
class Foo:
    def bar(self):
        raise NotImplemented

Use instead:

class Foo:
    def bar(self):
        raise NotImplementedError

docs.title: References
docs.text:
• Python documentation: NotImplemented
  • Python documentation: NotImplementedError

docs.title: raise-vanilla-args (TRY003)
docs.text: Derived from the tryceratops linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for long exception messages that are not defined in the exception class itself.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
By formatting an exception message at the raise site, the exception class becomes less reusable, and may now raise inconsistent messages depending on where it is raised.

If the exception message is instead defined within the exception class, it will be consistent across all raise invocations.

This rule is not enforced for some built-in exceptions that are commonly raised with a message and would be unusual to subclass, such as NotImplementedError.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
class CantBeNegative(Exception):
    pass


def foo(x):
    if x < 0:
        raise CantBeNegative(f"{x} is negative")

Use instead:

class CantBeNegative(Exception):
    def __init__(self, number):
        super().__init__(f"{number} is negative")


def foo(x):
    if x < 0:
        raise CantBeNegative(x)

docs.title: raise-vanilla-class (TRY002)
docs.text: Derived from the tryceratops linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for code that raises Exception or BaseException directly.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
Handling such exceptions requires the use of except Exception or except BaseException. These will capture almost any raised exception, including failed assertions, division by zero, and more.

Prefer to raise your own exception, or a more specific built-in exception, so that you can avoid over-capturing exceptions that you don't intend to handle.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
def main_function():
    if not cond:
        raise Exception()


def consumer_func():
    try:
        do_step()
        prepare()
        main_function()
    except Exception:
        logger.error("Oops")

Use instead:

def main_function():
    if not cond:
        raise CustomException()


def consumer_func():
    try:
        do_step()
        prepare()
        main_function()
    except CustomException:
        logger.error("Main function failed")
    except Exception:
        logger.error("Oops")

docs.title: raise-within-try (TRY301)
docs.text: Derived from the tryceratops linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for raise statements within try blocks. The only raises caught are those that throw exceptions caught by the try statement itself.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
Raising and catching exceptions within the same try block is redundant, as the code can be refactored to avoid the try block entirely.

Alternatively, the raise can be moved within an inner function, making the exception reusable across multiple call sites.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
def bar():
    pass


def foo():
    try:
        a = bar()
        if not a:
            raise ValueError
    except ValueError:
        raise

Use instead:

def bar():
    raise ValueError


def foo():
    try:
        a = bar()  # refactored `bar` to raise `ValueError`
    except ValueError:
        raise

docs.title: raise-without-from-inside-except (B904)
docs.text: Derived from the flake8-bugbear linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for raise statements in exception handlers that lack a from clause.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
In Python, raise can be used with or without an exception from which the current exception is derived. This is known as exception chaining. When printing the stack trace, chained exceptions are displayed in such a way so as make it easier to trace the exception back to its root cause.

When raising an exception from within an except clause, always include a from clause to facilitate exception chaining. If the exception is not chained, it will be difficult to trace the exception back to its root cause.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
try:
    ...
except FileNotFoundError:
    if ...:
        raise RuntimeError("...")
    else:
        raise UserWarning("...")

Use instead:

try:
    ...
except FileNotFoundError as exc:
    if ...:
        raise RuntimeError("...") from None
    else:
        raise UserWarning("...") from exc

docs.title: References
docs.text: • Python documentation: raise statement

docs.title: raw-string-in-exception (EM101)
docs.text:
Derived from the flake8-errmsg linter.

Fix is sometimes available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text:
Checks for the use of string literals in exception constructors.

In preview, this rule checks for byte string literals in exception constructors.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
Python includes the raise in the default traceback (and formatters like Rich and IPython do too).

By using a string literal, the error message will be duplicated in the traceback, which can make the traceback less readable.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
Given:

raise RuntimeError("'Some value' is incorrect")

Python will produce a traceback like:

Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "tmp.py", line 2, in <module>
    raise RuntimeError("'Some value' is incorrect")
RuntimeError: 'Some value' is incorrect

Instead, assign the string to a variable:

msg = "'Some value' is incorrect"
raise RuntimeError(msg)

Which will produce a traceback like:

Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "tmp.py", line 3, in <module>
    raise RuntimeError(msg)
RuntimeError: 'Some value' is incorrect

docs.title: re-sub-positional-args (B034)
docs.text: Derived from the flake8-bugbear linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for calls to re.sub, re.subn, and re.split that pass count, maxsplit, or flags as positional arguments.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
Passing count, maxsplit, or flags as positional arguments to re.sub, re.subn, or re.split can lead to confusion, as most methods in the re module accept flags as the third positional argument, while re.sub, re.subn, and re.split have different signatures.

Instead, pass count, maxsplit, and flags as keyword arguments.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
import re

re.split("pattern", "replacement", 1)

Use instead:

import re

re.split("pattern", "replacement", maxsplit=1)

docs.title: References
docs.text:
• Python documentation: re.sub
  • Python documentation: re.subn
  • Python documentation: re.split

docs.title: read-whole-file (FURB101)
docs.text:
Derived from the refurb linter.

This rule is unstable and in preview. The --preview flag is required for use.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for uses of open and read that can be replaced by pathlib methods, like Path.read_text and Path.read_bytes.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: When reading the entire contents of a file into a variable, it's simpler and more concise to use pathlib methods like Path.read_text and Path.read_bytes instead of open and read calls via with statements.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
with open(filename) as f:
    contents = f.read()

Use instead:

from pathlib import Path

contents = Path(filename).read_text()

docs.title: References
docs.text:
• Python documentation: Path.read_bytes
  • Python documentation: Path.read_text

docs.title: readlines-in-for (FURB129)
docs.text:
Derived from the refurb linter.

Fix is always available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for uses of readlines() when iterating over a file line-by-line.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: Rather than iterating over all lines in a file by calling readlines(), it's more convenient and performant to iterate over the file object directly.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
with open("file.txt") as fp:
    for line in fp.readlines():
        ...

Use instead:

with open("file.txt") as fp:
    for line in fp:
        ...

docs.title: Fix safety
docs.text:
This rule's fix is marked as unsafe if there's comments in the readlines() call, as comments may be removed.

For example, the fix would be marked as unsafe in the following case:

with open("file.txt") as fp:
    for line in (  # comment
        fp.readlines()  # comment
    ):
        ...

docs.title: References
docs.text: • Python documentation: io.IOBase.readlines

docs.title: redeclared-assigned-name (PLW0128)
docs.text: Derived from the Pylint linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for declared assignments to the same variable multiple times in the same assignment.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: Assigning a variable multiple times in the same assignment is redundant, as the final assignment to the variable is what the value will be.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
a, b, a = (1, 2, 3)
print(a)  # 3

Use instead:

# this is assuming you want to assign 3 to `a`
_, b, a = (1, 2, 3)
print(a)  # 3

docs.title: redefined-argument-from-local (PLR1704)
docs.text: Derived from the Pylint linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for variables defined in for, try, with statements that redefine function parameters.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: Redefined variables can cause unexpected behavior because of overridden function parameters. If nested functions are declared, an inner function's body can override an outer function's parameters.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
def show(host_id=10.11):
    for host_id, host in [[12.13, "Venus"], [14.15, "Mars"]]:
        print(host_id, host)

Use instead:

def show(host_id=10.11):
    for inner_host_id, host in [[12.13, "Venus"], [14.15, "Mars"]]:
        print(host_id, inner_host_id, host)

docs.title: Options
docs.text: • lint.dummy-variable-rgx

docs.title: References
docs.text: • Pylint documentation

docs.title: redefined-loop-name (PLW2901)
docs.text: Derived from the Pylint linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for variables defined in for loops and with statements that get overwritten within the body, for example by another for loop or with statement or by direct assignment.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
Redefinition of a loop variable inside the loop's body causes its value to differ from the original loop iteration for the remainder of the block, in a way that will likely cause bugs.

In Python, unlike many other languages, for loops and with statements don't define their own scopes. Therefore, a nested loop that uses the same target variable name as an outer loop will reuse the same actual variable, and the value from the last iteration will "leak out" into the remainder of the enclosing loop.

While this mistake is easy to spot in small examples, it can be hidden in larger blocks of code, where the definition and redefinition of the variable may not be visible at the same time.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
for i in range(10):
    i = 9
    print(i)  # prints 9 every iteration

for i in range(10):
    for i in range(10):  # original value overwritten
        pass
    print(i)  # also prints 9 every iteration

with path1.open() as f:
    with path2.open() as f:
        f = path2.open()
    print(f.readline())  # prints a line from path2

docs.title: redefined-slots-in-subclass (PLW0244)
docs.text:
Derived from the Pylint linter.

This rule is unstable and in preview. The --preview flag is required for use.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for a re-defined slot in a subclass.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: If a class defines a slot also defined in a base class, the instance variable defined by the base class slot is inaccessible (except by retrieving its descriptor directly from the base class).

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
class Base:
    __slots__ = ("a", "b")


class Subclass(Base):
    __slots__ = ("a", "d")  # slot "a" redefined

Use instead:

class Base:
    __slots__ = ("a", "b")


class Subclass(Base):
    __slots__ = "d"

docs.title: redefined-while-unused (F811)
docs.text:
Derived from the Pyflakes linter.

Fix is sometimes available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for variable definitions that redefine (or "shadow") unused variables.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: Redefinitions of unused names are unnecessary and often indicative of a mistake.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
import foo
import bar
import foo  # Redefinition of unused `foo` from line 1

Use instead:

import foo
import bar

docs.title: redirected-noqa (RUF101)
docs.text: Fix is always available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for noqa directives that use redirected rule codes.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: When one of Ruff's rule codes has been redirected, the implication is that the rule has been deprecated in favor of another rule or code. To keep your codebase consistent and up-to-date, prefer the canonical rule code over the deprecated code.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
x = eval(command)  # noqa: PGH001

Use instead:

x = eval(command)  # noqa: S307

docs.title: redundant-backslash (E502)
docs.text:
Derived from the pycodestyle linter.

Fix is always available.

This rule is unstable and in preview. The --preview flag is required for use.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for redundant backslashes between brackets.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: Explicit line joins using a backslash are redundant between brackets.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
x = (2 + \
    2)

Use instead:

x = (2 +
    2)

docs.title: redundant-bool-literal (RUF038)
docs.text:
Fix is sometimes available.

This rule is unstable and in preview. The --preview flag is required for use.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for Literal[True, False] type annotations.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
Literal[True, False] can be replaced with bool in type annotations, which has the same semantic meaning but is more concise and readable.

bool type has exactly two constant instances: True and False. Static type checkers such as mypy treat Literal[True, False] as equivalent to bool in a type annotation.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
from typing import Literal

x: Literal[True, False]
y: Literal[True, False, "hello", "world"]

Use instead:

from typing import Literal

x: bool
y: Literal["hello", "world"] | bool

docs.title: Fix safety
docs.text:
The fix for this rule is marked as unsafe, as it may change the semantics of the code. Specifically:

  • Type checkers may not treat bool as equivalent when overloading boolean arguments with Literal[True] and Literal[False] (see, e.g., #14764 and #5421).
  • bool is not strictly equivalent to Literal[True, False], as bool is a subclass of int, and this rule may not apply if the type annotations are used in a numeric context.

Further, the Literal slice may contain trailing-line comments which the fix would remove.

docs.title: References
docs.text:
• Typing documentation: Legal parameters for Literal at type check time
  • Python documentation: Boolean type - bool

docs.title: redundant-final-literal (PYI064)
docs.text:
Derived from the flake8-pyi linter.

Fix is sometimes available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for redundant Final[Literal[...]] annotations.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: All constant variables annotated as Final are understood as implicitly having Literal types by a type checker. As such, a Final[Literal[...]] annotation can often be replaced with a bare Final, annotation, which will have the same meaning to the type checker while being more concise and more readable.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
from typing import Final, Literal

x: Final[Literal[42]]
y: Final[Literal[42]] = 42

Use instead:

from typing import Final, Literal

x: Final = 42
y: Final = 42

docs.title: redundant-literal-union (PYI051)
docs.text: Derived from the flake8-pyi linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for redundant unions between a Literal and a builtin supertype of that Literal.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: Using a Literal type in a union with its builtin supertype is redundant, as the supertype will be strictly more general than the Literal type. For example, Literal["A"] | str is equivalent to str, and Literal[1] | int is equivalent to int, as str and int are the supertypes of "A" and 1 respectively.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
from typing import Literal

x: Literal["A", b"B"] | str

Use instead:

from typing import Literal

x: Literal[b"B"] | str

docs.title: redundant-log-base (FURB163)
docs.text:
Derived from the refurb linter.

Fix is sometimes available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for math.log calls with a redundant base.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
The default base of math.log is e, so specifying it explicitly is redundant.

Instead of passing 2 or 10 as the base, use math.log2 or math.log10 respectively, as these dedicated variants are typically more accurate than math.log.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
import math

math.log(4, math.e)
math.log(4, 2)
math.log(4, 10)

Use instead:

import math

math.log(4)
math.log2(4)
math.log10(4)

docs.title: Fix safety
docs.text: This fix is marked unsafe when the argument is a starred expression, as this changes the call semantics and may raise runtime errors. It is also unsafe if comments are present within the call, as they will be removed. Additionally, math.log(x, base) and math.log2(x) / math.log10(x) may differ due to floating-point rounding, so the fix is also unsafe when making this transformation.

docs.title: References
docs.text:
• Python documentation: math.log
  • Python documentation: math.log2
  • Python documentation: math.log10

docs.title: redundant-none-literal (PYI061)
docs.text:
Derived from the flake8-pyi linter.

Fix is sometimes available.

This rule is unstable and in preview. The --preview flag is required for use.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for redundant Literal[None] annotations.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: While Literal[None] is a valid type annotation, it is semantically equivalent to None. Prefer None over Literal[None] for both consistency and readability.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
from typing import Literal

Literal[None]
Literal[1, 2, 3, "foo", 5, None]

Use instead:

from typing import Literal

None
Literal[1, 2, 3, "foo", 5] | None

docs.title: Fix safety and availability
docs.text:
This rule's fix is marked as safe unless the literal contains comments.

There is currently no fix available when applying the fix would lead to a TypeError from an expression of the form None | None or when we are unable to import the symbol typing.Optional and the Python version is 3.9 or below.

docs.title: References
docs.text: • Typing documentation: Legal parameters for Literal at type check time

docs.title: redundant-numeric-union (PYI041)
docs.text:
Derived from the flake8-pyi linter.

Fix is sometimes available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for parameter annotations that contain redundant unions between builtin numeric types (e.g., int | float).

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
The typing specification states:

Python’s numeric types complex, float and int are not subtypes of each other, but to support common use cases, the type system contains a straightforward shortcut: when an argument is annotated as having type float, an argument of type int is acceptable; similar, for an argument annotated as having type complex, arguments of type float or int are acceptable.

As such, a union that includes both int and float is redundant in the specific context of a parameter annotation, as it is equivalent to a union that only includes float. For readability and clarity, unions should omit redundant elements.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
def foo(x: float | int | str) -> None: ...

Use instead:

def foo(x: float | str) -> None: ...

docs.title: Fix safety
docs.text:
This rule's fix is marked as safe, unless the type annotation contains comments.

Note that while the fix may flatten nested unions into a single top-level union, the semantics of the annotation will remain unchanged.

docs.title: References
docs.text:
• Python documentation: The numeric tower
  • PEP 484: The numeric tower

docs.text: Redundant open mode arguments are unnecessary and should be removed to avoid confusion.

with open("foo.txt", "r") as f:
    ...

Use instead:

with open("foo.txt") as f:

docs.title: redundant-tuple-in-exception-handler (B013)
docs.text:
Derived from the flake8-bugbear linter.

Fix is always available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text:
Checks for single-element tuples in exception handlers (e.g., except (ValueError,):).

Note: Single-element tuples consisting of a starred expression are allowed.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: A tuple with a single element can be more concisely and idiomatically expressed as a single value.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
try:
    ...
except (ValueError,):
    ...

Use instead:

try:
    ...
except ValueError:
    ...

docs.title: regex-flag-alias (FURB167)
docs.text:
Derived from the refurb linter.

Fix is always available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for the use of shorthand aliases for regular expression flags (e.g., re.I instead of re.IGNORECASE).

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: The regular expression module provides descriptive names for each flag, along with single-letter aliases. Prefer the descriptive names, as they are more readable and self-documenting.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
import re

if re.match("^hello", "hello world", re.I):
    ...

Use instead:

import re

if re.match("^hello", "hello world", re.IGNORECASE):
    ...

docs.title: reimplemented-builtin (SIM110)
docs.text:
Derived from the flake8-simplify linter.

Fix is sometimes available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for for loops that can be replaced with a builtin function, like any or all.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: Using a builtin function is more concise and readable.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
def foo():
    for item in iterable:
        if predicate(item):
            return True
    return False

Use instead:

def foo():
    return any(predicate(item) for item in iterable)

docs.title: Fix safety
docs.text: This fix is always marked as unsafe because it might remove comments.

docs.text:
• Python documentation: any
  • Python documentation: all

docs.title: reimplemented-container-builtin (PIE807)
docs.text:
Derived from the flake8-pie linter.

Fix is sometimes available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for lambdas that can be replaced with the list or dict builtins.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: Using container builtins are more succinct and idiomatic than wrapping the literal in a lambda.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
from dataclasses import dataclass, field


@dataclass
class Foo:
    bar: list[int] = field(default_factory=lambda: [])

Use instead:

from dataclasses import dataclass, field


@dataclass
class Foo:
    bar: list[int] = field(default_factory=list)
    baz: dict[str, int] = field(default_factory=dict)

docs.text: • Python documentation: list

docs.title: reimplemented-operator (FURB118)
docs.text:
Derived from the refurb linter.

Fix is sometimes available.

This rule is unstable and in preview. The --preview flag is required for use.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for lambda expressions and function definitions that can be replaced with a function from the operator module.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: The operator module provides functions that implement the same functionality as the corresponding operators. For example, operator.add is often equivalent to lambda x, y: x + y. Using the functions from the operator module is more concise and communicates the intent of the code more clearly.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
import functools

nums = [1, 2, 3]
total = functools.reduce(lambda x, y: x + y, nums)

Use instead:

import functools
import operator

nums = [1, 2, 3]
total = functools.reduce(operator.add, nums)

docs.title: Fix safety
docs.text:
The fix offered by this rule is always marked as unsafe. While the changes the fix would make would rarely break your code, there are two ways in which functions from the operator module differ from user-defined functions. It would be non-trivial for Ruff to detect whether or not these differences would matter in a specific situation where Ruff is emitting a diagnostic for this rule.

The first difference is that operator functions cannot be called with keyword arguments, but most user-defined functions can. If an add function is defined as add = lambda x, y: x + y, replacing this function with operator.add will cause the later call to raise TypeError if the function is later called with keyword arguments, e.g. add(x=1, y=2).

The second difference is that user-defined functions are descriptors, but this is not true of the functions defined in the operator module. Practically speaking, this means that defining a function in a class body (either by using a def statement or assigning a lambda function to a variable) is a valid way of defining an instance method on that class; monkeypatching a user-defined function onto a class after the class has been created also has the same effect. The same is not true of an operator function: assigning an operator function to a variable in a class body or monkeypatching one onto a class will not create a valid instance method. Ruff will refrain from emitting diagnostics for this rule on function definitions in class bodies; however, it does not currently have sophisticated enough type inference to avoid emitting this diagnostic if a user-defined function is being monkeypatched onto a class after the class has been constructed.

docs.title: reimplemented-starmap (FURB140)
docs.text:
Derived from the refurb linter.

Fix is sometimes available.

This rule is unstable and in preview. The --preview flag is required for use.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for generator expressions, list and set comprehensions that can be replaced with itertools.starmap.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
When unpacking values from iterators to pass them directly to a function, prefer itertools.starmap.

Using itertools.starmap is more concise and readable. Furthermore, it is more efficient than generator expressions, and in some versions of Python, it is more efficient than comprehensions.

docs.title: Known problems
docs.text: Since Python 3.12, itertools.starmap is less efficient than comprehensions (#7771). This is due to PEP 709, which made comprehensions faster.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
all(predicate(a, b) for a, b in some_iterable)

Use instead:

from itertools import starmap


all(starmap(predicate, some_iterable))

docs.title: References
docs.text: • Python documentation: itertools.starmap

docs.title: relative-imports (TID252)
docs.text:
Derived from the flake8-tidy-imports linter.

Fix is sometimes available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for relative imports.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
Absolute imports, or relative imports from siblings, are recommended by PEP 8:

Absolute imports are recommended, as they are usually more readable and tend to be better behaved...

import mypkg.sibling
from mypkg import sibling
from mypkg.sibling import example

However, explicit relative imports are an acceptable alternative to absolute imports, especially when dealing with complex package layouts where using absolute imports would be unnecessarily verbose:

from . import sibling
from .sibling import example

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
from .. import foo

Use instead:

from mypkg import foo

docs.title: Options
docs.text: • lint.flake8-tidy-imports.ban-relative-imports

docs.title: repeated-append (FURB113)
docs.text:
Derived from the refurb linter.

Fix is sometimes available.

This rule is unstable and in preview. The --preview flag is required for use.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for consecutive calls to append.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: Consecutive calls to append can be less efficient than batching them into a single extend. Each append resizes the list individually, whereas an extend can resize the list once for all elements.

docs.title: Known problems
docs.text: This rule is prone to false negatives due to type inference limitations, as it will only detect lists that are instantiated as literals or annotated with a type annotation.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
nums = [1, 2, 3]

nums.append(4)
nums.append(5)
nums.append(6)

Use instead:

nums = [1, 2, 3]

nums.extend((4, 5, 6))

docs.title: References
docs.text: • Python documentation: More on Lists

docs.title: repeated-equality-comparison (PLR1714)
docs.text:
Derived from the Pylint linter.

Fix is always available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text:
Checks for repeated equality comparisons that can be rewritten as a membership test.

This rule will try to determine if the values are hashable and the fix will use a set if they are. If unable to determine, the fix will use a tuple and suggest the use of a set.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
To check if a variable is equal to one of many values, it is common to write a series of equality comparisons (e.g., foo == "bar" or foo == "baz").

Instead, prefer to combine the values into a collection and use the in operator to check for membership, which is more performant and succinct. If the items are hashable, use a set for efficiency; otherwise, use a tuple.

docs.title: Fix safety
docs.text: This rule is always unsafe since literal sets and tuples evaluate their members eagerly whereas or comparisons are short-circuited. It is therefore possible that a fix will change behavior in the presence of side-effects.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
foo == "bar" or foo == "baz" or foo == "qux"

Use instead:

foo in {"bar", "baz", "qux"}

docs.title: References
docs.text:
• Python documentation: Comparisons
  • Python documentation: Membership test operations
  • Python documentation: set

docs.title: repeated-global (FURB154)
docs.text:
Derived from the refurb linter.

Fix is always available.

This rule is unstable and in preview. The --preview flag is required for use.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for consecutive global (or nonlocal) statements.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: The global and nonlocal keywords accepts multiple comma-separated names. Instead of using multiple global (or nonlocal) statements for separate variables, you can use a single statement to declare multiple variables at once.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
def func():
    global x
    global y

    print(x, y)

Use instead:

def func():
    global x, y

    print(x, y)
