  • Python documentation: the nonlocal statement

docs.title: repeated-isinstance-calls (PLR1701)
docs.text:
Derived from the Pylint linter.

Warning: This rule has been removed and its documentation is only available for historical reasons.

Fix is always available.

docs.title: Removed
docs.text: This rule is identical to SIM101 which should be used instead.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for repeated isinstance calls on the same object.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: Repeated isinstance calls on the same object can be merged into a single call.

docs.title: Fix safety
docs.text:
This rule's fix is marked as unsafe on Python 3.10 and later, as combining multiple isinstance calls with a binary operator (|) will fail at runtime if any of the operands are themselves tuples.

For example, given TYPES = (dict, list), then isinstance(None, TYPES | set | float) will raise a TypeError at runtime, while isinstance(None, set | float) will not.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
def is_number(x):
    return isinstance(x, int) or isinstance(x, float) or isinstance(x, complex)

Use instead:

def is_number(x):
    return isinstance(x, (int, float, complex))

Or, for Python 3.10 and later:

def is_number(x):
    return isinstance(x, int | float | complex)

docs.title: Options
docs.text: • target-version

docs.text: • Python documentation: isinstance

docs.title: repeated-keyword-argument (PLE1132)
docs.text: Derived from the Pylint linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for repeated keyword arguments in function calls.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: Python does not allow repeated keyword arguments in function calls. If a function is called with the same keyword argument multiple times, the interpreter will raise an exception.

docs.title: Example
docs.text: func(1, 2, c=3, **{"c": 4})

docs.title: replace-stdout-stderr (UP022)
docs.text:
Derived from the pyupgrade linter.

Fix is sometimes available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for uses of subprocess.run that send stdout and stderr to a pipe.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: As of Python 3.7, subprocess.run has a capture_output keyword argument that can be set to True to capture stdout and stderr outputs. This is equivalent to setting stdout and stderr to subprocess.PIPE, but is more explicit and readable.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
import subprocess

subprocess.run(["foo"], stdout=subprocess.PIPE, stderr=subprocess.PIPE)

Use instead:

import subprocess

subprocess.run(["foo"], capture_output=True)

docs.title: Fix safety
docs.text: This rule's fix is marked as unsafe because replacing stdout=subprocess.PIPE and stderr=subprocess.PIPE with capture_output=True may delete comments attached to the original arguments.

docs.title: References
docs.text:
• Python 3.7 release notes
  • Python documentation: subprocess.run

docs.title: replace-str-enum (UP042)
docs.text:
Derived from the pyupgrade linter.

Fix is sometimes available.

This rule is unstable and in preview. The --preview flag is required for use.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for classes that inherit from both str and enum.Enum.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: Python 3.11 introduced enum.StrEnum, which is preferred over inheriting from both str and enum.Enum.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
import enum


class Foo(str, enum.Enum): ...

Use instead:

import enum


class Foo(enum.StrEnum): ...

docs.title: Fix safety
docs.text:
Python 3.11 introduced a breaking change for enums that inherit from both str and enum.Enum. Consider the following enum:

from enum import Enum


class Foo(str, Enum):
    BAR = "bar"

In Python 3.11, the formatted representation of Foo.BAR changed as follows:

# Python 3.10
f"{Foo.BAR}"  # > bar
# Python 3.11
f"{Foo.BAR}"  # > Foo.BAR

Migrating from str and enum.Enum to enum.StrEnum will restore the previous behavior, such that:

from enum import StrEnum


class Foo(StrEnum):
    BAR = "bar"


f"{Foo.BAR}"  # > bar

As such, migrating to enum.StrEnum will introduce a behavior change for code that relies on the Python 3.11 behavior.

docs.title: References
docs.text: • enum.StrEnum

docs.title: replace-universal-newlines (UP021)
docs.text:
Derived from the pyupgrade linter.

Fix is always available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for uses of subprocess.run that set the universal_newlines keyword argument.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: As of Python 3.7, the universal_newlines keyword argument has been renamed to text, and now exists for backwards compatibility. The universal_newlines keyword argument may be removed in a future version of Python. Prefer text, which is more explicit and readable.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
import subprocess

subprocess.run(["foo"], universal_newlines=True)

Use instead:

import subprocess

subprocess.run(["foo"], text=True)

docs.title: request-with-no-cert-validation (S501)
docs.text: Derived from the flake8-bandit linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for HTTPS requests that disable SSL certificate checks.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: If SSL certificates are not verified, an attacker could perform a "man in the middle" attack by intercepting and modifying traffic between the client and server.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
import requests

requests.get("https://www.example.com", verify=False)

Use instead:

import requests

requests.get("https://www.example.com")  # By default, `verify=True`.

docs.title: request-without-timeout (S113)
docs.text: Derived from the flake8-bandit linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for uses of the Python requests or httpx module that omit the timeout parameter.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: The timeout parameter is used to set the maximum time to wait for a response from the server. By omitting the timeout parameter, the program may hang indefinitely while awaiting a response.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
import requests

requests.get("https://www.example.com/")

Use instead:

import requests

requests.get("https://www.example.com/", timeout=10)

docs.title: reraise-no-cause (TRY200)
docs.text:
Derived from the tryceratops linter.

Warning: This rule has been removed and its documentation is only available for historical reasons.

docs.title: Removed
docs.text: This rule is identical to B904 which should be used instead.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for exceptions that are re-raised without specifying the cause via the from keyword.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: The from keyword sets the __cause__ attribute of the exception, which stores the "cause" of the exception. The availability of an exception "cause" is useful for debugging.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
def reciprocal(n):
    try:
        return 1 / n
    except ZeroDivisionError:
        raise ValueError()

Use instead:

def reciprocal(n):
    try:
        return 1 / n
    except ZeroDivisionError as exc:
        raise ValueError() from exc

docs.title: References
docs.text: • Python documentation: Exception context

docs.title: return-in-generator (B901)
docs.text:
Derived from the flake8-bugbear linter.

This rule is unstable and in preview. The --preview flag is required for use.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for return {value} statements in functions that also contain yield or yield from statements.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
Using return {value} in a generator function was syntactically invalid in Python 2. In Python 3 return {value} can be used in a generator; however, the combination of yield and return can lead to confusing behavior, as the return statement will cause the generator to raise StopIteration with the value provided, rather than returning the value to the caller.

For example, given:

from collections.abc import Iterable
from pathlib import Path


def get_file_paths(file_types: Iterable[str] | None = None) -> Iterable[Path]:
    dir_path = Path(".")
    if file_types is None:
        return dir_path.glob("*")

    for file_type in file_types:
        yield from dir_path.glob(f"*.{file_type}")

Readers might assume that get_file_paths() would return an iterable of Path objects in the directory; in reality, though, list(get_file_paths()) evaluates to [], since the return statement causes the generator to raise StopIteration with the value dir_path.glob("*"):

>>> list(get_file_paths(file_types=["cfg", "toml"]))
[PosixPath('setup.cfg'), PosixPath('pyproject.toml')]
>>> list(get_file_paths())
[]

For intentional uses of return in a generator, consider suppressing this diagnostic.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
from collections.abc import Iterable
from pathlib import Path


def get_file_paths(file_types: Iterable[str] | None = None) -> Iterable[Path]:
    dir_path = Path(".")
    if file_types is None:
        return dir_path.glob("*")

    for file_type in file_types:
        yield from dir_path.glob(f"*.{file_type}")

Use instead:

from collections.abc import Iterable
from pathlib import Path


def get_file_paths(file_types: Iterable[str] | None = None) -> Iterable[Path]:
    dir_path = Path(".")
    if file_types is None:
        yield from dir_path.glob("*")
    else:
        for file_type in file_types:
            yield from dir_path.glob(f"*.{file_type}")

docs.title: return-in-init (PLE0101)
docs.text: Derived from the Pylint linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for __init__ methods that return values.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
The __init__ method is the constructor for a given Python class, responsible for initializing, rather than creating, new objects.

The __init__ method has to return None. Returning any value from an __init__ method will result in a runtime error.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
class Example:
    def __init__(self):
        return []

Use instead:

class Example:
    def __init__(self):
        self.value = []

docs.title: References
docs.text: • CodeQL: py-explicit-return-in-init

docs.title: return-in-try-except-finally (SIM107)
docs.text: Derived from the flake8-simplify linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for return statements in try-except and finally blocks.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: The return statement in a finally block will always be executed, even if an exception is raised in the try or except block. This can lead to unexpected behavior.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
def squared(n):
    try:
        sqr = n**2
        return sqr
    except Exception:
        return "An exception occurred"
    finally:
        return -1  # Always returns -1.

Use instead:

def squared(n):
    try:
        return_value = n**2
    except Exception:
        return_value = "An exception occurred"
    finally:
        return_value = -1
    return return_value

docs.title: References
docs.text: • Python documentation: Defining Clean-up Actions

docs.title: return-outside-function (F706)
docs.text: Derived from the Pyflakes linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for return statements outside of functions.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: The use of a return statement outside of a function will raise a SyntaxError.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
class Foo:
    return 1

docs.title: References
docs.text: • Python documentation: return

docs.title: reuse-of-groupby-generator (B031)
docs.text: Derived from the flake8-bugbear linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for multiple usage of the generator returned from itertools.groupby().

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: Using the generator more than once will do nothing on the second usage. If that data is needed later, it should be stored as a list.

docs.title: Example:
docs.text:
import itertools

for name, group in itertools.groupby(data):
    for _ in range(5):
        do_something_with_the_group(group)

Use instead:

import itertools

for name, group in itertools.groupby(data):
    values = list(group)
    for _ in range(5):
        do_something_with_the_group(values)

docs.title: root-logger-call (LOG015)
docs.text: Derived from the flake8-logging linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for usages of the following logging top-level functions: debug, info, warn, warning, error, critical, log, exception.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: Using the root logger causes the messages to have no source information, making them less useful for debugging.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
import logging

logging.info("Foobar")

Use instead:

import logging

logger = logging.getLogger(__name__)
logger.info("Foobar")

docs.title: ruff-static-key-dict-comprehension (RUF011)
docs.text: Warning: This rule has been removed and its documentation is only available for historical reasons.

docs.title: Removed
docs.text: This rule was implemented in flake8-bugbear and has been remapped to B035

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for dictionary comprehensions that use a static key, like a string literal or a variable defined outside the comprehension.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: Using a static key (like a string literal) in a dictionary comprehension is usually a mistake, as it will result in a dictionary with only one key, despite the comprehension iterating over multiple values.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
data = ["some", "Data"]
{"key": value.upper() for value in data}

Use instead:

data = ["some", "Data"]
{value: value.upper() for value in data}

docs.title: ruff-unsafe-markup-use (RUF035)
docs.text: Warning: This rule has been removed and its documentation is only available for historical reasons.

docs.title: Removed
docs.text: This rule was implemented in bandit and has been remapped to S704

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for non-literal strings being passed to markupsafe.Markup.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
markupsafe.Markup does not perform any escaping, so passing dynamic content, like f-strings, variables or interpolated strings will potentially lead to XSS vulnerabilities.

Instead you should interpolate the Markup object.

Using lint.flake8-bandit.extend-markup-names additional objects can be treated like Markup.

This rule was originally inspired by flake8-markupsafe but doesn't carve out any exceptions for i18n related calls by default.

You can use lint.flake8-bandit.allowed-markup-calls to specify exceptions.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
Given:

from markupsafe import Markup

content = "<script>alert('Hello, world!')</script>"
html = Markup(f"<b>{content}</b>")  # XSS

Use instead:

from markupsafe import Markup

content = "<script>alert('Hello, world!')</script>"
html = Markup("<b>{}</b>").format(content)  # Safe

Given:

from markupsafe import Markup

lines = [
    Markup("<b>heading</b>"),
    "<script>alert('XSS attempt')</script>",
]
html = Markup("<br>".join(lines))  # XSS

Use instead:

from markupsafe import Markup

lines = [
    Markup("<b>heading</b>"),
    "<script>alert('XSS attempt')</script>",
]
html = Markup("<br>").join(lines)  # Safe

docs.text:

  • lint.flake8-bandit.allowed-markup-calls

docs.text:

docs.title: run-process-in-async-function (ASYNC221)
docs.text: Derived from the flake8-async linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks that async functions do not run processes with blocking methods.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
Blocking an async function via a blocking call will block the entire event loop, preventing it from executing other tasks while waiting for the call to complete, negating the benefits of asynchronous programming.

Instead of making a blocking call, use an equivalent asynchronous library or function, like trio.run_process() or anyio.run_process().

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
import subprocess


async def foo():
    subprocess.run(cmd)

Use instead:

import asyncio


async def foo():
    asyncio.create_subprocess_shell(cmd)

docs.title: runtime-cast-value (TC006)
docs.text:
Derived from the flake8-type-checking linter.

Fix is always available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for unquoted type expressions in typing.cast() calls.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
This rule helps enforce a consistent style across your codebase.

It's often necessary to quote the first argument passed to cast(), as type expressions can involve forward references, or references to symbols which are only imported in typing.TYPE_CHECKING blocks. This can lead to a visual inconsistency across different cast() calls, where some type expressions are quoted but others are not. By enabling this rule, you ensure that all type expressions passed to cast() are quoted, enforcing stylistic consistency across all of your cast() calls.

In some cases where cast() is used in a hot loop, this rule may also help avoid overhead from repeatedly evaluating complex type expressions at runtime.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
from typing import cast

x = cast(dict[str, int], foo)

Use instead:

from typing import cast

x = cast("dict[str, int]", foo)

docs.title: Fix safety
docs.text: This fix is safe as long as the type expression doesn't span multiple lines and includes comments on any of the lines apart from the last one.

docs.title: runtime-import-in-type-checking-block (TC004)
docs.text:
Derived from the flake8-type-checking linter.

Fix is sometimes available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for imports that are required at runtime but are only defined in type-checking blocks.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
The type-checking block is not executed at runtime, so if the only definition of a symbol is in a type-checking block, it will not be available at runtime.

If lint.flake8-type-checking.quote-annotations is set to true, annotations will be wrapped in quotes if doing so would enable the corresponding import to remain in the type-checking block.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
from typing import TYPE_CHECKING

if TYPE_CHECKING:
    import foo


def bar() -> None:
    foo.bar()  # raises NameError: name 'foo' is not defined

Use instead:

import foo


def bar() -> None:
    foo.bar()

docs.title: Options
docs.text: • lint.flake8-type-checking.quote-annotations

docs.title: References
docs.text: • PEP 563: Runtime annotation resolution and TYPE_CHECKING

docs.title: runtime-string-union (TC010)
docs.text: Derived from the flake8-type-checking linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for the presence of string literals in X | Y-style union types.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
PEP 604 introduced a new syntax for union type annotations based on the | operator.

While Python's type annotations can typically be wrapped in strings to avoid runtime evaluation, the use of a string member within an X | Y-style union type will cause a runtime error.

Instead, remove the quotes, wrap the entire union in quotes, or use from __future__ import annotations to disable runtime evaluation of annotations entirely.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
var: "Foo" | None


class Foo: ...

Use instead:

from __future__ import annotations

var: Foo | None


class Foo: ...

Or, extend the quotes to include the entire union:

var: "Foo | None"


class Foo: ...

docs.title: References
docs.text:
• PEP 563 - Postponed Evaluation of Annotations
  • PEP 604 – Allow writing union types as X | Y

docs.title: self-assigning-variable (PLW0127)
docs.text: Derived from the Pylint linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for self-assignment of variables.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: Self-assignment of variables is redundant and likely a mistake.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
country = "Poland"
country = country

Use instead:

country = "Poland"

docs.title: self-or-cls-assignment (PLW0642)
docs.text: Derived from the Pylint linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text:
Checks for assignment of self and cls in instance and class methods respectively.

This check also applies to __new__ even though this is technically a static method.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: The identifiers self and cls are conventional in Python for the first parameter of instance methods and class methods, respectively. Assigning new values to these variables can be confusing for others reading your code; using a different variable name can lead to clearer code.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
class Version:
    def add(self, other):
        self = self + other
        return self

    @classmethod
    def superclass(cls):
        cls = cls.__mro__[-1]
        return cls

Use instead:

class Version:
    def add(self, other):
        new_version = self + other
        return new_version

    @classmethod
    def superclass(cls):
        supercls = cls.__mro__[-1]
        return supercls

docs.title: set-attr-with-constant (B010)
docs.text:
Derived from the flake8-bugbear linter.

Fix is always available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for uses of setattr that take a constant attribute value as an argument (e.g., setattr(obj, "foo", 42)).

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: setattr is used to set attributes dynamically. If the attribute is defined as a constant, it is no safer than a typical property access. When possible, prefer property access over setattr calls, as the former is more concise and idiomatic.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
setattr(obj, "foo", 42)

Use instead:

obj.foo = 42

docs.title: References
docs.text: • Python documentation: setattr

docs.title: shallow-copy-environ (PLW1507)
docs.text:
Derived from the Pylint linter.

Fix is always available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Check for shallow os.environ copies.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
os.environ is not a dict object, but rather, a proxy object. As such, mutating a shallow copy of os.environ will also mutate the original object.

See BPO 15373 for more information.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
import copy
import os

env = copy.copy(os.environ)

Use instead:

import os

env = os.environ.copy()

docs.title: Fix safety
docs.text: This rule's fix is marked as unsafe because replacing a shallow copy with a deep copy can lead to unintended side effects. If the program modifies the shallow copy at some point, changing it to a deep copy may prevent those modifications from affecting the original data, potentially altering the program's behavior.

docs.title: References
docs.text:
• Python documentation: copy — Shallow and deep copy operations
  • Python documentation: os.environ

docs.title: shebang-leading-whitespace (EXE004)
docs.text:
Derived from the flake8-executable linter.

Fix is always available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for whitespace before a shebang directive.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
In Python, a shebang (also known as a hashbang) is the first line of a script, which specifies the interpreter that should be used to run the script.

The shebang's #! prefix must be the first two characters of a file. The presence of whitespace before the shebang will cause the shebang to be ignored, which is likely a mistake.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
#!/usr/bin/env python3

Use instead:

#!/usr/bin/env python3

docs.title: References
docs.text: • Python documentation: Executable Python Scripts

docs.title: shebang-missing-executable-file (EXE002)
docs.text: Derived from the flake8-executable linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for executable .py files that do not have a shebang.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
In Python, a shebang (also known as a hashbang) is the first line of a script, which specifies the interpreter that should be used to run the script.

If a .py file is executable, but does not have a shebang, it may be run with the wrong interpreter, or fail to run at all.

If the file is meant to be executable, add a shebang, as in:

#!/usr/bin/env python

Otherwise, remove the executable bit from the file (e.g., chmod -x __main__.py or git update-index --chmod=-x __main__.py).

A file is considered executable if it has the executable bit set (i.e., its permissions mode intersects with 0o111). As such, this rule is only available on Unix-like systems, and is not enforced on Windows or WSL.

docs.title: References
docs.text:
• Python documentation: Executable Python Scripts
  • Git documentation: git update-index --chmod

docs.title: shebang-missing-python (EXE003)
docs.text: Derived from the flake8-executable linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for a shebang directive in .py files that does not contain python, pytest, or uv run.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
In Python, a shebang (also known as a hashbang) is the first line of a script, which specifies the command that should be used to run the script.

For Python scripts, if the shebang does not include a command that explicitly or implicitly specifies an interpreter, then the file will be executed with the default interpreter, which is likely a mistake.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
#!/usr/bin/env bash

Use instead:

#!/usr/bin/env python3

docs.title: References
docs.text: • Python documentation: Executable Python Scripts

docs.title: shebang-not-executable (EXE001)
docs.text: Derived from the flake8-executable linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for a shebang directive in a file that is not executable.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
In Python, a shebang (also known as a hashbang) is the first line of a script, which specifies the interpreter that should be used to run the script.

The presence of a shebang suggests that a file is intended to be executable. If a file contains a shebang but is not executable, then the shebang is misleading, or the file is missing the executable bit.

If the file is meant to be executable, add the executable bit to the file (e.g., chmod +x __main__.py or git update-index --chmod=+x __main__.py).

Otherwise, remove the shebang.

A file is considered executable if it has the executable bit set (i.e., its permissions mode intersects with 0o111). As such, this rule is only available on Unix-like systems, and is not enforced on Windows or WSL.

docs.title: Example
docs.text: #!/usr/bin/env python

docs.title: References
docs.text:
• Python documentation: Executable Python Scripts
  • Git documentation: git update-index --chmod

docs.title: shebang-not-first-line (EXE005)
docs.text: Derived from the flake8-executable linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for a shebang directive that is not at the beginning of the file.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
In Python, a shebang (also known as a hashbang) is the first line of a script, which specifies the interpreter that should be used to run the script.

The shebang's #! prefix must be the first two characters of a file. If the shebang is not at the beginning of the file, it will be ignored, which is likely a mistake.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
foo = 1
#!/usr/bin/env python3

Use instead:

#!/usr/bin/env python3
foo = 1

docs.title: References
docs.text: • Python documentation: Executable Python Scripts

docs.title: signature-in-docstring (D402)
docs.text: Derived from the pydocstyle linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for function docstrings that include the function's signature in the summary line.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
PEP 257 recommends against including a function's signature in its docstring. Instead, consider using type annotations as a form of documentation for the function's parameters and return value.

This rule may not apply to all projects; its applicability is a matter of convention. By default, this rule is enabled when using the google and pep257 conventions, and disabled when using the numpy convention.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
def foo(a, b):
    """foo(a: int, b: int) -> list[int]"""

Use instead:

def foo(a: int, b: int) -> list[int]:
    """Return a list of a and b."""

docs.title: Options
docs.text: • lint.pydocstyle.convention

docs.title: References
docs.text:
• PEP 257 – Docstring Conventions
  • NumPy Style Guide
  • Google Python Style Guide - Docstrings

docs.title: single-item-membership-test (FURB171)
docs.text:
Derived from the refurb linter.

Fix is sometimes available.

This rule is unstable and in preview. The --preview flag is required for use.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for membership tests against single-item containers.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: Performing a membership test against a container (like a list or set) with a single item is less readable and less efficient than comparing against the item directly.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
1 in [1]

Use instead:

1 == 1

docs.title: Fix safety
docs.text:
When the right-hand side is a string, the fix is marked as unsafe. This is because c in "a" is true both when c is "a" and when c is the empty string, so the fix can change the behavior of your program in these cases.

Additionally, if there are comments within the fix's range, it will also be marked as unsafe.

docs.title: References
docs.text:
• Python documentation: Comparisons
  • Python documentation: Membership test operations

docs.title: single-line-implicit-string-concatenation (ISC001)
docs.text:
Derived from the flake8-implicit-str-concat linter.

Fix is sometimes available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for implicitly concatenated strings on a single line.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
While it is valid Python syntax to concatenate multiple string or byte literals implicitly (via whitespace delimiters), it is unnecessary and negatively affects code readability.

In some cases, the implicit concatenation may also be unintentional, as code formatters are capable of introducing single-line implicit concatenations when collapsing long lines.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
z = "The quick " "brown fox."

Use instead:

z = "The quick brown fox."

docs.title: single-string-slots (PLC0205)
docs.text: Derived from the Pylint linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for single strings assigned to __slots__.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
In Python, the __slots__ attribute allows you to explicitly define the attributes (instance variables) that a class can have. By default, Python uses a dictionary to store an object's attributes, which incurs some memory overhead. However, when __slots__ is defined, Python uses a more compact internal structure to store the object's attributes, resulting in memory savings.

Any string iterable may be assigned to __slots__ (most commonly, a tuple of strings). If a string is assigned to __slots__, it is interpreted as a single attribute name, rather than an iterable of attribute names. This can cause confusion, as users that iterate over the __slots__ value may expect to iterate over a sequence of attributes, but would instead iterate over the characters of the string.

To use a single string attribute in __slots__, wrap the string in an iterable container type, like a tuple.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
class Person:
    __slots__: str = "name"

    def __init__(self, name: str) -> None:
        self.name = name

Use instead:

class Person:
    __slots__: tuple[str, ...] = ("name",)

    def __init__(self, name: str) -> None:
        self.name = name

docs.title: References
docs.text: • Python documentation: __slots__

docs.title: singledispatch-method (PLE1519)
docs.text:
Derived from the Pylint linter.

Fix is sometimes available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for methods decorated with @singledispatch.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
The @singledispatch decorator is intended for use with functions, not methods.

Instead, use the @singledispatchmethod decorator, or migrate the method to a standalone function.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
from functools import singledispatch


class Class:
    @singledispatch
    def method(self, arg): ...

Use instead:

from functools import singledispatchmethod


class Class:
    @singledispatchmethod
    def method(self, arg): ...

docs.title: Fix safety
docs.text: This rule's fix is marked as unsafe, as migrating from @singledispatch to @singledispatchmethod may change the behavior of the code.

docs.title: singledispatchmethod-function (PLE1520)
docs.text:
Derived from the Pylint linter.

Fix is sometimes available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for non-method functions decorated with @singledispatchmethod.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
The @singledispatchmethod decorator is intended for use with methods, not functions.

Instead, use the @singledispatch decorator.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
from functools import singledispatchmethod


@singledispatchmethod
def func(arg): ...

Use instead:

from functools import singledispatch


@singledispatch
def func(arg): ...

docs.title: Fix safety
docs.text: This rule's fix is marked as unsafe, as migrating from @singledispatchmethod to @singledispatch may change the behavior of the code.

docs.title: six-py3 (YTT202)
docs.text: Derived from the flake8-2020 linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for uses of six.PY3.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
six.PY3 will evaluate to False on Python 4 and greater. This is likely unintended, and may cause code intended to run on Python 2 to run on Python 4 too.

Instead, use not six.PY2 to validate that the current Python major version is not equal to 2, to future-proof the code.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
import six

six.PY3  # `False` on Python 4.

Use instead:

import six

not six.PY2  # `True` on Python 4.

docs.title: References
docs.text:
• PyPI: six
  • Six documentation: six.PY2
  • Six documentation: six.PY3

docs.title: slice-copy (FURB145)
docs.text:
Derived from the refurb linter.

Fix is sometimes available.

This rule is unstable and in preview. The --preview flag is required for use.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for unbounded slice expressions to copy a list.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: The list.copy method is more readable and consistent with copying other types.

docs.title: Known problems
docs.text: This rule is prone to false negatives due to type inference limitations, as it will only detect lists that are instantiated as literals or annotated with a type annotation.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
a = [1, 2, 3]
b = a[:]

Use instead:

a = [1, 2, 3]
b = a.copy()

docs.title: References
docs.text: • Python documentation: Mutable Sequence Types

docs.title: slice-to-remove-prefix-or-suffix (FURB188)
docs.text:
Derived from the refurb linter.

Fix is always available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text:
Checks for code that could be written more idiomatically using str.removeprefix() or str.removesuffix().

Specifically, the rule flags code that conditionally removes a prefix or suffix using a slice operation following an if test that uses str.startswith() or str.endswith().

The rule is only applied if your project targets Python 3.9 or later.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: The methods str.removeprefix() and str.removesuffix(), introduced in Python 3.9, have the same behavior while being more readable and efficient.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
def example(filename: str, text: str):
    filename = filename[:-4] if filename.endswith(".txt") else filename

    if text.startswith("pre"):
        text = text[3:]

Use instead:

def example(filename: str, text: str):
    filename = filename.removesuffix(".txt")
    text = text.removeprefix("pre")

docs.title: snake-case-type-alias (PYI042)
docs.text: Derived from the flake8-pyi linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for type aliases that do not use the CamelCase naming convention.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: It's conventional to use the CamelCase naming convention for type aliases, to distinguish them from other variables.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
from typing import TypeAlias

type_alias_name: TypeAlias = int

Use instead:

from typing import TypeAlias

TypeAliasName: TypeAlias = int

docs.title: snmp-insecure-version (S508)
docs.text: Derived from the flake8-bandit linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for uses of SNMPv1 or SNMPv2.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: The SNMPv1 and SNMPv2 protocols are considered insecure as they do not support encryption. Instead, prefer SNMPv3, which supports encryption.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
from pysnmp.hlapi import CommunityData

CommunityData("public", mpModel=0)

Use instead:

from pysnmp.hlapi import CommunityData

CommunityData("public", mpModel=2)

docs.title: References
docs.text:
• Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA): Alert TA17-156A
  • Common Weakness Enumeration: CWE-319

docs.title: snmp-weak-cryptography (S509)
docs.text: Derived from the flake8-bandit linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for uses of the SNMPv3 protocol without encryption.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: Unencrypted SNMPv3 communication can be intercepted and read by unauthorized parties. Instead, enable encryption when using SNMPv3.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
from pysnmp.hlapi import UsmUserData

UsmUserData("user")

Use instead:

from pysnmp.hlapi import UsmUserData

UsmUserData("user", "authkey", "privkey")

docs.title: References
docs.text: • Common Weakness Enumeration: CWE-319

docs.title: sorted-min-max (FURB192)
docs.text:
Derived from the refurb linter.

Fix is sometimes available.

This rule is unstable and in preview. The --preview flag is required for use.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for uses of sorted() to retrieve the minimum or maximum value in a sequence.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: Using sorted() to compute the minimum or maximum value in a sequence is inefficient and less readable than using min() or max() directly.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
nums = [3, 1, 4, 1, 5]
lowest = sorted(nums)[0]
highest = sorted(nums)[-1]
highest = sorted(nums, reverse=True)[0]

Use instead:

nums = [3, 1, 4, 1, 5]
lowest = min(nums)
highest = max(nums)

docs.title: Fix safety
docs.text:
In some cases, migrating to min or max can lead to a change in behavior, notably when breaking ties.

As an example, sorted(data, key=itemgetter(0), reverse=True)[0] will return the last "minimum" element in the list, if there are multiple elements with the same key. However, min(data, key=itemgetter(0)) will return the first "minimum" element in the list in the same scenario.

As such, this rule's fix is marked as unsafe when the reverse keyword is used.

docs.title: References
docs.text:
• Python documentation: min
  • Python documentation: max

docs.title: split-static-string (SIM905)
docs.text:
Derived from the flake8-simplify linter.

Fix is sometimes available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for static str.split calls that can be replaced with list literals.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: List literals are more readable and do not require the overhead of calling str.split.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
"a,b,c,d".split(",")

Use instead:

["a", "b", "c", "d"]

docs.title: Fix safety
docs.text:
This rule's fix is marked as unsafe for implicit string concatenations with comments interleaved between segments, as comments may be removed.

For example, the fix would be marked as unsafe in the following case:

(
    "a"  # comment
    ","  # comment
    "b"  # comment
).split(",")

as this is converted to ["a", "b"] without any of the comments.

docs.title: References
docs.text: • Python documentation: str.split

docs.title: ssh-no-host-key-verification (S507)
docs.text: Derived from the flake8-bandit linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for uses of policies disabling SSH verification in Paramiko.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: By default, Paramiko checks the identity of the remote host when establishing an SSH connection. Disabling the verification might lead to the client connecting to a malicious host, without the client knowing.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
from paramiko import client

ssh_client = client.SSHClient()
ssh_client.set_missing_host_key_policy(client.AutoAddPolicy)

Use instead:

from paramiko import client

ssh_client = client.SSHClient()
ssh_client.set_missing_host_key_policy(client.RejectPolicy)

docs.title: References
docs.text: • Paramiko documentation: set_missing_host_key_policy

docs.title: ssl-insecure-version (S502)
docs.text: Derived from the flake8-bandit linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for function calls with parameters that indicate the use of insecure SSL and TLS protocol versions.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
Several highly publicized exploitable flaws have been discovered in all versions of SSL and early versions of TLS. The following versions are considered insecure, and should be avoided:

  • SSL v2
  • SSL v3
  • TLS v1
  • TLS v1.1

This method supports detection on the Python's built-in ssl module and the pyOpenSSL module.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
import ssl

ssl.wrap_socket(ssl_version=ssl.PROTOCOL_TLSv1)

Use instead:

import ssl

ssl.wrap_socket(ssl_version=ssl.PROTOCOL_TLSv1_2)

docs.title: ssl-with-bad-defaults (S503)
docs.text: Derived from the flake8-bandit linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for function definitions with default arguments set to insecure SSL and TLS protocol versions.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
Several highly publicized exploitable flaws have been discovered in all versions of SSL and early versions of TLS. The following versions are considered insecure, and should be avoided:

  • SSL v2
  • SSL v3
  • TLS v1
  • TLS v1.1

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
import ssl


def func(version=ssl.PROTOCOL_TLSv1): ...

Use instead:

import ssl


def func(version=ssl.PROTOCOL_TLSv1_2): ...

docs.title: ssl-with-no-version (S504)
docs.text: Derived from the flake8-bandit linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for calls to ssl.wrap_socket() without an ssl_version.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: This method is known to provide a default value that maximizes compatibility, but permits use of insecure protocols.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
import ssl

ssl.wrap_socket()

Use instead:

import ssl

ssl.wrap_socket(ssl_version=ssl.PROTOCOL_TLSv1_2)

docs.title: star-arg-unpacking-after-keyword-arg (B026)
docs.text: Derived from the flake8-bugbear linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for function calls that use star-argument unpacking after providing a keyword argument

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
In Python, you can use star-argument unpacking to pass a list or tuple of arguments to a function.

Providing a star-argument after a keyword argument can lead to confusing behavior, and is only supported for backwards compatibility.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
def foo(x, y, z):
    return x, y, z


foo(1, 2, 3)  # (1, 2, 3)
foo(1, *[2, 3])  # (1, 2, 3)
# foo(x=1, *[2, 3])  # TypeError
# foo(y=2, *[1, 3])  # TypeError
foo(z=3, *[1, 2])  # (1, 2, 3)  # No error, but confusing!

Use instead:

def foo(x, y, z):
    return x, y, z


foo(1, 2, 3)  # (1, 2, 3)
foo(x=1, y=2, z=3)  # (1, 2, 3)
foo(*[1, 2, 3])  # (1, 2, 3)
foo(*[1, 2], 3)  # (1, 2, 3)

docs.title: References
docs.text:
• Python documentation: Calls
  • Disallow iterable argument unpacking after a keyword argument?

docs.title: starmap-zip (RUF058)
docs.text: Fix is sometimes available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for itertools.starmap calls where the second argument is a zip call.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: zip-ping iterables only to unpack them later from within starmap is unnecessary. For such cases, map() should be used instead.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
from itertools import starmap


starmap(func, zip(a, b))
starmap(func, zip(a, b, strict=True))

Use instead:

map(func, a, b)
map(func, a, b, strict=True)  # 3.14+

docs.title: Fix safety
docs.text: This rule's fix is marked as unsafe if the starmap or zip expressions contain comments that would be deleted by applying the fix. Otherwise, the fix can be applied safely.

docs.title: Fix availability
docs.text: This rule will emit a diagnostic but not suggest a fix if map has been shadowed from its builtin binding.

docs.title: start-process-with-a-shell (S605)
docs.text: Derived from the flake8-bandit linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for calls that start a process with a shell, providing guidance on whether the usage is safe or not.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
Starting a process with a shell can introduce security risks, such as code injection vulnerabilities. It's important to be aware of whether the usage of the shell is safe or not.

This rule triggers on functions like os.system, popen, etc., which start processes with a shell. It evaluates whether the provided command is a literal string or an expression. If the command is a literal string, it's considered safe. If the command is an expression, it's considered (potentially) unsafe.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
import os

# Safe usage (literal string)
command = "ls -l"
os.system(command)

# Potentially unsafe usage (expression)
cmd = get_user_input()
os.system(cmd)

docs.title: Note
docs.text: The subprocess module provides more powerful facilities for spawning new processes and retrieving their results, and using that module is preferable to using os.system or similar functions. Consider replacing such usages with subprocess.call or related functions.

docs.title: References
docs.text: • Python documentation: subprocess

docs.title: start-process-with-no-shell (S606)
docs.text: Derived from the flake8-bandit linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for functions that start a process without a shell.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
Invoking any kind of external executable via a function call can pose security risks if arbitrary variables are passed to the executable, or if the input is otherwise unsanitised or unvalidated.

This rule specifically flags functions in the os module that spawn subprocesses without the use of a shell. Note that these typically pose a much smaller security risk than subprocesses that are started with a shell, which are flagged by start-process-with-a-shell (S605). This gives you the option of enabling one rule while disabling the other if you decide that the security risk from these functions is acceptable for your use case.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
import os


def insecure_function(arbitrary_user_input: str):
    os.spawnlp(os.P_NOWAIT, "/bin/mycmd", "mycmd", arbitrary_user_input)

docs.title: start-process-with-partial-path (S607)
docs.text: Derived from the flake8-bandit linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for the starting of a process with a partial executable path.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: Starting a process with a partial executable path can allow attackers to execute an arbitrary executable by adjusting the PATH environment variable. Consider using a full path to the executable instead.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
import subprocess

subprocess.Popen(["ruff", "check", "file.py"])

Use instead:

import subprocess

subprocess.Popen(["/usr/bin/ruff", "check", "file.py"])

docs.title: References
docs.text:
• Python documentation: subprocess.Popen()
  • Common Weakness Enumeration: CWE-426

docs.title: static-join-to-f-string (FLY002)
docs.text:
Derived from the flynt linter.

Fix is always available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for str.join calls that can be replaced with f-strings.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: f-strings are more readable and generally preferred over str.join calls.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
" ".join((foo, bar))

Use instead:

f"{foo} {bar}"

docs.title: Fix safety
docs.text: The fix is always marked unsafe because the evaluation of the f-string expressions will default to calling the __format__ method of each object, whereas str.join expects each object to be an instance of str and uses the corresponding string. Therefore it is possible for the values of the resulting strings to differ, or for one expression to raise an exception while the other does not.

docs.title: References
docs.text: • Python documentation: f-strings

docs.title: static-key-dict-comprehension (B035)
docs.text: Derived from the flake8-bugbear linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for dictionary comprehensions that use a static key, like a string literal or a variable defined outside the comprehension.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: Using a static key (like a string literal) in a dictionary comprehension is usually a mistake, as it will result in a dictionary with only one key, despite the comprehension iterating over multiple values.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
data = ["some", "Data"]
{"key": value.upper() for value in data}

Use instead:

data = ["some", "Data"]
{value: value.upper() for value in data}

docs.title: stdlib-module-shadowing (A005)
docs.text: Derived from the flake8-builtins linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for modules that use the same names as Python standard-library modules.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
Reusing a standard-library module name for the name of a module increases the difficulty of reading and maintaining the code, and can cause non-obvious errors. Readers may mistake the first-party module for the standard-library module and vice versa.

Standard-library modules can be marked as exceptions to this rule via the lint.flake8-builtins.allowed-modules configuration option.

By default, the module path relative to the project root or src directories is considered, so a top-level logging.py or logging/__init__.py will clash with the builtin logging module, but utils/logging.py, for example, will not. With the lint.flake8-builtins.strict-checking option set to true, only the last component of the module name is considered, so logging.py, utils/logging.py, and utils/logging/__init__.py will all trigger the rule.

This rule is not applied to stub files, as the name of a stub module is out of the control of the author of the stub file. Instead, a stub should aim to faithfully emulate the runtime module it is stubbing.

As of Python 3.13, errors from modules that use the same name as standard-library modules now display a custom message.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
$ touch random.py
$ python3 -c 'from random import choice'
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<string>", line 1, in <module>
    from random import choice
ImportError: cannot import name 'choice' from 'random' (consider renaming '/random.py' since it has the same name as the standard library module named 'random' and prevents importing that standard library module)

docs.title: Options
docs.text:
• lint.flake8-builtins.allowed-modules
  • lint.flake8-builtins.strict-checking

docs.title: str-or-repr-defined-in-stub (PYI029)
docs.text:
Derived from the flake8-pyi linter.

Fix is always available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for redundant definitions of __str__ or __repr__ in stubs.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: Defining __str__ or __repr__ in a stub is almost always redundant, as the signatures are almost always identical to those of the default equivalent, object.__str__ and object.__repr__, respectively.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
class Foo:
    def __repr__(self) -> str: ...

docs.title: string-dot-format-extra-named-arguments (F522)
docs.text:
Derived from the Pyflakes linter.

Fix is sometimes available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for str.format calls with unused keyword arguments.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: Unused keyword arguments are redundant, and often indicative of a mistake. They should be removed.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
"Hello, {name}".format(greeting="Hello", name="World")

Use instead:

"Hello, {name}".format(name="World")

docs.title: Fix safety
docs.text:
This rule's fix is marked as unsafe if the unused keyword argument contains a function call with potential side effects, because removing such arguments could change the behavior of the code.

For example, the fix would be marked as unsafe in the following case:

"Hello, {name}".format(greeting=print(1), name="World")

docs.title: References
docs.text: • Python documentation: str.format

docs.title: string-dot-format-extra-positional-arguments (F523)
docs.text:
Derived from the Pyflakes linter.

Fix is sometimes available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for str.format calls with unused positional arguments.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: Unused positional arguments are redundant, and often indicative of a mistake. They should be removed.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
"Hello, {0}".format("world", "!")

Use instead:

"Hello, {0}".format("world")

docs.title: Fix safety
docs.text:
This rule's fix is marked as unsafe if the unused positional argument contains a function call with potential side effects, because removing such arguments could change the behavior of the code.

For example, the fix would be marked as unsafe in the following case:

"Hello, {0}".format("world", print(1))

docs.title: References
docs.text: • Python documentation: str.format

docs.text: Derived from the Pyflakes linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for str.format calls with invalid format strings.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: Invalid format strings will raise a ValueError.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
"{".format(foo)

Use instead:

docs.title: References
docs.text: • Python documentation: str.format

docs.title: string-dot-format-missing-arguments (F524)
docs.text: Derived from the Pyflakes linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for str.format calls with placeholders that are missing arguments.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: In str.format calls, omitting arguments for placeholders will raise a KeyError at runtime.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
"{greeting}, {name}".format(name="World")

Use instead:

"{greeting}, {name}".format(greeting="Hello", name="World")

docs.title: References
docs.text: • Python documentation: str.format

docs.title: string-dot-format-mixing-automatic (F525)
docs.text: Derived from the Pyflakes linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for str.format calls that mix automatic and manual numbering.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: In str.format calls, mixing automatic and manual numbering will raise a ValueError at runtime.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
"{0}, {}".format("Hello", "World")

Use instead:

"{0}, {1}".format("Hello", "World")

Or:

"{}, {}".format("Hello", "World")

docs.title: References
docs.text: • Python documentation: str.format

docs.title: string-or-bytes-too-long (PYI053)
docs.text:
Derived from the flake8-pyi linter.

Fix is always available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for the use of string and bytes literals longer than 50 characters in stub (.pyi) files.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
If a function or variable has a default value where the string or bytes representation is greater than 50 characters long, it is likely to be an implementation detail or a constant that varies depending on the system you're running on.

Although IDEs may find them useful, default values are ignored by type checkers, the primary consumers of stub files. Replace very long constants with ellipses (...) to simplify the stub.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
def foo(arg: str = "51 character stringgggggggggggggggggggggggggggggggg") -> None: ...

Use instead:

def foo(arg: str = ...) -> None: ...

docs.title: strip-with-multi-characters (B005)
docs.text: Derived from the flake8-bugbear linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for uses of multi-character strings in .strip(), .lstrip(), and .rstrip() calls.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
All characters in the call to .strip(), .lstrip(), or .rstrip() are removed from the leading and trailing ends of the string. If the string contains multiple characters, the reader may be misled into thinking that a prefix or suffix is being removed, rather than a set of characters.

In Python 3.9 and later, you can use str.removeprefix and str.removesuffix to remove an exact prefix or suffix from a string, respectively, which should be preferred when possible.

docs.title: Known problems
docs.text:
As a heuristic, this rule only flags multi-character strings that contain duplicate characters. This allows usages like .strip("xyz"), which removes all occurrences of the characters x, y, and z from the leading and trailing ends of the string, but not .strip("foo").

The use of unique, multi-character strings may be intentional and consistent with the intent of .strip(), .lstrip(), or .rstrip(), while the use of duplicate-character strings is very likely to be a mistake.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
"text.txt".strip(".txt")  # "e"

Use instead:

"text.txt".removesuffix(".txt")  # "text"

docs.title: References
docs.text: • Python documentation: str.strip

docs.title: stub-body-multiple-statements (PYI048)
docs.text: Derived from the flake8-pyi linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for functions in stub (.pyi) files that contain multiple statements.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: Stub files are never executed, and are only intended to define type hints. As such, functions in stub files should not contain functional code, and should instead contain only a single statement (e.g., ...).

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
def function():
    x = 1
    y = 2
    return x + y

Use instead:

def function(): ...

docs.title: subclass-builtin (FURB189)
docs.text:
Derived from the refurb linter.

Fix is always available.

This rule is unstable and in preview. The --preview flag is required for use.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for subclasses of dict, list or str.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
Built-in types don't consistently use their own dunder methods. For example, dict.__init__ and dict.update() bypass __setitem__, making inheritance unreliable.

Use the UserDict, UserList, and UserString objects from the collections module instead.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
class UppercaseDict(dict):
    def __setitem__(self, key, value):
        super().__setitem__(key.upper(), value)


d = UppercaseDict({"a": 1, "b": 2})  # Bypasses __setitem__
print(d)  # {'a': 1, 'b': 2}

Use instead:

from collections import UserDict


class UppercaseDict(UserDict):
    def __setitem__(self, key, value):
        super().__setitem__(key.upper(), value)


d = UppercaseDict({"a": 1, "b": 2})  # Uses __setitem__
print(d)  # {'A': 1, 'B': 2}

docs.title: Fix safety
docs.text:
This fix is marked as unsafe because isinstance() checks for dict, list, and str types will fail when using the corresponding User class. If you need to pass custom dict or list objects to code you don't control, ignore this check. If you do control the code, consider using the following type checks instead:

  • dict -> collections.abc.MutableMapping
  • list -> collections.abc.MutableSequence
  • str -> No such conversion exists

docs.title: References
docs.text: • Python documentation: collections

docs.title: subprocess-popen-preexec-fn (PLW1509)
docs.text: Derived from the Pylint linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for uses of subprocess.Popen with a preexec_fn argument.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
The preexec_fn argument is unsafe within threads as it can lead to deadlocks. Furthermore, preexec_fn is targeted for deprecation.

Instead, consider using task-specific arguments such as env, start_new_session, and process_group. These are not prone to deadlocks and are more explicit.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
import os, subprocess

subprocess.Popen(foo, preexec_fn=os.setsid)
subprocess.Popen(bar, preexec_fn=os.setpgid(0, 0))

Use instead:

import subprocess

subprocess.Popen(foo, start_new_session=True)
subprocess.Popen(bar, process_group=0)  # Introduced in Python 3.11

docs.title: References
docs.text:
• Python documentation: subprocess.Popen
  • Why preexec_fn in subprocess.Popen may lead to deadlock?

docs.title: subprocess-popen-with-shell-equals-true (S602)
docs.text: Derived from the flake8-bandit linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Check for method calls that initiate a subprocess with a shell.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: Starting a subprocess with a shell can allow attackers to execute arbitrary shell commands. Consider starting the process without a shell call and sanitize the input to mitigate the risk of shell injection.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
import subprocess

subprocess.run("ls -l", shell=True)

Use instead:

import subprocess

subprocess.run(["ls", "-l"])

docs.title: References
docs.text:
• Python documentation: subprocess — Subprocess management
  • Common Weakness Enumeration: CWE-78

docs.title: subprocess-run-without-check (PLW1510)
docs.text:
Derived from the Pylint linter.

Fix is always available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for uses of subprocess.run without an explicit check argument.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
By default, subprocess.run does not check the return code of the process it runs. This can lead to silent failures.

Instead, consider using check=True to raise an exception if the process fails, or set check=False explicitly to mark the behavior as intentional.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
import subprocess

subprocess.run(["ls", "nonexistent"])  # No exception raised.

Use instead:

import subprocess

subprocess.run(["ls", "nonexistent"], check=True)  # Raises exception.

Or:

import subprocess

subprocess.run(["ls", "nonexistent"], check=False)  # Explicitly no check.

docs.title: Fix safety
docs.text: This rule's fix is marked as unsafe for function calls that contain **kwargs, as adding a check keyword argument to such a call may lead to a duplicate keyword argument error.

docs.title: References
docs.text: • Python documentation: subprocess.run

docs.title: subprocess-without-shell-equals-true (S603)
docs.text: Derived from the flake8-bandit linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Check for method calls that initiate a subprocess without a shell.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: Starting a subprocess without a shell can prevent attackers from executing arbitrary shell commands; however, it is still error-prone. Consider validating the input.

docs.title: Known problems
docs.text: Prone to false positives as it is difficult to determine whether the passed arguments have been validated (#4045).

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
import subprocess

cmd = input("Enter a command: ").split()
subprocess.run(cmd)

docs.title: References
docs.text: • Python documentation: subprocess — Subprocess management

docs.title: super-call-with-parameters (UP008)
docs.text:
Derived from the pyupgrade linter.

Fix is sometimes available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for super calls that pass redundant arguments.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
In Python 3, super can be invoked without any arguments when: (1) the first argument is __class__, and (2) the second argument is equivalent to the first argument of the enclosing method.

When possible, omit the arguments to super to make the code more concise and maintainable.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
class A:
    def foo(self):
        pass


class B(A):
    def bar(self):
        super(B, self).foo()

Use instead:

class A:
    def foo(self):
        pass


class B(A):
    def bar(self):
        super().foo()

docs.title: Fix safety
docs.text:
This rule's fix is marked as unsafe because removing the arguments from a call may delete comments that are attached to the arguments.

In preview, the fix is marked safe if no comments are present.

docs.title: References
docs.text:
• Python documentation: super
  • super/MRO, Python's most misunderstood feature.

docs.title: super-without-brackets (PLW0245)
docs.text:
Derived from the Pylint linter.

Fix is always available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Detects attempts to use super without parentheses.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: The super() callable can be used inside method definitions to create a proxy object that delegates attribute access to a superclass of the current class. Attempting to access attributes on super itself, however, instead of the object returned by a call to super(), will raise AttributeError.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
class Animal:
    @staticmethod
    def speak():
        return "This animal says something."


class Dog(Animal):
    @staticmethod
    def speak():
        original_speak = super.speak()  # ERROR: `super.speak()`
        return f"{original_speak} But as a dog, it barks!"

Use instead:

class Animal:
    @staticmethod
    def speak():
        return "This animal says something."


class Dog(Animal):
    @staticmethod
    def speak():
        original_speak = super().speak()  # Correct: `super().speak()`
        return f"{original_speak} But as a dog, it barks!"

docs.title: superfluous-else-break (RET508)
docs.text:
Derived from the flake8-return linter.

Fix is sometimes available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for else statements with a break statement in the preceding if block.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: The else statement is not needed, as the break statement will always break out of the loop. Removing the else will reduce nesting and make the code more readable.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
def foo(bar, baz):
    for i in bar:
        if i > baz:
            break
        else:
            x = 0

Use instead:

def foo(bar, baz):
    for i in bar:
        if i > baz:
            break
        x = 0

docs.title: superfluous-else-continue (RET507)
docs.text:
Derived from the flake8-return linter.

Fix is sometimes available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for else statements with a continue statement in the preceding if block.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: The else statement is not needed, as the continue statement will always continue onto the next iteration of a loop. Removing the else will reduce nesting and make the code more readable.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
def foo(bar, baz):
    for i in bar:
        if i < baz:
            continue
        else:
            x = 0

Use instead:

def foo(bar, baz):
    for i in bar:
        if i < baz:
            continue
        x = 0

docs.title: superfluous-else-raise (RET506)
docs.text:
Derived from the flake8-return linter.

Fix is sometimes available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for else statements with a raise statement in the preceding if block.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: The else statement is not needed as the raise statement will always break out of the current scope. Removing the else will reduce nesting and make the code more readable.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
def foo(bar, baz):
    if bar == "Specific Error":
        raise Exception(bar)
    else:
        raise Exception(baz)

Use instead:

def foo(bar, baz):
    if bar == "Specific Error":
        raise Exception(bar)
    raise Exception(baz)

docs.title: superfluous-else-return (RET505)
docs.text:
Derived from the flake8-return linter.

Fix is sometimes available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for else statements with a return statement in the preceding if block.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: The else statement is not needed as the return statement will always break out of the enclosing function. Removing the else will reduce nesting and make the code more readable.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
def foo(bar, baz):
    if bar:
        return 1
    else:
        return baz

Use instead:

def foo(bar, baz):
    if bar:
        return 1
    return baz

docs.title: suppressible-exception (SIM105)
docs.text:
Derived from the flake8-simplify linter.

Fix is sometimes available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for try-except-pass blocks that can be replaced with the contextlib.suppress context manager.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
Using contextlib.suppress is more concise and directly communicates the intent of the code: to suppress a given exception.

Note that contextlib.suppress is slower than using try-except-pass directly. For performance-critical code, consider retaining the try-except-pass pattern.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
try:
    1 / 0
except ZeroDivisionError:
    pass

Use instead:

import contextlib

with contextlib.suppress(ZeroDivisionError):
    1 / 0

docs.title: suspicious-insecure-cipher-mode-usage (S305)
docs.text: Derived from the flake8-bandit linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for uses of weak or broken cryptographic cipher modes.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
Weak or broken cryptographic ciphers may be susceptible to attacks that allow an attacker to decrypt ciphertext without knowing the key or otherwise compromise the security of the cipher, such as forgeries.

Use strong, modern cryptographic ciphers instead of weak or broken ones.

In preview, this rule will also flag references to insecure cipher modes.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
from cryptography.hazmat.primitives.ciphers import Cipher, algorithms, modes

algorithm = algorithms.ARC4(key)
cipher = Cipher(algorithm, mode=modes.ECB(iv))
encryptor = cipher.encryptor()

Use instead:

from cryptography.hazmat.primitives.ciphers import Cipher, algorithms, modes

algorithm = algorithms.ARC4(key)
cipher = Cipher(algorithm, mode=modes.CTR(iv))
encryptor = cipher.encryptor()

docs.title: suspicious-insecure-hash-usage (S303)
docs.text: Derived from the flake8-bandit linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for uses of weak or broken cryptographic hash functions.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
Weak or broken cryptographic hash functions may be susceptible to collision attacks (where two different inputs produce the same hash) or pre-image attacks (where an attacker can find an input that produces a given hash). This can lead to security vulnerabilities in applications that rely on these hash functions.

Avoid using weak or broken cryptographic hash functions in security contexts. Instead, use a known secure hash function such as SHA-256.

In preview, this rule will also flag references to insecure hash functions.

docs.title: Example

from cryptography.hazmat.primitives import hashes

digest = hashes.Hash(hashes.MD5())
digest.update(b"Hello, world!")
digest.finalize()

Use instead:

from cryptography.hazmat.primitives import hashes

digest = hashes.Hash(hashes.SHA256())
digest.update(b"Hello, world!")
digest.finalize()

docs.title: suspicious-mark-safe-usage (S308)
docs.text: Derived from the flake8-bandit linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for uses of calls to django.utils.safestring.mark_safe.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
Cross-site scripting (XSS) vulnerabilities allow attackers to execute arbitrary JavaScript. To guard against XSS attacks, Django templates assumes that data is unsafe and automatically escapes malicious strings before rending them.

django.utils.safestring.mark_safe marks a string as safe for use in HTML templates, bypassing XSS protection. Its usage can be dangerous if the contents of the string are dynamically generated, because it may allow cross-site scripting attacks if the string is not properly escaped.

For dynamically generated strings, consider utilizing django.utils.html.format_html.

In preview, this rule will also flag references to django.utils.safestring.mark_safe.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
from django.utils.safestring import mark_safe


def render_username(username):
    return mark_safe(f"<i>{username}</i>")  # Dangerous if username is user-provided.

Use instead:

from django.utils.html import format_html


def render_username(username):
    return django.utils.html.format_html("<i>{}</i>", username)  # username is escaped.

docs.title: suspicious-marshal-usage (S302)
docs.text: Derived from the flake8-bandit linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for calls to marshal functions.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
Deserializing untrusted data with marshal is insecure, as it can allow for the creation of arbitrary objects, which can then be used to achieve arbitrary code execution and otherwise unexpected behavior.

Avoid deserializing untrusted data with marshal. Instead, consider safer formats, such as JSON.

If you must deserialize untrusted data with marshal, consider signing the data with a secret key and verifying the signature before deserializing the payload. This will prevent an attacker from injecting arbitrary objects into the serialized data.

In preview, this rule will also flag references to marshal functions.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
import marshal

with open("foo.marshal", "rb") as file:
    foo = marshal.load(file)

Use instead:

import json

with open("foo.json", "rb") as file:
    foo = json.load(file)

docs.text:
• Python documentation: marshal — Internal Python object serialization
  • Common Weakness Enumeration: CWE-502

docs.title: suspicious-mktemp-usage (S306)
docs.text: Derived from the flake8-bandit linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for uses of tempfile.mktemp.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
tempfile.mktemp returns a pathname of a file that does not exist at the time the call is made; then, the caller is responsible for creating the file and subsequently using it. This is insecure because another process could create a file with the same name between the time the function returns and the time the caller creates the file.

tempfile.mktemp is deprecated in favor of tempfile.mkstemp which creates the file when it is called. Consider using tempfile.mkstemp instead, either directly or via a context manager such as tempfile.TemporaryFile.

In preview, this rule will also flag references to tempfile.mktemp.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
import tempfile

tmp_file = tempfile.mktemp()
with open(tmp_file, "w") as file:
    file.write("Hello, world!")

Use instead:

import tempfile

with tempfile.TemporaryFile() as file:
    file.write("Hello, world!")

docs.title: References
docs.text: • Python documentation:mktemp

docs.text: Derived from the flake8-bandit linter.

docs.title: What it does

docs.title: Why is this bad?

Cryptographically weak pseudo-random number generators are insecure, as they are easily predictable. This can allow an attacker to guess the generated numbers and compromise the security of the system.

Instead, use a cryptographically secure pseudo-random number generator (such as using the secrets module) when generating random numbers for security purposes.

In preview, this rule will also flag references to these generators.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
import random

random.randrange(10)

Use instead:

import secrets

secrets.randbelow(10)

docs.title: suspicious-unverified-context-usage (S323)
docs.text: Derived from the flake8-bandit linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for uses of ssl._create_unverified_context.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
PEP 476 enabled certificate and hostname validation by default in Python standard library HTTP clients. Previously, Python did not validate certificates by default, which could allow an attacker to perform a "man in the middle" attack by intercepting and modifying traffic between client and server.

To support legacy environments, ssl._create_unverified_context reverts to the previous behavior that does perform verification. Otherwise, use ssl.create_default_context to create a secure context.

In preview, this rule will also flag references to ssl._create_unverified_context.

context = ssl._create_unverified_context()

Use instead:

docs.title: suspicious-url-open-usage (S310)
docs.text: Derived from the flake8-bandit linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for instances where URL open functions are used with unexpected schemes.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
Some URL open functions allow the use of file: or custom schemes (for use instead of http: or https:). An attacker may be able to use these schemes to access or modify unauthorized resources, and cause unexpected behavior.

To mitigate this risk, audit all uses of URL open functions and ensure that only permitted schemes are used (e.g., allowing http: and https:, and disallowing file: and ftp:).

In preview, this rule will also flag references to URL open functions.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
from urllib.request import urlopen

url = input("Enter a URL: ")

with urlopen(url) as response:
    ...

Use instead:

from urllib.request import urlopen

url = input("Enter a URL: ")

if not url.startswith(("http:", "https:")):
    raise ValueError("URL must start with 'http:' or 'https:'")

with urlopen(url) as response:
    ...

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
Many XML parsers are vulnerable to XML attacks (such as entity expansion), which cause excessive memory and CPU usage by exploiting recursion. An attacker could use such methods to access unauthorized resources.

Consider using the defusedxml package when parsing untrusted XML data, to protect against XML attacks.

In preview, this rule will also flag references to insecure XML parsers.

from xml.sax import make_parser

Use instead:

from defusedxml.sax import make_parser

docs.title: sys-exit-alias (PLR1722)
docs.text:
Derived from the Pylint linter.

Fix is sometimes available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for uses of the exit() and quit().

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
exit and quit come from the site module, which is typically imported automatically during startup. However, it is not guaranteed to be imported, and so using these functions may result in a NameError at runtime. Generally, these constants are intended to be used in an interactive interpreter, and not in programs.

Prefer sys.exit(), as the sys module is guaranteed to exist in all contexts.

docs.title: Fix safety
docs.text:
This fix is always unsafe. When replacing exit or quit with sys.exit, the behavior can change in the following ways:

  1. If the code runs in an environment where the site module is not imported (e.g., with python -S), the original code would raise a NameError, while the fixed code would execute normally.

  2. site.exit and sys.exit handle tuple arguments differently. site.exit treats tuples as regular objects and always returns exit code 1, while sys.exit interprets tuple contents to determine the exit code: an empty tuple () results in exit code 0, and a single-element tuple like (2,) uses that element's value (2) as the exit code.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
if __name__ == "__main__":
    exit()

Use instead:

import sys

if __name__ == "__main__":
    sys.exit()

docs.title: References
docs.text: • Python documentation: Constants added by the site module

docs.title: sys-version-cmp-str10 (YTT302)
docs.text: Derived from the flake8-2020 linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for comparisons that test sys.version against string literals, such that the comparison would fail if the major version number were ever incremented to Python 10 or higher.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
Comparing sys.version to a string is error-prone and may cause subtle bugs, as the comparison will be performed lexicographically, not semantically.

Instead, use sys.version_info to access the current major and minor version numbers as a tuple, which can be compared to other tuples without issue.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
import sys

sys.version >= "3"  # `False` on Python 10.

Use instead:

import sys

sys.version_info >= (3,)  # `True` on Python 10.
