docs.text:
• Python documentation: enumerate
  • Python documentation: range
  • Python documentation: len

docs.title: unnecessary-escaped-quote (Q004)
docs.text:
Derived from the flake8-quotes linter.

Fix is always available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for strings that include unnecessarily escaped quotes.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: If a string contains an escaped quote that doesn't match the quote character used for the string, it's unnecessary and can be removed.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
foo = "bar\'s"

Use instead:

foo = "bar's"

docs.title: Formatter compatibility
docs.text: We recommend against using this rule alongside the formatter. The formatter automatically removes unnecessary escapes, making the rule redundant.

docs.title: unnecessary-from-float (FURB164)
docs.text:
Derived from the refurb linter.

Fix is sometimes available.

This rule is unstable and in preview. The --preview flag is required for use.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for unnecessary from_float and from_decimal usages to construct Decimal and Fraction instances.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
Since Python 3.2, the Fraction and Decimal classes can be constructed by passing float or decimal instances to the constructor directly. As such, the use of from_float and from_decimal methods is unnecessary, and should be avoided in favor of the more concise constructor syntax.

However, there are important behavioral differences between the from_* methods and the constructors:

  • The from_* methods validate their argument types and raise TypeError for invalid types
  • The constructors accept broader argument types without validation
  • The from_* methods have different parameter names than the constructors

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
from decimal import Decimal
from fractions import Fraction

Decimal.from_float(4.2)
Decimal.from_float(float("inf"))
Fraction.from_float(4.2)
Fraction.from_decimal(Decimal("4.2"))

Use instead:

from decimal import Decimal
from fractions import Fraction

Decimal(4.2)
Decimal("inf")
Fraction(4.2)
Fraction(Decimal("4.2"))

docs.title: Fix safety
docs.text:
This rule's fix is marked as unsafe by default because:

  • The from_* methods provide type validation that the constructors don't
  • Removing type validation can change program behavior
  • The parameter names are different between methods and constructors

The fix is marked as safe only when:

  • The argument type is known to be valid for the target constructor
  • No keyword arguments are used, or they match the constructor's parameters

docs.title: References
docs.text:
• Python documentation: decimal
  • Python documentation: fractions

docs.title: unnecessary-future-import (UP010)
docs.text:
Derived from the pyupgrade linter.

Fix is always available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for unnecessary __future__ imports.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: The __future__ module is used to enable features that are not yet available in the current Python version. If a feature is already available in the minimum supported Python version, importing it from __future__ is unnecessary and should be removed to avoid confusion.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
from __future__ import print_function

print("Hello, world!")

Use instead:

print("Hello, world!")

docs.title: Fix safety
docs.text: This fix is marked unsafe if applying it would delete a comment.

docs.title: Options
docs.text: • target-version

docs.title: References
docs.text: • Python documentation: __future__ — Future statement definitions

docs.title: unnecessary-generator-dict (C402)
docs.text:
Derived from the flake8-comprehensions linter.

Fix is always available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for unnecessary generators that can be rewritten as dict comprehensions.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: It is unnecessary to use dict() around a generator expression, since there are equivalent comprehensions for these types. Using a comprehension is clearer and more idiomatic.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
dict((x, f(x)) for x in foo)

Use instead:

{x: f(x) for x in foo}

docs.title: Fix safety
docs.text: This rule's fix is marked as unsafe, as it may occasionally drop comments when rewriting the call. In most cases, though, comments will be preserved.

docs.title: unnecessary-generator-list (C400)
docs.text:
Derived from the flake8-comprehensions linter.

Fix is always available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for unnecessary generators that can be rewritten as list comprehensions (or with list() directly).

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
It is unnecessary to use list() around a generator expression, since there are equivalent comprehensions for these types. Using a comprehension is clearer and more idiomatic.

Further, if the comprehension can be removed entirely, as in the case of list(x for x in foo), it's better to use list(foo) directly, since it's even more direct.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
list(f(x) for x in foo)
list(x for x in foo)
list((x for x in foo))

Use instead:

[f(x) for x in foo]
list(foo)
list(foo)

docs.title: Fix safety
docs.text: This rule's fix is marked as unsafe, as it may occasionally drop comments when rewriting the call. In most cases, though, comments will be preserved.

docs.title: unnecessary-generator-set (C401)
docs.text:
Derived from the flake8-comprehensions linter.

Fix is always available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for unnecessary generators that can be rewritten as set comprehensions (or with set() directly).

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
It is unnecessary to use set around a generator expression, since there are equivalent comprehensions for these types. Using a comprehension is clearer and more idiomatic.

Further, if the comprehension can be removed entirely, as in the case of set(x for x in foo), it's better to use set(foo) directly, since it's even more direct.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
set(f(x) for x in foo)
set(x for x in foo)
set((x for x in foo))

Use instead:

{f(x) for x in foo}
set(foo)
set(foo)

docs.title: Fix safety
docs.text: This rule's fix is marked as unsafe, as it may occasionally drop comments when rewriting the call. In most cases, though, comments will be preserved.

docs.title: unnecessary-iterable-allocation-for-first-element (RUF015)
docs.text: Fix is always available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text:
Checks the following constructs, all of which can be replaced by next(iter(...)):

  • list(...)[0]
  • tuple(...)[0]
  • list(i for i in ...)[0]
  • [i for i in ...][0]
  • list(...).pop(0)

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: Calling e.g. list(...) will create a new list of the entire collection, which can be very expensive for large collections. If you only need the first element of the collection, you can use next(...) or next(iter(...) to lazily fetch the first element. The same is true for the other constructs.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
head = list(x)[0]
head = [x * x for x in range(10)][0]

Use instead:

head = next(iter(x))
head = next(x * x for x in range(10))

docs.title: Fix safety
docs.text:
This rule's fix is marked as unsafe, as migrating from (e.g.) list(...)[0] to next(iter(...)) can change the behavior of your program in two ways:

  1. First, all above-mentioned constructs will eagerly evaluate the entire collection, while next(iter(...)) will only evaluate the first element. As such, any side effects that occur during iteration will be delayed.
  2. Second, accessing members of a collection via square bracket notation [0] of the pop() function will raise IndexError if the collection is empty, while next(iter(...)) will raise StopIteration.

docs.title: References
docs.text: • Iterators and Iterables in Python: Run Efficient Iterations

docs.title: unnecessary-key-check (RUF019)
docs.text: Fix is always available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for unnecessary key checks prior to accessing a dictionary.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: When working with dictionaries, the get can be used to access a value without having to check if the dictionary contains the relevant key, returning None if the key is not present.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
if "key" in dct and dct["key"]:
    ...

Use instead:

if dct.get("key"):
    ...

docs.title: unnecessary-lambda (PLW0108)
docs.text:
Derived from the Pylint linter.

Fix is sometimes available.

This rule is unstable and in preview. The --preview flag is required for use.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for lambda definitions that consist of a single function call with the same arguments as the lambda itself.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: When a lambda is used to wrap a function call, and merely propagates the lambda arguments to that function, it can typically be replaced with the function itself, removing a level of indirection.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
df.apply(lambda x: str(x))

Use instead:

df.apply(str)

docs.title: Fix safety
docs.text:
This rule's fix is marked as unsafe for two primary reasons.

First, the lambda body itself could contain an effect.

For example, replacing lambda x, y: (func()(x, y)) with func() would lead to a change in behavior, as func() would be evaluated eagerly when defining the lambda, rather than when the lambda is called.

However, even when the lambda body itself is pure, the lambda may change the argument names, which can lead to a change in behavior when callers pass arguments by name.

For example, replacing foo = lambda x, y: func(x, y) with foo = func, where func is defined as def func(a, b): return a + b, would be a breaking change for callers that execute the lambda by passing arguments by name, as in: foo(x=1, y=2). Since func does not define the arguments x and y, unlike the lambda, the call would raise a TypeError.

docs.title: unnecessary-list-call (C411)
docs.text:
Derived from the flake8-comprehensions linter.

Fix is always available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for unnecessary list() calls around list comprehensions.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: It is redundant to use a list() call around a list comprehension.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
list([f(x) for x in foo])

Use instead

[f(x) for x in foo]

docs.title: Fix safety
docs.text: This rule's fix is marked as unsafe, as it may occasionally drop comments when rewriting the call. In most cases, though, comments will be preserved.

docs.title: unnecessary-list-cast (PERF101)
docs.text:
Derived from the Perflint linter.

Fix is always available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for explicit casts to list on for-loop iterables.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
Using a list() call to eagerly iterate over an already-iterable type (like a tuple, list, or set) is inefficient, as it forces Python to create a new list unnecessarily.

Removing the list() call will not change the behavior of the code, but may improve performance.

Note that, as with all perflint rules, this is only intended as a micro-optimization, and will have a negligible impact on performance in most cases.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
items = (1, 2, 3)
for i in list(items):
    print(i)

Use instead:

items = (1, 2, 3)
for i in items:
    print(i)

docs.title: Fix safety
docs.text:
This rule's fix is marked as unsafe if there's comments in the list() call, as comments may be removed.

For example, the fix would be marked as unsafe in the following case:

items = (1, 2, 3)
for i in list(  # comment
    items
):
    print(i)

docs.title: unnecessary-list-comprehension-dict (C404)
docs.text:
Derived from the flake8-comprehensions linter.

Fix is always available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for unnecessary list comprehensions.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: It's unnecessary to use a list comprehension inside a call to dict(), since there is an equivalent comprehension for this type.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
dict([(x, f(x)) for x in foo])

Use instead:

{x: f(x) for x in foo}

docs.title: Fix safety
docs.text: This rule's fix is marked as unsafe, as it may occasionally drop comments when rewriting the call. In most cases, though, comments will be preserved.

docs.title: unnecessary-list-comprehension-set (C403)
docs.text:
Derived from the flake8-comprehensions linter.

Fix is always available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for unnecessary list comprehensions.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: It's unnecessary to use a list comprehension inside a call to set(), since there is an equivalent comprehension for this type.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
set([f(x) for x in foo])

Use instead:

{f(x) for x in foo}

docs.title: Fix safety
docs.text: This rule's fix is marked as unsafe, as it may occasionally drop comments when rewriting the call. In most cases, though, comments will be preserved.

docs.title: unnecessary-list-index-lookup (PLR1736)
docs.text:
Derived from the Pylint linter.

Fix is always available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for index-based list accesses during enumerate iterations.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: When iterating over a list with enumerate, the current item is already available alongside its index. Using the index to look up the item is unnecessary.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
letters = ["a", "b", "c"]

for index, letter in enumerate(letters):
    print(letters[index])

Use instead:

letters = ["a", "b", "c"]

for index, letter in enumerate(letters):
    print(letter)

docs.title: unnecessary-literal-dict (C406)
docs.text:
Derived from the flake8-comprehensions linter.

Fix is always available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for unnecessary list or tuple literals.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: It's unnecessary to use a list or tuple literal within a call to dict(). It can be rewritten as a dict literal ({}).

docs.title: Fix safety
docs.text: This rule's fix is marked as unsafe, as it may occasionally drop comments when rewriting the call. In most cases, though, comments will be preserved.

docs.title: unnecessary-literal-set (C405)
docs.text:
Derived from the flake8-comprehensions linter.

Fix is always available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for set() calls that take unnecessary list or tuple literals as arguments.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: It's unnecessary to use a list or tuple literal within a call to set(). Instead, the expression can be rewritten as a set literal.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
set([1, 2])
set((1, 2))
set([])

Use instead:

{1, 2}
{1, 2}
set()

docs.title: Fix safety
docs.text: This rule's fix is marked as unsafe, as it may occasionally drop comments when rewriting the call. In most cases, though, comments will be preserved.

docs.title: unnecessary-literal-union (PYI030)
docs.text:
Derived from the flake8-pyi linter.

Fix is sometimes available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for the presence of multiple literal types in a union.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: Literal["foo", 42] has identical semantics to Literal["foo"] | Literal[42], but is clearer and more concise.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
from typing import Literal

field: Literal[1] | Literal[2] | str

Use instead:

from typing import Literal

field: Literal[1, 2] | str

docs.title: Fix safety
docs.text:
This fix is marked unsafe if it would delete any comments within the replacement range.

An example to illustrate where comments are preserved and where they are not:

from typing import Literal

field: (
    # deleted comment
    Literal["a", "b"]  # deleted comment
    # deleted comment
    | Literal["c", "d"]  # preserved comment
)

docs.title: References
docs.text: • Python documentation: typing.Literal

docs.title: unnecessary-literal-within-dict-call (C418)
docs.text:
Derived from the flake8-comprehensions linter.

Fix is always available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for dict() calls that take unnecessary dict literals or dict comprehensions as arguments.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: It's unnecessary to wrap a dict literal or comprehension within a dict() call, since the literal or comprehension syntax already returns a dictionary.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
dict({})
dict({"a": 1})

Use instead:

{}
{"a": 1}

docs.title: Fix safety
docs.text: This rule's fix is marked as unsafe, as it may occasionally drop comments when rewriting the call. In most cases, though, comments will be preserved.

docs.title: unnecessary-literal-within-list-call (C410)
docs.text:
Derived from the flake8-comprehensions linter.

Fix is always available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for list() calls that take unnecessary list or tuple literals as arguments.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
It's unnecessary to use a list or tuple literal within a list() call, since there is a literal syntax for these types.

If a list literal is passed in, then the outer call to list() should be removed. Otherwise, if a tuple literal is passed in, then it should be rewritten as a list literal.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
list([1, 2])
list((1, 2))

Use instead:

[1, 2]
[1, 2]

docs.title: Fix safety
docs.text: This rule's fix is marked as unsafe, as it may occasionally drop comments when rewriting the call. In most cases, though, comments will be preserved.

docs.title: unnecessary-literal-within-tuple-call (C409)
docs.text:
Derived from the flake8-comprehensions linter.

Fix is always available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for tuple calls that take unnecessary list or tuple literals as arguments. In preview, this also includes unnecessary list comprehensions within tuple calls.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
It's unnecessary to use a list or tuple literal within a tuple() call, since there is a literal syntax for these types.

If a list literal was passed, then it should be rewritten as a tuple literal. Otherwise, if a tuple literal was passed, then the outer call to tuple() should be removed.

In preview, this rule also checks for list comprehensions within tuple() calls. If a list comprehension is found, it should be rewritten as a generator expression.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
tuple([1, 2])
tuple((1, 2))
tuple([x for x in range(10)])

Use instead:

(1, 2)
(1, 2)
tuple(x for x in range(10))

docs.title: Fix safety
docs.text: This rule's fix is marked as unsafe, as it may occasionally drop comments when rewriting the call. In most cases, though, comments will be preserved.

docs.title: unnecessary-map (C417)
docs.text:
Derived from the flake8-comprehensions linter.

Fix is sometimes available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for unnecessary map() calls with lambda functions.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
Using map(func, iterable) when func is a lambda is slower than using a generator expression or a comprehension, as the latter approach avoids the function call overhead, in addition to being more readable.

This rule also applies to map() calls within list(), set(), and dict() calls. For example:

  • Instead of list(map(lambda num: num * 2, nums)), use [num * 2 for num in nums].
  • Instead of set(map(lambda num: num % 2 == 0, nums)), use {num % 2 == 0 for num in nums}.
  • Instead of dict(map(lambda v: (v, v ** 2), values)), use {v: v ** 2 for v in values}.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
map(lambda x: x + 1, iterable)

Use instead:

(x + 1 for x in iterable)

docs.title: Fix safety
docs.text: This rule's fix is marked as unsafe, as it may occasionally drop comments when rewriting the call. In most cases, though, comments will be preserved.

docs.title: unnecessary-multiline-docstring (D200)
docs.text:
Derived from the pydocstyle linter.

Fix is sometimes available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for single-line docstrings that are broken across multiple lines.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: PEP 257 recommends that docstrings that can fit on one line should be formatted on a single line, for consistency and readability.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
def average(values: list[float]) -> float:
    """
    Return the mean of the given values.
    """

Use instead:

def average(values: list[float]) -> float:
    """Return the mean of the given values."""

docs.title: Fix safety
docs.text: The fix is marked as unsafe because it could affect tools that parse docstrings, documentation generators, or custom introspection utilities that rely on specific docstring formatting.

docs.title: References
docs.text: • PEP 257 – Docstring Conventions

docs.title: unnecessary-nested-literal (RUF041)
docs.text: Fix is sometimes available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for unnecessary nested Literal.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
Prefer using a single Literal, which is equivalent and more concise.

Parameterization of literals by other literals is supported as an ergonomic feature as proposed in [PEP 586], to enable patterns such as:

ReadOnlyMode         = Literal["r", "r+"]
WriteAndTruncateMode = Literal["w", "w+", "wt", "w+t"]
WriteNoTruncateMode  = Literal["r+", "r+t"]
AppendMode           = Literal["a", "a+", "at", "a+t"]

AllModes = Literal[ReadOnlyMode, WriteAndTruncateMode,
                  WriteNoTruncateMode, AppendMode]

As a consequence, type checkers also support nesting of literals which is less readable than a flat Literal:

AllModes = Literal[Literal["r", "r+"], Literal["w", "w+", "wt", "w+t"],
                  Literal["r+", "r+t"], Literal["a", "a+", "at", "a+t"]]

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
AllModes = Literal[
    Literal["r", "r+"],
    Literal["w", "w+", "wt", "w+t"],
    Literal["r+", "r+t"],
    Literal["a", "a+", "at", "a+t"],
]

Use instead:

AllModes = Literal[
    "r", "r+", "w", "w+", "wt", "w+t", "r+", "r+t", "a", "a+", "at", "a+t"
]

or assign the literal to a variable as in the first example.

docs.title: Fix safety
docs.text: The fix for this rule is marked as unsafe when the Literal slice is split across multiple lines and some of the lines have trailing comments.

docs.title: References
docs.text:
• Typing documentation: Legal parameters for Literal at type check time

PEP 586

docs.title: unnecessary-paren-on-raise-exception (RSE102)
docs.text:
Derived from the flake8-raise linter.

Fix is always available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for unnecessary parentheses on raised exceptions.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
If an exception is raised without any arguments, parentheses are not required, as the raise statement accepts either an exception instance or an exception class (which is then implicitly instantiated).

Removing the parentheses makes the code more concise.

docs.title: Known problems
docs.text:
Parentheses can only be omitted if the exception is a class, as opposed to a function call. This rule isn't always capable of distinguishing between the two.

For example, if you import a function module.get_exception from another module, and module.get_exception returns an exception object, this rule will incorrectly mark the parentheses in raise module.get_exception() as unnecessary.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
raise TypeError()

Use instead:

raise TypeError

docs.title: Fix Safety
docs.text: This rule's fix is marked as unsafe if removing the parentheses would also remove comments or if it’s unclear whether the expression is a class or a function call.

docs.title: References
docs.text: • Python documentation: The raise statement

docs.title: unnecessary-placeholder (PIE790)
docs.text:
Derived from the flake8-pie linter.

Fix is always available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for unnecessary pass statements and ellipsis (...) literals in functions, classes, and other blocks.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
In Python, the pass statement and ellipsis (...) literal serve as placeholders, allowing for syntactically correct empty code blocks. The primary purpose of these nodes is to avoid syntax errors in situations where a statement or expression is syntactically required, but no code needs to be executed.

If a pass or ellipsis is present in a code block that includes at least one other statement (even, e.g., a docstring), it is unnecessary and should be removed.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
def func():
    """Placeholder docstring."""
    pass

Use instead:

def func():
    """Placeholder docstring."""

Or, given:

def func():
    """Placeholder docstring."""
    ...

Use instead:

def func():
    """Placeholder docstring."""

docs.title: Fix safety
docs.text: This rule's fix is marked as unsafe in the rare case that the pass or ellipsis is followed by a string literal, since removal of the placeholder would convert the subsequent string literal into a docstring.

docs.title: References
docs.text: • Python documentation: The pass statement

docs.title: unnecessary-range-start (PIE808)
docs.text:
Derived from the flake8-pie linter.

Fix is always available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for range calls with an unnecessary start argument.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: range(0, x) is equivalent to range(x), as 0 is the default value for the start argument. Omitting the start argument makes the code more concise and idiomatic.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
range(0, 3)

Use instead:

range(3)

docs.title: References
docs.text: • Python documentation: range

docs.title: unnecessary-regular-expression (RUF055)
docs.text:
Fix is sometimes available.

This rule is unstable and in preview. The --preview flag is required for use.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for uses of the re module that can be replaced with builtin str methods.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: Performing checks on strings directly can make the code simpler, may require less escaping, and will often be faster.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
re.sub("abc", "", s)

Use instead:

s.replace("abc", "")

docs.title: Details
docs.text:
The rule reports the following calls when the first argument to the call is a plain string literal, and no additional flags are passed:

  • re.sub
  • re.match
  • re.search
  • re.fullmatch
  • re.split

For re.sub, the repl (replacement) argument must also be a string literal, not a function. For re.match, re.search, and re.fullmatch, the return value must also be used only for its truth value.

docs.title: Fix safety
docs.text: This rule's fix is marked as unsafe if the affected expression contains comments. Otherwise, the fix can be applied safely.

docs.title: References
docs.text: • Python Regular Expression HOWTO: Common Problems - Use String Methods

docs.title: unnecessary-return-none (RET501)
docs.text:
Derived from the flake8-return linter.

Fix is always available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for the presence of a return None statement when None is the only possible return value.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: Python implicitly assumes return None if an explicit return value is omitted. Therefore, explicitly returning None is redundant and should be avoided when it is the only possible return value across all code paths in a given function.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
def foo(bar):
    if not bar:
        return
    return None

Use instead:

def foo(bar):
    if not bar:
        return
    return

docs.title: Fix safety
docs.text: This rule's fix is marked as unsafe for cases in which comments would be dropped from the return statement.

docs.title: unnecessary-round (RUF057)
docs.text: Fix is always available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for round() calls that have no effect on the input.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: Rounding a value that's already an integer is unnecessary. It's clearer to use the value directly.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
a = round(1, 0)

Use instead:

a = 1

docs.title: Fix safety
docs.text: The fix is marked unsafe if it is not possible to guarantee that the first argument of round() is of type int, or if the fix deletes comments.

docs.title: unnecessary-spread (PIE800)
docs.text:
Derived from the flake8-pie linter.

Fix is sometimes available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for unnecessary dictionary unpacking operators (**).

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: Unpacking a dictionary into another dictionary is redundant. The unpacking operator can be removed, making the code more readable.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
foo = {"A": 1, "B": 2}
bar = {**foo, **{"C": 3}}

Use instead:

foo = {"A": 1, "B": 2}
bar = {**foo, "C": 3}

docs.title: References
docs.text: • Python documentation: Dictionary displays

docs.title: unnecessary-subscript-reversal (C415)
docs.text: Derived from the flake8-comprehensions linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for unnecessary subscript reversal of iterable.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: It's unnecessary to reverse the order of an iterable when passing it into reversed(), set() or sorted() functions as they will change the order of the elements again.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
sorted(iterable[::-1])
set(iterable[::-1])
reversed(iterable[::-1])

Use instead:

sorted(iterable)
set(iterable)
iterable

docs.title: unnecessary-type-union (PYI055)
docs.text:
Derived from the flake8-pyi linter.

Fix is sometimes available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for the presence of multiple types in a union.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: type[T | S] has identical semantics to type[T] | type[S] in a type annotation, but is cleaner and more concise.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
field: type[int] | type[float] | str

Use instead:

field: type[int | float] | str

docs.title: Fix safety
docs.text:
This rule's fix is marked as safe, unless the type annotation contains comments.

Note that while the fix may flatten nested unions into a single top-level union, the semantics of the annotation will remain unchanged.

docs.title: unpacked-list-comprehension (UP027)
docs.text:
Derived from the pyupgrade linter.

Warning: This rule has been removed and its documentation is only available for historical reasons.

docs.title: Removed
docs.text: There's no evidence that generators are meaningfully faster than list comprehensions when combined with unpacking.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for list comprehensions that are immediately unpacked.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: There is no reason to use a list comprehension if the result is immediately unpacked. Instead, use a generator expression, which avoids allocating an intermediary list.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
a, b, c = [foo(x) for x in items]

Use instead:

a, b, c = (foo(x) for x in items)

docs.title: References
docs.text:
• Python documentation: Generator expressions
  • Python documentation: List comprehensions

docs.title: unprefixed-type-param (PYI001)
docs.text: Derived from the flake8-pyi linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks that type TypeVars, ParamSpecs, and TypeVarTuples in stubs have names prefixed with _.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: Prefixing type parameters with _ avoids accidentally exposing names internal to the stub.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
from typing import TypeVar

T = TypeVar("T")

Use instead:

from typing import TypeVar

_T = TypeVar("_T")

docs.title: unquoted-type-alias (TC007)
docs.text:
Derived from the flake8-type-checking linter.

Fix is sometimes available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks if PEP 613 explicit type aliases contain references to symbols that are not available at runtime.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: Referencing type-checking only symbols results in a NameError at runtime.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
from typing import TYPE_CHECKING, TypeAlias

if TYPE_CHECKING:
    from foo import Foo
OptFoo: TypeAlias = Foo | None

Use instead:

from typing import TYPE_CHECKING, TypeAlias

if TYPE_CHECKING:
    from foo import Foo
OptFoo: TypeAlias = "Foo | None"

docs.title: Fix safety
docs.text: This rule's fix is currently always marked as unsafe, since runtime typing libraries may try to access/resolve the type alias in a way that we can't statically determine during analysis and relies on the type alias not containing any forward references.

docs.title: References
docs.text: • PEP 613 – Explicit Type Aliases

docs.title: unraw-re-pattern (RUF039)
docs.text:
Fix is sometimes available.

This rule is unstable and in preview. The --preview flag is required for use.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text:
Reports the following re and regex calls when their first arguments are not raw strings:

  • For regex and re: compile, findall, finditer, fullmatch, match, search, split, sub, subn.
  • regex-specific: splititer, subf, subfn, template.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: Regular expressions should be written using raw strings to avoid double escaping.

docs.title: Fix safety
docs.text:
The fix is unsafe if the string/bytes literal contains an escape sequence because the fix alters the runtime value of the literal while retaining the regex semantics.

For example

# Literal is `1\n2`.
re.compile("1\n2")

# Literal is `1\\n2`, but the regex library will interpret `\\n` and will still match a newline
# character as before.
re.compile(r"1\n2")

docs.title: Fix availability
docs.text:
A fix is not available if either

  • the argument is a string with a (no-op) u prefix (e.g., u"foo") as the prefix is incompatible with the raw prefix r
  • the argument is a string or bytes literal with an escape sequence that has a different meaning in the context of a regular expression such as \b, which is word boundary or backspace in a regex, depending on the context, but always a backspace in string and bytes literals.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
re.compile("foo\\bar")

Use instead:

re.compile(r"foo\bar")

docs.title: unrecognized-platform-check (PYI007)
docs.text: Derived from the flake8-pyi linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text:
Check for unrecognized sys.platform checks. Platform checks should be simple string comparisons.

Note: this rule is only enabled in .pyi stub files.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: Some sys.platform checks are too complex for type checkers to understand, and thus result in incorrect inferences by these tools. sys.platform checks should be simple string comparisons, like if sys.platform == "linux".

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
import sys

if sys.platform == "xunil"[::-1]:
    # Linux specific definitions
    ...
else:
    # Posix specific definitions
    ...

Instead, use a simple string comparison, such as == or !=:

import sys

if sys.platform == "linux":
    # Linux specific definitions
    ...
else:
    # Posix specific definitions
    ...

docs.title: References
docs.text: • Typing documentation: Version and Platform checking

docs.title: unrecognized-platform-name (PYI008)
docs.text: Derived from the flake8-pyi linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text:
Check for unrecognized platform names in sys.platform checks.

Note: this rule is only enabled in .pyi stub files.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
If a sys.platform check compares to a platform name outside of a small set of known platforms (e.g. "linux", "win32", etc.), it's likely a typo or a platform name that is not recognized by type checkers.

The list of known platforms is: "linux", "win32", "cygwin", "darwin".

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
import sys

if sys.platform == "linus": ...

Use instead:

import sys

if sys.platform == "linux": ...

docs.title: References
docs.text: • Typing documentation: Version and Platform checking

docs.title: unrecognized-version-info-check (PYI003)
docs.text: Derived from the flake8-pyi linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for problematic sys.version_info-related conditions in stubs.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: Stub files support simple conditionals to test for differences in Python versions using sys.version_info. However, there are a number of common mistakes involving sys.version_info comparisons that should be avoided. For example, comparing against a string can lead to unexpected behavior.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
import sys

if sys.version_info[0] == "2": ...

Use instead:

import sys

if sys.version_info[0] == 2: ...

docs.title: References
docs.text: • Typing documentation: Version and Platform checking

docs.title: unreliable-callable-check (B004)
docs.text:
Derived from the flake8-bugbear linter.

Fix is sometimes available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for uses of hasattr to test if an object is callable (e.g., hasattr(obj, "__call__")).

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
Using hasattr is an unreliable mechanism for testing if an object is callable. If obj implements a custom __getattr__, or if its __call__ is itself not callable, you may get misleading results.

Instead, use callable(obj) to test if obj is callable.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
hasattr(obj, "__call__")

Use instead:

callable(obj)

docs.title: Fix safety
docs.text:
This rule's fix is marked as unsafe if there's comments in the hasattr call expression, as comments may be removed.

For example, the fix would be marked as unsafe in the following case:

hasattr(
    # comment 1
    obj,  # comment 2
    # comment 3
    "__call__",  # comment 4
    # comment 5
)

docs.title: References
docs.text:
• Python documentation: callable
  • Python documentation: hasattr
  • Python documentation: __getattr__
  • Python documentation: __call__

docs.title: unsafe-markup-use (S704)
docs.text: Derived from the flake8-bandit linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for non-literal strings being passed to markupsafe.Markup.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
[markupsafe.Markup][markupsafe.Markup] does not perform any escaping, so passing dynamic content, like f-strings, variables or interpolated strings will potentially lead to XSS vulnerabilities.

Instead you should interpolate the Markup object.

Using lint.flake8-bandit.extend-markup-names additional objects can be treated like Markup.

This rule was originally inspired by flake8-markupsafe but doesn't carve out any exceptions for i18n related calls by default.

You can use lint.flake8-bandit.allowed-markup-calls to specify exceptions.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
Given:

from markupsafe import Markup

content = "<script>alert('Hello, world!')</script>"
html = Markup(f"<b>{content}</b>")  # XSS

Use instead:

from markupsafe import Markup

content = "<script>alert('Hello, world!')</script>"
html = Markup("<b>{}</b>").format(content)  # Safe

Given:

from markupsafe import Markup

lines = [
    Markup("<b>heading</b>"),
    "<script>alert('XSS attempt')</script>",
]
html = Markup("<br>".join(lines))  # XSS

Use instead:

from markupsafe import Markup

lines = [
    Markup("<b>heading</b>"),
    "<script>alert('XSS attempt')</script>",
]
html = Markup("<br>").join(lines)  # Safe

docs.title: Options
docs.text:
• lint.flake8-bandit.extend-markup-names
  • lint.flake8-bandit.allowed-markup-calls

docs.title: References
docs.text:
• MarkupSafe on PyPI
  • markupsafe.Markup API documentation

docs.title: unsafe-yaml-load (S506)
docs.text: Derived from the flake8-bandit linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for uses of the yaml.load function.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
Running the yaml.load function over untrusted YAML files is insecure, as yaml.load allows for the creation of arbitrary Python objects, which can then be used to execute arbitrary code.

Instead, consider using yaml.safe_load, which allows for the creation of simple Python objects like integers and lists, but prohibits the creation of more complex objects like functions and classes.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
import yaml

yaml.load(untrusted_yaml)

Use instead:

import yaml

yaml.safe_load(untrusted_yaml)

docs.title: References
docs.text:
• PyYAML documentation: Loading YAML
  • Common Weakness Enumeration: CWE-20

docs.title: unsorted-dunder-all (RUF022)
docs.text: Fix is sometimes available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text:
Checks for __all__ definitions that are not ordered according to an "isort-style" sort.

An isort-style sort orders items first according to their casing: SCREAMING_SNAKE_CASE names (conventionally used for global constants) come first, followed by CamelCase names (conventionally used for classes), followed by anything else. Within each category, a natural sort is used to order the elements.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: Consistency is good. Use a common convention for __all__ to make your code more readable and idiomatic.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
import sys

__all__ = [
    "b",
    "c",
    "a",
]

if sys.platform == "win32":
    __all__ += ["z", "y"]

Use instead:

import sys

__all__ = [
    "a",
    "b",
    "c",
]

if sys.platform == "win32":
    __all__ += ["y", "z"]

docs.title: Fix safety
docs.text:
This rule's fix is marked as unsafe if there are any comments that take up a whole line by themselves inside the __all__ definition, for example:

__all__ = [
    # eggy things
    "duck_eggs",
    "chicken_eggs",
    # hammy things
    "country_ham",
    "parma_ham",
]

This is a common pattern used to delimit categories within a module's API, but it would be out of the scope of this rule to attempt to maintain these categories when alphabetically sorting the items of __all__.

The fix is also marked as unsafe if there are more than two __all__ items on a single line and that line also has a trailing comment, since here it is impossible to accurately gauge which item the comment should be moved with when sorting __all__:

__all__ = [
    "a", "c", "e",  # a comment
    "b", "d", "f",  # a second  comment
]

Other than this, the rule's fix is marked as always being safe, in that it should very rarely alter the semantics of any Python code. However, note that (although it's rare) the value of __all__ could be read by code elsewhere that depends on the exact iteration order of the items in __all__, in which case this rule's fix could theoretically cause breakage.

docs.title: unsorted-dunder-slots (RUF023)
docs.text: Fix is sometimes available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for __slots__ definitions that are not ordered according to a natural sort.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: Consistency is good. Use a common convention for this special variable to make your code more readable and idiomatic.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
class Dog:
    __slots__ = "name", "breed"

Use instead:

class Dog:
    __slots__ = "breed", "name"

docs.title: Fix safety
docs.text:
This rule's fix is marked as unsafe in three situations.

Firstly, the fix is unsafe if there are any comments that take up a whole line by themselves inside the __slots__ definition, for example:

class Foo:
    __slots__ = [
        # eggy things
        "duck_eggs",
        "chicken_eggs",
        # hammy things
        "country_ham",
        "parma_ham",
    ]

This is a common pattern used to delimit categories within a class's slots, but it would be out of the scope of this rule to attempt to maintain these categories when applying a natural sort to the items of __slots__.

Secondly, the fix is also marked as unsafe if there are more than two __slots__ items on a single line and that line also has a trailing comment, since here it is impossible to accurately gauge which item the comment should be moved with when sorting __slots__:

class Bar:
    __slots__ = [
        "a", "c", "e",  # a comment
        "b", "d", "f",  # a second  comment
    ]

Lastly, this rule's fix is marked as unsafe whenever Ruff can detect that code elsewhere in the same file reads the __slots__ variable in some way and the __slots__ variable is not assigned to a set. This is because the order of the items in __slots__ may have semantic significance if the __slots__ of a class is being iterated over, or being assigned to another value.

In the vast majority of other cases, this rule's fix is unlikely to cause breakage; as such, Ruff will otherwise mark this rule's fix as safe. However, note that (although it's rare) the value of __slots__ could still be read by code outside of the module in which the __slots__ definition occurs, in which case this rule's fix could theoretically cause breakage.

docs.title: unsorted-imports (I001)
docs.text:
Derived from the isort linter.

Fix is sometimes available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: De-duplicates, groups, and sorts imports based on the provided isort settings.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: Consistency is good. Use a common convention for imports to make your code more readable and idiomatic.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
import pandas
import numpy as np

Use instead:

import numpy as np
import pandas

docs.title: Preview
docs.text: When preview mode is enabled, Ruff applies a stricter criterion for determining whether an import should be classified as first-party. Specifically, for an import of the form import foo.bar.baz, Ruff will check that foo/bar, relative to a user-specified src directory, contains either the directory baz or else a file with the name baz.py or baz.pyi.

docs.title: unspecified-encoding (PLW1514)
docs.text:
Derived from the Pylint linter.

Fix is always available.

This rule is unstable and in preview. The --preview flag is required for use.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for uses of open and related calls without an explicit encoding argument.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
Using open in text mode without an explicit encoding can lead to non-portable code, with differing behavior across platforms. While readers may assume that UTF-8 is the default encoding, in reality, the default is locale-specific.

Instead, consider using the encoding parameter to enforce a specific encoding. PEP 597 recommends the use of encoding="utf-8" as a default, and suggests that it may become the default in future versions of Python.

If a locale-specific encoding is intended, use encoding="locale" on Python 3.10 and later, or locale.getpreferredencoding() on earlier versions, to make the encoding explicit.

docs.title: Fix safety
docs.text:
This fix is always unsafe and may change the program's behavior. It forces encoding="utf-8" as the default, regardless of the platform’s actual default encoding, which may cause UnicodeDecodeError on non-UTF-8 systems.

with open("test.txt") as f:
    print(f.read()) # before fix (on UTF-8 systems): 你好，世界！
with open("test.txt", encoding="utf-8") as f:
    print(f.read()) # after fix (on Windows): UnicodeDecodeError

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
open("file.txt")

Use instead:

open("file.txt", encoding="utf-8")

docs.title: References
docs.text: • Python documentation: open

docs.title: unsupported-method-call-on-all (PYI056)
docs.text: Derived from the flake8-pyi linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks that append, extend and remove methods are not called on __all__.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: Different type checkers have varying levels of support for calling these methods on __all__. Instead, use the += operator to add items to __all__, which is known to be supported by all major type checkers.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
import sys

__all__ = ["A", "B"]

if sys.version_info >= (3, 10):
    __all__.append("C")

if sys.version_info >= (3, 11):
    __all__.remove("B")

Use instead:

import sys

__all__ = ["A"]

if sys.version_info < (3, 11):
    __all__ += ["B"]

if sys.version_info >= (3, 10):
    __all__ += ["C"]

docs.title: unused-annotation (F842)
docs.text: Derived from the Pyflakes linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for local variables that are annotated but never used.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: Annotations are used to provide type hints to static type checkers. If a variable is annotated but never used, the annotation is unnecessary.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
def foo():
    bar: int

docs.title: References
docs.text: • PEP 484 – Type Hints

docs.title: unused-async (RUF029)
docs.text: This rule is unstable and in preview. The --preview flag is required for use.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for functions declared async that do not await or otherwise use features requiring the function to be declared async.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: Declaring a function async when it's not is usually a mistake, and will artificially limit the contexts where that function may be called. In some cases, labeling a function async is semantically meaningful (e.g. with the trio library).

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
async def foo():
    bar()

Use instead:

def foo():
    bar()

docs.title: unused-class-method-argument (ARG003)
docs.text: Derived from the flake8-unused-arguments linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for the presence of unused arguments in class method definitions.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
An argument that is defined but not used is likely a mistake, and should be removed to avoid confusion.

If a variable is intentionally defined-but-not-used, it should be prefixed with an underscore, or some other value that adheres to the lint.dummy-variable-rgx pattern.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
class Class:
    @classmethod
    def foo(cls, arg1, arg2):
        print(arg1)

Use instead:

class Class:
    @classmethod
    def foo(cls, arg1):
        print(arg1)

docs.title: Options
docs.text: • lint.dummy-variable-rgx

docs.title: unused-function-argument (ARG001)
docs.text: Derived from the flake8-unused-arguments linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for the presence of unused arguments in function definitions.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
An argument that is defined but not used is likely a mistake, and should be removed to avoid confusion.

If a variable is intentionally defined-but-not-used, it should be prefixed with an underscore, or some other value that adheres to the lint.dummy-variable-rgx pattern.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
def foo(bar, baz):
    return bar * 2

Use instead:

def foo(bar):
    return bar * 2

docs.title: Options
docs.text: • lint.dummy-variable-rgx

docs.title: unused-import (F401)
docs.text:
Derived from the Pyflakes linter.

Fix is sometimes available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for unused imports.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
Unused imports add a performance overhead at runtime, and risk creating import cycles. They also increase the cognitive load of reading the code.

If an import statement is used to check for the availability or existence of a module, consider using importlib.util.find_spec instead.

If an import statement is used to re-export a symbol as part of a module's public interface, consider using a "redundant" import alias, which instructs Ruff (and other tools) to respect the re-export, and avoid marking it as unused, as in:

from module import member as member

Alternatively, you can use __all__ to declare a symbol as part of the module's interface, as in:

# __init__.py
import some_module

__all__ = ["some_module"]

docs.title: Fix safety
docs.text:
Fixes to remove unused imports are safe, except in __init__.py files.

Applying fixes to __init__.py files is currently in preview. The fix offered depends on the type of the unused import. Ruff will suggest a safe fix to export first-party imports with either a redundant alias or, if already present in the file, an __all__ entry. If multiple __all__ declarations are present, Ruff will not offer a fix. Ruff will suggest an unsafe fix to remove third-party and standard library imports -- the fix is unsafe because the module's interface changes.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
import numpy as np  # unused import


def area(radius):
    return 3.14 * radius**2

Use instead:

def area(radius):
    return 3.14 * radius**2

To check the availability of a module, use importlib.util.find_spec:

from importlib.util import find_spec

if find_spec("numpy") is not None:
    print("numpy is installed")
else:
    print("numpy is not installed")

docs.title: Preview
docs.text: When preview is enabled, the criterion for determining whether an import is first-party is stricter, which could affect the suggested fix. See this FAQ section for more details.

docs.title: Options
docs.text:
• lint.ignore-init-module-imports
  • lint.pyflakes.allowed-unused-imports

docs.title: References
docs.text:
• Python documentation: import
  • Python documentation: importlib.util.find_spec
  • Typing documentation: interface conventions

docs.title: unused-lambda-argument (ARG005)
docs.text: Derived from the flake8-unused-arguments linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for the presence of unused arguments in lambda expression definitions.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
An argument that is defined but not used is likely a mistake, and should be removed to avoid confusion.

If a variable is intentionally defined-but-not-used, it should be prefixed with an underscore, or some other value that adheres to the lint.dummy-variable-rgx pattern.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
my_list = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]
squares = map(lambda x, y: x**2, my_list)

Use instead:

my_list = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]
squares = map(lambda x: x**2, my_list)

docs.title: Options
docs.text: • lint.dummy-variable-rgx

docs.title: unused-loop-control-variable (B007)
docs.text:
Derived from the flake8-bugbear linter.

Fix is sometimes available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for unused variables in loops (e.g., for and while statements).

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
Defining a variable in a loop statement that is never used can confuse readers.

If the variable is intended to be unused (e.g., to facilitate destructuring of a tuple or other object), prefix it with an underscore to indicate the intent. Otherwise, remove the variable entirely.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
for i, j in foo:
    bar(i)

Use instead:

for i, _j in foo:
    bar(i)

docs.title: References
docs.text: • PEP 8: Naming Conventions

docs.title: unused-method-argument (ARG002)
docs.text: Derived from the flake8-unused-arguments linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for the presence of unused arguments in instance method definitions.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
An argument that is defined but not used is likely a mistake, and should be removed to avoid confusion.

If a variable is intentionally defined-but-not-used, it should be prefixed with an underscore, or some other value that adheres to the lint.dummy-variable-rgx pattern.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
class Class:
    def foo(self, arg1, arg2):
        print(arg1)

Use instead:

class Class:
    def foo(self, arg1):
        print(arg1)

docs.title: Options
docs.text: • lint.dummy-variable-rgx

docs.title: unused-noqa (RUF100)
docs.text: Fix is always available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for noqa directives that are no longer applicable.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: A noqa directive that no longer matches any diagnostic violations is likely included by mistake, and should be removed to avoid confusion.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
import foo  # noqa: F401


def bar():
    foo.bar()

Use instead:

import foo


def bar():
    foo.bar()
