docs.text: • lint.external

docs.title: References
docs.text: • Ruff error suppression

docs.title: unused-private-protocol (PYI046)
docs.text: Derived from the flake8-pyi linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for the presence of unused private typing.Protocol definitions.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: A private typing.Protocol that is defined but not used is likely a mistake. It should either be used, made public, or removed to avoid confusion.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
import typing

class _PrivateProtocol(typing.Protocol):
    foo: int

Use instead:

import typing

class _PrivateProtocol(typing.Protocol):
    foo: int

def func(arg: _PrivateProtocol) -> None: ...

docs.title: unused-private-type-alias (PYI047)
docs.text: Derived from the flake8-pyi linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for the presence of unused private type aliases.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: A private type alias that is defined but not used is likely a mistake. It should either be used, made public, or removed to avoid confusion.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
import typing

_UnusedTypeAlias: typing.TypeAlias = int

Use instead:

import typing

_UsedTypeAlias: typing.TypeAlias = int

def func(arg: _UsedTypeAlias) -> _UsedTypeAlias: ...

docs.title: unused-private-type-var (PYI018)
docs.text:
Derived from the flake8-pyi linter.

Fix is sometimes available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for the presence of unused private TypeVar, ParamSpec or TypeVarTuple declarations.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: A private TypeVar that is defined but not used is likely a mistake. It should either be used, made public, or removed to avoid confusion. A type variable is considered "private" if its name starts with an underscore.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
import typing
import typing_extensions

_T = typing.TypeVar("_T")
_Ts = typing_extensions.TypeVarTuple("_Ts")

docs.title: Fix safety
docs.text: The fix is always marked as unsafe, as it would break your code if the type variable is imported by another module.

docs.title: unused-private-typed-dict (PYI049)
docs.text: Derived from the flake8-pyi linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for the presence of unused private typing.TypedDict definitions.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: A private typing.TypedDict that is defined but not used is likely a mistake. It should either be used, made public, or removed to avoid confusion.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
import typing

class _UnusedPrivateTypedDict(typing.TypedDict):
    foo: list[int]

Use instead:

import typing

class _UsedPrivateTypedDict(typing.TypedDict):
    foo: set[str]

def func(arg: _UsedPrivateTypedDict) -> _UsedPrivateTypedDict: ...

docs.title: unused-static-method-argument (ARG004)
docs.text: Derived from the flake8-unused-arguments linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for the presence of unused arguments in static method definitions.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
An argument that is defined but not used is likely a mistake, and should be removed to avoid confusion.

If a variable is intentionally defined-but-not-used, it should be prefixed with an underscore, or some other value that adheres to the lint.dummy-variable-rgx pattern.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
class Class:
    @staticmethod
    def foo(arg1, arg2):
        print(arg1)

Use instead:

class Class:
    @staticmethod
    def foo(arg1):
        print(arg1)

docs.title: Options
docs.text: • lint.dummy-variable-rgx

docs.title: unused-unpacked-variable (RUF059)
docs.text:
Fix is sometimes available.

This rule is unstable and in preview. The --preview flag is required for use.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for the presence of unused variables in unpacked assignments.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
A variable that is defined but never used can confuse readers.

If a variable is intentionally defined-but-not-used, it should be prefixed with an underscore, or some other value that adheres to the lint.dummy-variable-rgx pattern.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
def get_pair():
    return 1, 2


def foo():
    x, y = get_pair()
    return x

Use instead:

def foo():
    x, _ = get_pair()
    return x

docs.title: Options
docs.text: • lint.dummy-variable-rgx

docs.title: unused-variable (F841)
docs.text:
Derived from the Pyflakes linter.

Fix is sometimes available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for the presence of unused variables in function scopes.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
A variable that is defined but not used is likely a mistake, and should be removed to avoid confusion.

If a variable is intentionally defined-but-not-used, it should be prefixed with an underscore, or some other value that adheres to the lint.dummy-variable-rgx pattern.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
def foo():
    x = 1
    y = 2
    return x

Use instead:

def foo():
    x = 1
    return x

docs.title: Fix safety
docs.text: This rule's fix is marked as unsafe because removing an unused variable assignment may delete comments that are attached to the assignment.

docs.title: Options
docs.text: • lint.dummy-variable-rgx

docs.title: used-dummy-variable (RUF052)
docs.text:
Fix is sometimes available.

This rule is unstable and in preview. The --preview flag is required for use.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text:
Checks for "dummy variables" (variables that are named as if to indicate they are unused) that are in fact used.

By default, "dummy variables" are any variables with names that start with leading underscores. However, this is customisable using the lint.dummy-variable-rgx setting).

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
Marking a variable with a leading underscore conveys that it is intentionally unused within the function or method. When these variables are later referenced in the code, it causes confusion and potential misunderstandings about the code's intention. If a variable marked as "unused" is subsequently used, it suggests that either the variable could be given a clearer name, or that the code is accidentally making use of the wrong variable.

Sometimes leading underscores are used to avoid variables shadowing other variables, Python builtins, or Python keywords. However, PEP 8 recommends to use trailing underscores for this rather than leading underscores.

Dunder variables are ignored by this rule, as are variables named _. Only local variables in function scopes are flagged by the rule.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
def function():
    _variable = 3
    # important: avoid shadowing the builtin `id()` function!
    _id = 4
    return _variable + _id

Use instead:

def function():
    variable = 3
    # important: avoid shadowing the builtin `id()` function!
    id_ = 4
    return variable + id_

docs.title: Fix availability
docs.text: The rule's fix is only available for variables that start with leading underscores. It will also only be available if the "obvious" new name for the variable would not shadow any other known variables already accessible from the scope in which the variable is defined.

docs.title: Fix safety
docs.text:
This rule's fix is marked as unsafe.

For this rule's fix, Ruff renames the variable and fixes up all known references to it so they point to the renamed variable. However, some renamings also require other changes such as different arguments to constructor calls or alterations to comments. Ruff is aware of some of these cases: _T = TypeVar("_T") will be fixed to T = TypeVar("T") if the _T binding is flagged by this rule. However, in general, cases like these are hard to detect and hard to automatically fix.

docs.title: Options
docs.text: • lint.dummy-variable-rgx

docs.title: useless-class-metaclass-type (UP050)
docs.text:
Derived from the pyupgrade linter.

Fix is sometimes available.

This rule is unstable and in preview. The --preview flag is required for use.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for metaclass=type in class definitions.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
Since Python 3, the default metaclass is type, so specifying it explicitly is redundant.

Even though __prepare__ is not required, the default metaclass (type) implements it, for the convenience of subclasses calling it via super().

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
class Foo(metaclass=type): ...

Use instead:

class Foo: ...

docs.title: References
docs.text: • PEP 3115 – Metaclasses in Python 3000

docs.title: useless-comparison (B015)
docs.text: Derived from the flake8-bugbear linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for useless comparisons.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: Useless comparisons have no effect on the program, and are often included by mistake. If the comparison is intended to enforce an invariant, prepend the comparison with an assert. Otherwise, remove it entirely.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
foo == bar

Use instead:

assert foo == bar, "`foo` and `bar` should be equal."

docs.title: Notebook behavior
docs.text: For Jupyter Notebooks, this rule is not applied to the last top-level expression in a cell. This is because it's common to have a notebook cell that ends with an expression, which will result in the repr of the evaluated expression being printed as the cell's output.

docs.title: References
docs.text: • Python documentation: assert statement

docs.title: useless-contextlib-suppress (B022)
docs.text: Derived from the flake8-bugbear linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for contextlib.suppress without arguments.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
contextlib.suppress is a context manager that suppresses exceptions. It takes, as arguments, the exceptions to suppress within the enclosed block. If no exceptions are specified, then the context manager won't suppress any exceptions, and is thus redundant.

Consider adding exceptions to the contextlib.suppress call, or removing the context manager entirely.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
import contextlib

with contextlib.suppress():
    foo()

Use instead:

import contextlib

with contextlib.suppress(Exception):
    foo()

docs.title: References
docs.text: • Python documentation: contextlib.suppress

docs.title: useless-else-on-loop (PLW0120)
docs.text:
Derived from the Pylint linter.

Fix is sometimes available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for else clauses on loops without a break statement.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
When a loop includes an else statement, the code inside the else clause will be executed if the loop terminates "normally" (i.e., without a break).

If a loop always terminates "normally" (i.e., does not contain a break), then the else clause is redundant, as the code inside the else clause will always be executed.

In such cases, the code inside the else clause can be moved outside the loop entirely, and the else clause can be removed.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
for item in items:
    print(item)
else:
    print("All items printed")

Use instead:

for item in items:
    print(item)
print("All items printed")

docs.title: References
docs.text: • Python documentation: break and continue Statements, and else Clauses on Loops

docs.title: useless-exception-statement (PLW0133)
docs.text:
Derived from the Pylint linter.

Fix is sometimes available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for an exception that is not raised.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: It's unnecessary to create an exception without raising it. For example, ValueError("...") on its own will have no effect (unlike raise ValueError("...")) and is likely a mistake.

docs.title: Known problems
docs.text: This rule only detects built-in exceptions, like ValueError, and does not catch user-defined exceptions.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
ValueError("...")

Use instead:

raise ValueError("...")

docs.title: Fix safety
docs.text: This rule's fix is marked as unsafe, as converting a useless exception statement to a raise statement will change the program's behavior.

docs.title: useless-expression (B018)
docs.text: Derived from the flake8-bugbear linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for useless expressions.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: Useless expressions have no effect on the program, and are often included by mistake. Assign a useless expression to a variable, or remove it entirely.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
1 + 1

Use instead:

foo = 1 + 1

docs.title: Notebook behavior
docs.text: For Jupyter Notebooks, this rule is not applied to the last top-level expression in a cell. This is because it's common to have a notebook cell that ends with an expression, which will result in the repr of the evaluated expression being printed as the cell's output.

docs.title: Known problems
docs.text:
This rule ignores expression types that are commonly used for their side effects, such as function calls.

However, if a seemingly useless expression (like an attribute access) is needed to trigger a side effect, consider assigning it to an anonymous variable, to indicate that the return value is intentionally ignored.

For example, given:

with errors.ExceptionRaisedContext():
    obj.attribute

Use instead:

with errors.ExceptionRaisedContext():
    _ = obj.attribute

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for useless if-else conditions with identical arms.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: Useless if-else conditions add unnecessary complexity to the code without providing any logical benefit. Assigning the value directly is clearer.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
foo = x if y else x

Use instead:

foo = x

docs.title: useless-import-alias (PLC0414)
docs.text:
Derived from the Pylint linter.

Fix is sometimes available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text:
Checks for import aliases that do not rename the original package.

In preview this rule does not apply in __init__.py files.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: The import alias is redundant and should be removed to avoid confusion.

docs.title: Fix safety
docs.text: This fix is marked as always unsafe because the user may be intentionally re-exporting the import. While statements like import numpy as numpy appear redundant, they can have semantic meaning in certain contexts.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
import numpy as numpy

Use instead:

import numpy as np

or

import numpy

docs.title: useless-metaclass-type (UP001)
docs.text:
Derived from the pyupgrade linter.

Fix is always available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for the use of __metaclass__ = type in class definitions.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: Since Python 3, __metaclass__ = type is implied and can thus be omitted.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
class Foo:
    __metaclass__ = type

Use instead:

class Foo: ...

docs.title: References
docs.text: • PEP 3115 – Metaclasses in Python 3000

docs.title: useless-object-inheritance (UP004)
docs.text:
Derived from the pyupgrade linter.

Fix is always available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for classes that inherit from object.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: Since Python 3, all classes inherit from object by default, so object can be omitted from the list of base classes.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
class Foo(object): ...

Use instead:

class Foo: ...

docs.title: Fix safety
docs.text: This fix is unsafe if it would cause comments to be deleted.

docs.title: References
docs.text: • PEP 3115 – Metaclasses in Python 3000

docs.title: useless-return (PLR1711)
docs.text:
Derived from the Pylint linter.

Fix is always available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for functions that end with an unnecessary return or return None, and contain no other return statements.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: Python implicitly assumes a None return at the end of a function, making it unnecessary to explicitly write return None.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
def f():
    print(5)
    return None

Use instead:

def f():
    print(5)

docs.title: useless-semicolon (E703)
docs.text:
Derived from the pycodestyle linter.

Fix is always available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for statements that end with an unnecessary semicolon.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: A trailing semicolon is unnecessary and should be removed.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
do_four();  # useless semicolon

Use instead:

do_four()

docs.title: useless-try-except (TRY203)
docs.text: Derived from the tryceratops linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for immediate uses of raise within exception handlers.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: Capturing an exception, only to immediately reraise it, has no effect. Instead, remove the error-handling code and let the exception propagate upwards without the unnecessary try-except block.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
def foo():
    try:
        bar()
    except NotImplementedError:
        raise

Use instead:

def foo():
    bar()

docs.title: useless-with-lock (PLW2101)
docs.text: Derived from the Pylint linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for lock objects that are created and immediately discarded in with statements.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
Creating a lock (via threading.Lock or similar) in a with statement has no effect, as locks are only relevant when shared between threads.

Instead, assign the lock to a variable outside the with statement, and share that variable between threads.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
import threading

counter = 0


def increment():
    global counter

    with threading.Lock():
        counter += 1

Use instead:

import threading

counter = 0
lock = threading.Lock()


def increment():
    global counter

    with lock:
        counter += 1

docs.title: References
docs.text: • Python documentation: Lock Objects

docs.title: utf8-encoding-declaration (UP009)
docs.text:
Derived from the pyupgrade linter.

Fix is always available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for unnecessary UTF-8 encoding declarations.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: PEP 3120 makes UTF-8 the default encoding, so a UTF-8 encoding declaration is unnecessary.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
# -*- coding: utf-8 -*-
print("Hello, world!")

Use instead:

print("Hello, world!")

docs.title: verbose-decimal-constructor (FURB157)
docs.text:
Derived from the refurb linter.

Fix is always available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for unnecessary string literal or float casts in Decimal constructors.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
The Decimal constructor accepts a variety of arguments, including integers, floats, and strings. However, it's not necessary to cast integer literals to strings when passing them to the Decimal.

Similarly, Decimal accepts inf, -inf, and nan as string literals, so there's no need to wrap those values in a float call when passing them to the Decimal constructor.

Prefer the more concise form of argument passing for Decimal constructors, as it's more readable and idiomatic.

Note that this rule does not flag quoted float literals such as Decimal("0.1"), which will produce a more precise Decimal value than the unquoted Decimal(0.1).

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
from decimal import Decimal

Decimal("0")
Decimal(float("Infinity"))

Use instead:

from decimal import Decimal

Decimal(0)
Decimal("Infinity")

docs.title: References
docs.text: • Python documentation: decimal

docs.title: verbose-log-message (TRY401)
docs.text: Derived from the tryceratops linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for excessive logging of exception objects.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: When logging exceptions via logging.exception, the exception object is logged automatically. Including the exception object in the log message is redundant and can lead to excessive logging.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
try:
    ...
except ValueError as e:
    logger.exception(f"Found an error: {e}")

Use instead:

try:
    ...
except ValueError:
    logger.exception("Found an error")

docs.title: verbose-raise (TRY201)
docs.text:
Derived from the tryceratops linter.

Fix is always available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for needless exception names in raise statements.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: It's redundant to specify the exception name in a raise statement if the exception is being re-raised.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
def foo():
    try:
        ...
    except ValueError as exc:
        raise exc

Use instead:

def foo():
    try:
        ...
    except ValueError:
        raise

docs.title: Fix safety
docs.text: This rule's fix is marked as unsafe, as it doesn't properly handle bound exceptions that are shadowed between the except and raise statements.

docs.title: wait-for-process-in-async-function (ASYNC222)
docs.text: Derived from the flake8-async linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks that async functions do not wait on processes with blocking methods.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
Blocking an async function via a blocking call will block the entire event loop, preventing it from executing other tasks while waiting for the call to complete, negating the benefits of asynchronous programming.

Instead of making a blocking call, use an equivalent asynchronous library or function, like trio.to_thread.run_sync() or anyio.to_thread.run_sync().

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
import os


async def foo():
    os.waitpid(0)

Use instead:

import asyncio
import os


def wait_for_process():
    os.waitpid(0)


async def foo():
    await asyncio.loop.run_in_executor(None, wait_for_process)

docs.title: weak-cryptographic-key (S505)
docs.text: Derived from the flake8-bandit linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for uses of cryptographic keys with vulnerable key sizes.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: Small keys are easily breakable. For DSA and RSA, keys should be at least 2048 bits long. For EC, keys should be at least 224 bits long.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
from cryptography.hazmat.primitives.asymmetric import dsa, ec

dsa.generate_private_key(key_size=512)
ec.generate_private_key(curve=ec.SECT163K1())

Use instead:

from cryptography.hazmat.primitives.asymmetric import dsa, ec

dsa.generate_private_key(key_size=4096)
ec.generate_private_key(curve=ec.SECP384R1())

docs.title: References
docs.text: • CSRC: Transitioning the Use of Cryptographic Algorithms and Key Lengths

docs.title: whitespace-after-decorator (E204)
docs.text:
Derived from the pycodestyle linter.

Fix is always available.

This rule is unstable and in preview. The --preview flag is required for use.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for trailing whitespace after a decorator's opening @.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: Including whitespace after the @ symbol is not compliant with PEP 8.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
@ decorator
def func():
   pass

Use instead:

@decorator
def func():
  pass

docs.title: whitespace-after-open-bracket (E201)
docs.text:
Derived from the pycodestyle linter.

Fix is always available.

This rule is unstable and in preview. The --preview flag is required for use.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for the use of extraneous whitespace after "(", "[" or "{".

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
PEP 8 recommends the omission of whitespace in the following cases:

  • "Immediately inside parentheses, brackets or braces."
  • "Immediately before a comma, semicolon, or colon."

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
spam( ham[1], {eggs: 2})
spam(ham[ 1], {eggs: 2})
spam(ham[1], { eggs: 2})

Use instead:

spam(ham[1], {eggs: 2})

docs.title: whitespace-before-close-bracket (E202)
docs.text:
Derived from the pycodestyle linter.

Fix is always available.

This rule is unstable and in preview. The --preview flag is required for use.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for the use of extraneous whitespace before ")", "]" or "}".

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
PEP 8 recommends the omission of whitespace in the following cases:

  • "Immediately inside parentheses, brackets or braces."
  • "Immediately before a comma, semicolon, or colon."

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
spam(ham[1], {eggs: 2} )
spam(ham[1 ], {eggs: 2})
spam(ham[1], {eggs: 2 })

Use instead:

spam(ham[1], {eggs: 2})

docs.title: whitespace-before-parameters (E211)
docs.text:
Derived from the pycodestyle linter.

Fix is always available.

This rule is unstable and in preview. The --preview flag is required for use.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for extraneous whitespace immediately preceding an open parenthesis or bracket.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: According to PEP 8, open parentheses and brackets should not be preceded by any trailing whitespace.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
spam (1)

Use instead:

spam(1)

docs.title: whitespace-before-punctuation (E203)
docs.text:
Derived from the pycodestyle linter.

Fix is always available.

This rule is unstable and in preview. The --preview flag is required for use.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for the use of extraneous whitespace before ",", ";" or ":".

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
PEP 8 recommends the omission of whitespace in the following cases:

  • "Immediately inside parentheses, brackets or braces."
  • "Immediately before a comma, semicolon, or colon."

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
if x == 4: print(x, y); x, y = y , x

Use instead:

if x == 4: print(x, y); x, y = y, x

docs.title: write-whole-file (FURB103)
docs.text:
Derived from the refurb linter.

This rule is unstable and in preview. The --preview flag is required for use.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for uses of open and write that can be replaced by pathlib methods, like Path.write_text and Path.write_bytes.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: When writing a single string to a file, it's simpler and more concise to use pathlib methods like Path.write_text and Path.write_bytes instead of open and write calls via with statements.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
with open(filename, "w") as f:
    f.write(contents)

Use instead:

from pathlib import Path

Path(filename).write_text(contents)

docs.title: wrong-tuple-length-version-comparison (PYI005)
docs.text: Derived from the flake8-pyi linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for Python version comparisons that compare against a tuple of the wrong length.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: Stub files support simple conditionals to test for differences in Python versions and platforms. When comparing against sys.version_info, avoid comparing against tuples of the wrong length, which can lead to unexpected behavior.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
import sys

if sys.version_info[:2] == (3,): ...

Use instead:

import sys

if sys.version_info[0] == 3: ...

docs.title: References
docs.text: • Typing documentation: Version and Platform checking

docs.title: yield-from-in-async-function (PLE1700)
docs.text: Derived from the Pylint linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for uses of yield from in async functions.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
Python doesn't support the use of yield from in async functions, and will raise a SyntaxError in such cases.

Instead, considering refactoring the code to use an async for loop instead.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
async def numbers():
    yield from [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]

Use instead:

async def numbers():
    async for number in [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]:
        yield number

docs.title: yield-in-for-loop (UP028)
docs.text:
Derived from the pyupgrade linter.

Fix is sometimes available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for for loops that can be replaced with yield from expressions.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: If a for loop only contains a yield statement, it can be replaced with a yield from expression, which is more concise and idiomatic.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
def bar():
    for x in foo:
        yield x

    global y
    for y in foo:
        yield y

Use instead:

def bar():
    yield from foo

    for _element in foo:
        y = _element
        yield y

docs.title: Fix safety
docs.text:
This rule's fix is marked as unsafe, as converting a for loop to a yield from expression can change the behavior of the program in rare cases. For example, if a generator is being sent values via send, then rewriting to a yield from could lead to an attribute error if the underlying generator does not implement the send method.

Additionally, if at least one target is global or nonlocal, no fix will be offered.

In most cases, however, the fix is safe, and such a modification should have no effect on the behavior of the program.

docs.title: References
docs.text:
• Python documentation: The yield statement
  • PEP 380 – Syntax for Delegating to a Subgenerator

docs.title: yield-in-init (PLE0100)
docs.text: Derived from the Pylint linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for __init__ methods that are turned into generators by the inclusion of yield or yield from expressions.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
The __init__ method is the constructor for a given Python class, responsible for initializing, rather than creating, new objects.

The __init__ method has to return None. By including a yield or yield from expression in an __init__, the method will return a generator object when called at runtime, resulting in a runtime error.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
class InitIsGenerator:
    def __init__(self, i):
        yield i

docs.title: References
docs.text: • CodeQL: py-init-method-is-generator

docs.title: yield-outside-function (F704)
docs.text: Derived from the Pyflakes linter.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for yield, yield from, and await usages outside of functions.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: The use of yield, yield from, or await outside of a function will raise a SyntaxError.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
class Foo:
    yield 1

docs.title: Notebook behavior
docs.text: As an exception, await is allowed at the top level of a Jupyter notebook (see: autoawait).

docs.title: References
docs.text: • Python documentation: yield

docs.title: yoda-conditions (SIM300)
docs.text:
Derived from the flake8-simplify linter.

Fix is sometimes available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for conditions that position a constant on the left-hand side of the comparison operator, rather than the right-hand side.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
These conditions (sometimes referred to as "Yoda conditions") are less readable than conditions that place the variable on the left-hand side of the comparison operator.

In some languages, Yoda conditions are used to prevent accidental assignment in conditions (i.e., accidental uses of the = operator, instead of the == operator). However, Python does not allow assignments in conditions unless using the := operator, so Yoda conditions provide no benefit in this regard.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
if "Foo" == foo:
    ...

Use instead:

if foo == "Foo":
    ...

docs.title: References
docs.text:
• Python documentation: Comparisons
  • Python documentation: Assignment statements

docs.title: zip-dict-keys-and-values (SIM911)
docs.text:
Derived from the flake8-simplify linter.

Fix is always available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for use of zip() to iterate over keys and values of a dictionary at once.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text: The dict type provides an .items() method which is faster and more readable.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
flag_stars = {"USA": 50, "Slovenia": 3, "Panama": 2, "Australia": 6}

for country, stars in zip(flag_stars.keys(), flag_stars.values()):
    print(f"{country}'s flag has {stars} stars.")

Use instead:

flag_stars = {"USA": 50, "Slovenia": 3, "Panama": 2, "Australia": 6}

for country, stars in flag_stars.items():
    print(f"{country}'s flag has {stars} stars.")

docs.title: References
docs.text: • Python documentation: dict.items

docs.title: zip-instead-of-pairwise (RUF007)
docs.text: Fix is sometimes available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for use of zip() to iterate over successive pairs of elements.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
When iterating over successive pairs of elements, prefer itertools.pairwise() over zip().

itertools.pairwise() is more readable and conveys the intent of the code more clearly.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
letters = "ABCD"
zip(letters, letters[1:])  # ("A", "B"), ("B", "C"), ("C", "D")

Use instead:

from itertools import pairwise

letters = "ABCD"
pairwise(letters)  # ("A", "B"), ("B", "C"), ("C", "D")

docs.title: Fix safety
docs.text: The fix is always marked unsafe because it assumes that slicing an object (e.g., obj[1:]) produces a value with the same type and iteration behavior as the original object, which is not guaranteed for user-defined types that override __getitem__ without properly handling slices. Moreover, the fix could delete comments.

docs.title: References
docs.text: • Python documentation: itertools.pairwise

docs.title: zip-without-explicit-strict (B905)
docs.text:
Derived from the flake8-bugbear linter.

Fix is always available.

docs.title: What it does
docs.text: Checks for zip calls without an explicit strict parameter.

docs.title: Why is this bad?
docs.text:
By default, if the iterables passed to zip are of different lengths, the resulting iterator will be silently truncated to the length of the shortest iterable. This can lead to subtle bugs.

Pass strict=True to raise a ValueError if the iterables are of non-uniform length. Alternatively, if the iterables are deliberately of different lengths, pass strict=False to make the intention explicit.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
zip(a, b)

Use instead:

zip(a, b, strict=True)

docs.title: Fix safety
docs.text: This rule's fix is marked as unsafe for zip calls that contain **kwargs, as adding a strict keyword argument to such a call may lead to a duplicate keyword argument error.

docs.title: References
docs.text: • Python documentation: zip
